PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, for the third time in this chamber, we are debating the Australia Card Bill. It is the greatest misnomer of all time to give the name of our nation to something that so intrudes on Australians' privacy and creates so much inconvenience. The Opposition again opposes this legislation. We will repeal this legislation and its provisions when we are returned to government. I am sure the anger of the Australian people has made this even more imminent. In fact, I give notice of an amendment that we will move during the committee stage of this Bill which makes this legislation unable to be proclaimed until such time as the Australian people have had the opportunity to vote at referendum and cast a deliberate vote on this threshold issue relative to the standards of living in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some interesting aspects of this particular proposal. First of all, again we find ourselves on a non-broadcast day debating this issue in the House of Representatives. We have a government that keeps telling us that the issue has been properly debated. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) went to some lengths yesterday to tell us that. But the Government ensures that the legislation in the House of Representatives-I underline the word `Representatives'-is debated on a non-broadcast day, the day immediately after the Budget, which is a very significant factor in parliamentary life. The Government has done everything possible to ensure that the public again does not get the issue on this particular matter. The Minister should not laugh. We will deal with his second reading speech and we will ensure that the people of Australia know just how much that has misled them and, in fact, the extent to which it even contradicts itself. I think that is of great interest to Australians. We also hope that on this occasion the Australian media and the print media in particular will address themselves to the issues.

The Government claims that it has a mandate for this legislation from the double dissolution election. It should have been looking at the constitutional debates to see what our forefathers laid down when they set the rules for a double dissolution. Honourable members might recall that there is a requirement that there be three months between the first and second introduction of this legislation. The reason that our fore-fathers set down that requirement was simply that there should be a community debate in that period. There was no community debate because the Australian media completely ignored the concerns of the Opposition properly expressed in this Parliament. In the typical fashion of today's journalism, members of the media completely ignored the issue and commented only on whether things were right or wrong. They failed to inform their readers-the people who keep them in a job by paying for their newspapers-on the issues.

That attitude is best exampled by the fact that, during the second debate on the issue in Parliament, as shadow Minister for Science and Small Business, I wrote to the Australian Financial Review, the Bulletin, the Business Review Weekly, the Business Weekly and all those other business papers pointing out their responsibility to their readers, the people who pay money for information that they think they get from these publications. The papers should tell the people what is in the card for the business community, about the draconian fines for failing to be a proper enforcer of the Government's legislation, and about the huge compliance costs of which the Government still refuses to tell us. Its Business Regulation Review Unit has told it, but the Government refuses to tell us and quite clearly the figures that have been provided are an embarrassment.

The media are much to blame. The Minister said in his second reading speech that the Government put an advertisement in the papers. The opening statement of that advertisement was that honest and decent Australians have nothing to fear. Not much! They have to fear total intrusion into their privacy, great inconvience and fines of $20,000 if they fail to act as the Government requires in reporting on clients, business associates and even family in some regard.

Let us look quickly at the Minister's second reading speech. In it, he tells us-this is an excuse for some more-that we already have to fill in one form a month. Already we have intrusions on our privacy, and his solution is to give us more through the Australia Card. He goes on to give us considerable misinformation. He tells us that the Australia Card is going to catch up with pinstripe criminals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear the honourable member say that. Which of the pinstripe criminals has ever bothered to use a false identity to avoid the tax system? They use expensive lawyers and accountants, not false names. Company directors are already subject to massive fines were they to divert some of their company funds to false bank accounts. That interjection is evidence of the honourable gentleman's naivety. He has no understanding of such activity. I have brought evidence to Parliament of how a member of the Australian Labor Party got around paying $1m probate. Was that done through lack of identity? Did he call himself Smith? No; he is a member of a wealthy family and he was able to employ the lawyers to defeat the tax man. The Labor Party puts out to poorer constituents this message about preventing pinstripe crime and tax avoidance, but such criminals do not cheat on their identity and the honourable gentleman should know that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the Australia Card will recover $1,000m, but the presumption is that having a plastic identity will make everyone honest. What a foolish idea. The Minister presumes that if there are a large number of bank accounts in false names, those people sufficiently sophisticated to do that will leave the money there so that they can get caught. Where are the Minister's brains? On page 5 of his speech, we are told that a select committee looked into all this, but of course it did not. It did not look at the legislation, which was not available. It is the legislation that we are debating now, and the draconian penalties on honest and decent Australians for failing to honour the call to be conscripted as the enforcers of this legislation.

Page 6 tells us of the community debate, to which I have already referred. Ordinary Australians were not told of the issues or the effect on them. They were not told of the inconvenience of lining up to alter 64 million bank accounts, of 16 million people lining up to have their photographs taken and to be properly numbered. The Government says it will be all so easy. Of course it will not.

There is a contradiction on page 9 of the Minister's second reading speech. He tells us that the card will be necessary to secure employment. People see that as some protection against dole cheating. Then on page 13 the Minister says that those horrible immigrants who come here and get jobs when Australians apparently are not sufficiently energetic to get them will be stopped by the card because they will not be able to get a job without a card. But then on page 25-and I add that this is also recorded in the explanations put out by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on page 25 under clause 49-the Minister goes on to say:
The Bill does not place any legal obligation on a person to produce a card in relation to employment.

The poor old employer has to pay a $20,000 fine if he fails to ask for the card but, of course, the Government, with its conscience pricking it a little bit, is not prepared to commit itself to saying, `You cannot get a job without a card', so it says, `You can have a job if you do not produce a card'.

The myth has been created that this card will stop social security fraud, but by the Minister's own statements and his massive contradictions on three separate pages of his second reading speech, when we get to the nitty-gritty we find the following circumstance. In the seasonal industries such as fruit picking, prawning, and a bit of shed-handing-which are generally well paid for the short term-the individual turns up and says to the prospective employer, `Here I am. I am looking for work'. The prospective employer says, `Where is your ID card?'. That is his statutory obligation. The employee, whether he is an illegal immigrant or someone on a government benefit, says, `I do not have one and my name is Bill Smith'. The employer is desperate for labour, because such employers are not flooded with prospective employees, irrespective of the levels of unemployment in Australia, so he says, `Right, you have a job'. The employee then works in that job. The Minister tells us, although the legislation certainly does not-but apparently through other legislation to be amended it can occur-that if that employee makes that statement he is obliged to pay tax at 49c in the dollar.

What is so bad about that? In seasonal industries where many hundreds of dollars can be earned in a week, employees would be pushing the 49c level anyway. But let us look at the wonderful compensation of being able to keep an unemployment or other social security benefit during the period that person is working and, of course, during the immediate period afterwards when the person otherwise would have to wait to get back that benefit. How does the person keep those benefits? He does so with a plastic card and his real name. That is what the Government has told us will happen and it is what will happen. The Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan)-I am not sure whether she is a maxi-Minister or mini-Minister-said on television that this problem will be easily solved. She said that the tax man will know this has happened when documentation comes in without a number. That again shows the naivety of those in the Government. The tax man does not get any documentation in terms of short term employment until the employee has left or in terms of longer employment until some time after 30 June. If a person is in the business of cheating, he will know that. He will have moved on.

There is total contradiction in the message from the Minister who said to us that privacy is a bourgeois right, one that is closely associated with the right to private property. We can only assume that this man who makes all these promises and gives all these assurances does not really care very much for our privacy and does not agree that we have a right to private property.

On page 12 of the second reading speech the Minister says that the card need be produced only once, that a person can go to a stockbroker and so open an account. I know that not everybody does that but ever increasing numbers of Australians do so. If the trend overseas is followed here with privatisation and a few other things, that number could get as high as 20 per cent of Australians. Let me tell honourable members about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Imputation.

—Yes, imputation-a great encouragement for more people to do it. The Minister told us that a person can open an account with a stockbroker with one visit. If he wishes to deal with 20 stockbrokers he will require 20 visits. The Minister has never bothered to tell us about clause 173 of the legislation which reflects the fact that the Government's conscience is pricking it again. Clause 173 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who retains a record of information under sub-section (1) shall destroy that record when it is no longer reasonably necessary for the record to be retained.

What will `reasonable' mean to a stockbroker? Some people may buy shares for investment purposes and not go back for six or 12 months. If he retains the information for too long he will be liable for up to two years in gaol. He will be pretty careful about it. When will the details be cancelled? I would say that most of the accounts of casual traders-ordinary, little Australians, not the big share dealers-will be closed before they choose to use them again, as they will in many other transactions that require validation by the card. When that happens they will be obliged to go back again. The Minister told us on page 16 of the second reading speech that there will be no amalgamation of information into a central computer. However, on page 12 of his speech he said:
. . . by linking all sources of a person's income to that number-
he means the ID number-
. . . the correct amount of tax is paid.

In other words, all sources of income will be linked. There will not be a central computer; everyone will have a single number which he or she can use. The Minister has contradicted himself again. Page 15 of the second reading speech tells us that we have a problem with a multiplicity of numbers: we have a Medicare number, a tax file number, credit card numbers and a drivers licence number. The Minister overlooks the fact that that is the protection we have today. If a criminal or some person who wants information about someone gets one of those numbers he can possibly discover information in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can buy it.

—The honourable member for Canning is quite right. I am glad that he said that: people can buy it. The honourable member suggests that everybody will become honest when he or she gets a plastic identity from the Government. Of course people will buy it. However, the Government is giving people the opportunity of having to discover only one number to access information held by the Australian Tax Office, the Department of Social Security, the Depart- ment of Community Services and Health, a person's employer, his stock and station agent, his stockbroker, his bank and his lawyer. What is more, the Government is obliging all those people to have the number on record. The number will be written on scraps of paper around the place and the office girl will know it. Access to the number will be so simple. Yet the Government tells us that we will be better off with one number than all the numbers we have at present. On page 16 the Minister also bothered to inform us:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a vast amount of personal information is already held by government.

I presume that this is some excuse for getting it all under one number. The Minister went to great pains, on a number of pages, to assure Australian citizens that they do not have to worry about hackers. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in America which, I would imagine, is an admitted expert in the area of technology, particularly communications technology, has been reported by the Guardian in London-this appears in today's Press-as having had its computer networks accessed by West German hackers. This Government will not be able to reach the level of technology that NASA would have. The Minister assured us that the card will show only a person's name, photograph, signature, expiry date and number. He failed to remind us that the less information on the card the easier it will be to forge.

The private sector is to have no access to the Register. Under the Government's legislation it is forbidden to check on the photo or the signature on the card. What do I have to discover about a person to forge a card in that person's name? I have to find the name of that person, and I have to find the expiry date and the number of that card. I do not need that person's photograph because I will put my photograph on the card. I do not need that person's signature because I will put a rendition of my signature on it. If I am a criminal with that intent I have now got a piece of plastic which establishes my identity as that of somebody else. Determined cheats will do just that. They will not be so silly as to manufacture Australia Card numbers; they will get proper numbers.

Honourable members opposite in their speeches to follow might tell me what happens when such a card is forged and it is used to cash dud cheques and to get goods on credit-goods for which the criminal has no intention of paying. They might tell me who will be the first person to be interviewed by the State police-police outside the control of honourable members opposite-when they start their inquiries. The police will go to the proper card holder. The police will have little difficulty in finding such a person because that person will be on the government record. Of course, that person might just happen to be like that poor girl who was the subject of a leak from the Health Insurance Commission-which is to become the authority under this legislation-and be interviewed in the work place. That person might be taken away from his work place to be interviewed at the police station. That person could come back and say to his colleagues, `It wasn't me', if lucky enough to be able to prove it.

What happens when a determined criminal opens a bank account in another person's name? The bank cannot go to the internal Australia Card Register to check on the validity of that person's signature or photograph. How does a person explain that to the Commissioner of Taxation when that determined criminal has withdrawn the money and gone off with it and there is an inquiry six months later into why he did not declare the interest and where he got the original sum of money from? The less information put on the card the simpler it is to forge. Of course, with a person's conscience pricking him in regard to this the easier it will be for criminals to forge the card.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not mention the digitised photograph.

—I did mention it, you foolish man. A person can get that if he is part of the social security system, the Health Insurance Commission or, in fact, the Tax Office. It would be a great help if honourable members opposite would acquaint themselves with the provisions of this legislation. For example, a bank, an employer, anyone in the private sector, can take the card only on its face value because they have no access to the card Register. The Government has put that in the legislation. Even if information can be got from the magnetic strip on the card, are honourable members opposite suggesting that 650,000 small businesses will have to buy the necessary equipment to go down that track and be able to read the information on the magnetic strip? Great help that will be when in Western Australia the other day forgers were able to access such information, rewrite it on the back of a forged card and withdraw other people's money from automatic tellers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has already told us on page 20 of the Minister's second reading speech that it already has the information and that there will be no unauthorised use of it. However, when a government department leaked information on doctors' salaries a Federal Police inquiry established that more people knew the information than had access to it and the police could not catch the people who leaked the information. Of course, we now have the assurances of the Minister for Community Services and Health, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) that it will all be okay because we will link all the computers by means of dedicated landlines. There are dedicated landlines in the television studios here in Parliament House, similar to those which apparently the Government proposes to use. Yet the television studios keep getting each other's programs. The studios do not have to ask for them; they get them voluntarily. That is what the Government is going to use to link the system.

If honourable members opposite want some evidence of how poorly that issue has been researched, let me tell them. Yesterday in this place I asked the mini-Minister for Communications, that is, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), a question about it, and in the other place the maxi-Minister for Communications, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), was asked about these wonderful new-style landlines that are supposed to be totally secure. Both Ministers declined to answer the question.

One would have thought that a government that wanted to go out and assure people on this issue would go to the experts in its own Cabinet to find out whether they were telling the truth. Quite clearly the experts in the Government's own Cabinet are not too keen to answer questions on this issue and, when they do come up with answers, they will be misleading the Parliament if they assure us of the system's security. Even if the Government were to start digging the trenches now all around Australia and laying wire in them and even if it were to put thousands of guards on those wires, it still could not guarantee the security of the information carried. It is absolute stupidity for the Government to suggest that it could, and it is wrong to mislead Australians in this fashion.

The Government says we will have a powerful watchdog, the Data Protection Agency. It has no powers; it can only recommend. What is more, it is modelled on the Swedish system. Jan Freese, the long-standing director of the Swedish organisation, has just resigned in disgust, complaining that the postal authorities in that country now sell information. When a system has been operating since 1947 one starts to realise the value of one's assets. A Treasurer like the one we have might say, `This is worth money; we have a wonderful data base here and we should be privatising it'. The Swedes have done that. They now sell direct mailing organisations lists of names and addresses including changes of address. Furthermore, Swedish organisations now go to data banks to conduct their surveys. The bureaucracy has found it is easier to get the answers from there. As an official said the other day, if the bureaucracy asked the people all these questions they would refuse to answer. Yet the Government suggests to us that it has it all together, that it can guarantee Australians' security.

Of course, the Government says that one will not be required to produce the card for all sorts of things. Yesterday my office got a form from an operating video rental firm in Western Australia, and the form has a space clearly marked for a national ID number. Already the private sector is getting ready.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be fine.

—I bet they will be fine, because the shop will not demand it; it just will not give people a video until they write their number down. And other people will not cash a cheque until one puts one's number on it. People should remember that when they do that they are giving another individual the opportunity to forge their card. I have here the form; I have just taken the name of the firm off it. The original is in my office in Perth. It has a space for date of birth, national ID card number and occupation. `ID' is written again; I do not know what that means. There is a space for business and home phone numbers, et cetera. It is an application for membership. The private sector is into it already. So much for the Minister's assurances.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposes this card on six basic grounds. It threatens a massive intrusion into personal privacy, and no guarantees have been given that people cannot get into the system. We are creating a key, by way of a common number, for all those who want the personal and financial information of Australians. A person is obliged to give an employer the same number that accesses his medical records, and employers today are very interested in that as a result of workers compensation problems. The card will create massive personal inconvenience. People will be queuing all over the place, running back and forth. Sporting clubs will have to have a personal card representative. The Australia Card will be hugely costly. The Minister for Community Services and Health once told us we could have free medicine and free medical treatment for $1,000m; it now costs us over $4,000m. Of course we must multiply that by three in the private sector to get the final figure.

No one has yet told us of the cost of the extra police, the extra courts and the extra gaols we will need when the Government applies all these penalties and starts throwing people in gaol, as it says it will if people break the requirements; and we must remember that a lot of the requirements are purely to enforce the Government's legislation. One can be fined massively, and not necessarily because one has done anything wrong. The system will conscript ordinary citizens and business entities, under threat of huge penalties, to report on their employees, clients and even neighbours. There are grave questions as to the ability of criminals to use the system, and in some cases lay the blame upon innocent Australians through the process of assuming their card identity. It simply will not work in its stated aim of stopping, or for that matter substantially reducing, tax and welfare cheating.

It is ridiculous that last night the Treasurer was boasting of how effective have been the measures the Government has taken to date, and clearly they are in a much broader sense. He is now going to put permanent audit groups into very large companies. Numerous measures will address the problem of where the revenue is being defrauded. There are simple mechanisms such as requiring people on the dole to work for it. They cannot forge themselves and they come from a community in which they will not get too many volunteers to stand in for them. It is a simple answer to the problem. There are answers to deal with those who cheat in our community without numbering 16 million Australians, putting them to huge inconvenience and putting the last vestiges of their privacy at risk to catch a few. The Government will not make the system work. It may succeed in bludgeoning the legislation through this Parliament; it will be its job to answer to the community at the next election as people are queueing up for the cards and with all the other problems associated with it. We promise the people that we will give them back their privacy and we will in the appropriate way catch cheats, to the extent that they exist in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time to put the record straight regarding Opposition allegations repeated ad nauseam about the involvement of the Department of Social Security with the Australia Card. Opposition members continue to repeat their misinformed allegations. I say categorically there is absolutely no foundation for comments such as that Social Security will not use the card, that Social Security will not rely on it, that the Department is sceptical about the proposal or that officers have publicly rejected it. The Australia Card will first and foremost enhance the integrity of the social security system so that welfare assistance goes only to those who are genuinely entitled to it. The introduction of the card will enable the Department to re-establish the identity of all current Social Security clients. When introduced, the card will provide for each person receiving welfare assistance to advise the Department of his or her card number. All Social Security clients will thus validate their identity with the Department. This will represent a major clamp down on false identities within the welfare system. The Australia Card will provide continuing evidence that the people we deal with are who they claim to be.

SPEECH.PARA: How will the Department use it? It will be used as an ongoing proof of identity in the following circumstances: at the time persons claim pension or benefit; when clients attend the counter with queries about payments; when clients are personally lodging unemployment benefit or sole parent forms; when dealing with requests to replace lost concession cards-for example, transport or medical cards-for all Social Security field officer interviews at the client's home; and for all Department of Social Security office interviews. Identity information is quite fundamental to the drive against fraud that we have been conducting within the Department of Social Security. It is a vital element in detecting schemes and organised attempts to defraud the Commonwealth. There is no doubt, in my view, that the Australia Card will help to eliminate the very big social security frauds. The Department has used analysis of client profiles surrounding identities to uncover large scale frauds.

For example, in the Jansenberger case the amount involved was $379,000 and the full extent of the scheme was detected through detailed computer analysis of identity information held by the Department. The offender was gaoled for eight years. In the McKenzie case the amount involved was $343,000 and the scheme came to light through the risk based approach used by the Department of Social Security in selecting cases for review. The offender was gaoled for 6 1/2 years. In the Stutz case the amount involved was $168,000, and again the scheme came to light through selecting clients for review. The offender was gaoled for 5 1/2 years.

The Australia Card will mesh with current systems to detect false identities and fraud. New systems to enhance proof of identity include proof of identity procedures and employment separation certificates, which were introduced from 1 September. The detection of false identities has increased. Since July 1985 the Department of Social Security has detected 50 fraudulent schemes involving $2.7m in which false identity was the key element. In the two years to 30 June 1987 there was a 76 per cent increase in the number of prosecutions-under the Crimes Act-and a five-fold increase in the amounts of money involved. The Australia Card will be the Department's principal means of identifying clients. The universal numbering system will help to support present detection systems, and future detection systems such as external agencies which use the Australia Card number.

The Australia Card will significantly help the fight against fraud by facilitating the matching of Social Security records with other agencies, as determined by the Act. The first advantage is clearly the faster identification of persons registered under different agencies. The card will help to detect fraudulent payments much more quickly than at present. Secondly, increased undisclosed income will be detected through the matching of Social Security records with taxation records held by employers and finance institutions. The Australia Card will form part of payroll records for taxation purposes. Thirdly, there will be greater protection against forgeries. Currently, in order to establish proof of identity the Department of Social Security requires at least three documents, including a `sound' document, such as a passport, a refugee document, an original Australian birth certificate or an extract issued at least five years previously, a marriage certificate where the identity of the marriage partner has been established, an official legal document, citizenship papers or apprenticeship papers. It is a very tough system, but not immune to abuse by hardened criminals. For example, charges were laid in Sydney on 30 July 1987 against a person with an elaborate scheme to defraud Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission.

In regard to the forgeries, there were a number of examples of forged birth certificates of very high quality, printed on paper with watermarks similar to that of the New South Wales Registrar-General. Forgeries were produced by photocopying a real certificate on to a plastic sleeve. The details on the original are then erased and the remaining details on the plastic sleeve are photocopied on to blank paper. The false details are then typed in. Fifty false certificates were found. In terms of leakage of information, claims that the Australia Card will provide risks of security of information are misguided. Leakage of information is more likely to occur from paper records or, in terms of the Department of Social Security, from microfiche records, than from records held within the Stratplan system. Any unauthorised access would incur a fine of $5,000 or imprisonment for up to two years, in terms of current rules in the Department of Social Security.

This Government is serious about attacking tax fraud and social security fraud. The Opposition has no policy or record on how to deal with fraud. It is embarrassed; it has been caught out by the debate on the Australia Card. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), for example, was a very strong advocate of bipartisan support for the introduction of the Australia Card. On 8 June 1985 he said:
The introduction of a national ID system, using ID cards, offered benefits to Australian people.
Another majority benefit would be a reduction of fraud affecting Government outlays, especially social welfare payments.

The Opposition is currently trading on misrepresentation to avoid the main issue. The main issue is that the Government is serious about the fight against fraud and the Opposition is opposing us on every front. It is just trying to score cheap political points. To date, the Government, through the Department of Social Security, has installed Stratplan. It has introduced direct deposits, which deals significantly with problems associated with cheques and misrepresentation in terms of cheques. It has developed an overpayments strategy, including the initial amnesty. It has introduced compulsory lodgment of 19b forms-that is, forms requiring regular income statements for unemployment benefit clients. It has introduced much stricter arrangements for clients of the Department of Social Security. We aim to make sure that the resources that are there are not eroded by fraud.

To understand the great value of these Government initiatives they need to be compared with the system which was left to us by the previous Government. The White Paper on tax made this very clear. The effects of avoidance and evasion had virtually destroyed the taxation system in this country. People earning between $50,000 and $100,000 managed to hide about 10 per cent of their income through evasion and avoidance. Those earning $100,000 and above were allowed to keep 22 per cent of their income from being brought into account. This was done by receiving fringe benefits instead of cash, disguising income as a capital gain, and tax exploitation measures. On average, someone on $100,000 was able to rip off the tax system to the tune of $12,900. This is equivalent to almost three age pensions at the married rate.

I think it is extremely important in this debate for us to understand what the real issue is all about. Fundamentally, it is a question of whether we want a fair and equitable society; whether we want to see a society in which social security payments are paid to those who are entitled to those payments and to those who are in real need and whether we want to ensure that people, often with considerable wealth and high incomes, pay their fair share of taxation. It is about integrity in relation to the taxation system and it is about fairness in terms of overall government operations.

We inherited from the previous Government a system which was extraordinarily unfair. Indeed, we inherited a situation where, in a real sense, public morality in society had reached its lowest ebb probably in the post-war period. During the Fraser years the state was fair game. If one could get into the state and avoid one's taxation obligations, thereby foisting those obligations on to someone else, that was encouraged. In my view that created a situation in which the legitimacy of government was effectively being called into question. More and more of the share of taxation was being paid by those in the pay as you earn tax system who could not avoid tax. People on low and middle incomes paid more and more taxation because the tax cheats and the tax avoidance industry had become the fastest growing industry in Australian society.

Similarly, in terms of the income security system, it is not untrue to suggest that most, if not all, of the principal controls relating to the social security system were erased in the last desperate years of the Fraser-Howard Government. The explosion that occurred in relation to beneficiary numbers made it almost impossible for the Department of Social Security to guarantee getting cheques out, let alone make appropriate checks in terms of who was paid, what they were paid and their proper entitlements. The legitimacy of government was being ravaged by people with no interest at all in achieving a fair and equitable society.

One ought not be misled for a moment by what the Opposition is about in this debate. While members of the Opposition cloak their concerns in mealy-mouthed mutterings about issues of privacy and civil liberties, the civil liberties of hundreds of thousands of Australians, in terms of their right to a proper share in the nation's income, were being attacked by the previous Government. No government in the history of this Commonwealth has a record of less attention to fairness, equity and integrity in terms of government systems than the previous Government. As was revealed in a number of reports in relation to the taxation system, it was clear that the Government was simply failing to give the attention that was necessary to ensuring that that system was based on fundamental integrity. So let us not put up too much with the kind of nonsense that we are receiving in this debate from members of the Opposition. We know that the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the previous spokesman on social security had some sympathy for the concept of the Australia Card and had some commitment to it but now, for opportunistic political reasons, the name of the game has shifted. Any concern that might be picked up, no matter how unfounded, is being seized upon by the Opposition as an attempt to somehow destroy the Government's attempts to achieve greater fairness and integrity with major revenue and expenditure systems, and that is what we have been about in a number of measures.

We have been able to achieve what I think people would regard as the most successful Budget in recent years in meeting objectives shared by the Australian people and delivering very substantial support to the lowest income families because we have taken a number of steps. At times these steps have been heavily criticised by the Opposition. I refer to fringe benefits taxes, entertainment taxes and capital gains taxes. Some people have not been paying their fair share of taxation, they have been avoiding it on a massive scale. The net result on the other side of the equation is that we have been able to deliver a package which is historically one of the most significant reforms in assisting low income families that we have ever seen in this country. Fairness in relation to taxation delivered in terms of social security is being paid to people in genuine and real need. Similarly, efforts have been made by this Government, not by the previous Government, where all the systems and all the controls disappeared, to pursue systematically those who are fraudulently manipulating the social security system to ensure that those people who have been receiving money to which they are not entitled pay it back or that preventative measures are put in place so that that cannot occur.

The Australia Card is a very significant preventative measure both on the revenue side and the expenditure side. I find it very hard to understand how people on the other side of the House could come back at this point, having failed to raise their head in the course of an election which was called on the basis of the Australia Card. The Leader of the Opposition is so gutless in terms of his public stance that he is not able to raise the issue for public debate. He did not raise the issue throughout the election campaign. No one else in his shadow Ministry has been able to raise it either. The reason members of the Opposition did not raise that issue is unknown to me, but I suspect it is because fundamentally, when it gets down to the arguments, they would have had to deal ultimately with their own record on the growth of taxation avoidance and their own inability to establish systems that had integrity in relation to the social security system.

In terms of the debate that is taking place within the Parliament, there is no question of where the logic lies and no question of where the fairness lies. I come back again and again to the term `fairness' because that is not within the lexicon of members of the Opposition. Whatever they say, it is never about fairness, social justice or achieving a society in which people on lower incomes receive a better deal and people on the very highest incomes and with the greatest wealth pay their fair share of taxation. Where are the Opposition's proposals to ensure that there is greater fairness in relation to the taxation system? All we have had from the Opposition spokesman on the Australia Card, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), was this furphy about work for the dole. That is the Opposition's contribution to public policy and debate on social security. Members of the Opposition could not get their schemes right because they had never thought them through. They have never shown the capacity--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Prime Minister about that.

—The former shadow Treasurer is interjecting. What right has he to say very much to this House about the integrity of the taxation system when he could not count his own numbers. He turned out to be hundreds of millions of dollars out with the package that he dreamed up. That suggests what the Opposition is about. It is about faking something for the most opportunistic reasons and not thinking it through in terms of any objective of fairness and equity. This is an important issue. The Australian people are right to be concerned about it because ultimately if the Government loses this debate the people who will suffer to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars will be the people paying taxes, the pay as you earn taxpayers on the one hand and people in the social security system on the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1868 the last people to come to Australia bearing a compulsory number arrived in Western Australia in wooden ships. In 1988 the gift of the Bicentenary from this Government will be a system whereby all Australians are numbered, but there is a difference between those people who came to Australia in 1868 and those in Australia in 1988. In 1868 those people were guilty; in 1988 we have a government that is putting in a system which says that all Australians are guilty until they are proved innocent. I feel that that is one of the most objectionable parts of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that we have a mere four-hour debate on the Australia Card after it has been stopped on earlier occasions when the Australia Card Bill came into the House. We have a situation now where the majority of Australians are against this proposal and the Government will not take any notice. It is true that when the idea of an identification card was first mooted we did have a support rate in the community of about 78 per cent; it is true that earlier this year when the market research was taken there was a support rate of 55 per cent; and it is true that that support by the general public of Australia has now dropped to 39 per cent. As people find out more about the way this ID card will intrude into the lives of ordinary Australians, so that great tide of objection is rolling towards Canberra, and we have this Government forcing through this legislation. We have a lot of questions to ask the Government. I have a list of them here. I hope the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) will respond to them because there is very deep concern not only about what information will be collected but also about the security that is to be provided under the system that we have.

I think one of the most incredible things that I have seen in this House in recent years was at Question Time yesterday when the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who represents the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), was asked a question about the dedicated landlines and could not answer it. What was even more amazing was in the other place when the Minister himself could not answer the question about landlines. The one thing that the Government did when the whole question of the database security came to the fore was panic. It said it was going to have dedicated landlines. Dedicated landlines, by their nature, are territorial. Does the Government expect us to believe that it is physically going to lay these dedicated landlines to every computer terminal used by the Government throughout Australia? If so, is there any provision in this Bill for the additional cost that would be required? The additional cost would be $8 billion to $10 billion. The Government will have a construction program to put in those dedicated landlines that will be a bigger construction program than the building of the pyramids in Egypt. This is the kind of tripe that we are getting from the Government in terms of the security of this legislation.

Are we going to believe that we will have absolute security of the information that will be stored by the Government? Are we really going to believe that the Australian system will be more secure than that of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which we have learnt has already been tampered with by hackers in West Germany? Are we going to believe that it will be more secure than that of the Pentagon, which says that it cannot guarantee the security of its information? Can we have a guarantee from the Government that the security of this information will be as good as the security of the personal identification number system used by banks for their money machines? If the answer is that it will be as secure, then we have seen what happened in Western Australia when people got into those machines and took out money at will. The whole question of security is a most important one and I believe that the people of Australia have every right to be concerned about the information that will be held on those computer services.

Why does Australia need an ID card? One of the biggest reasons why we do not need a card has been put forward by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who has told us what a tremendous job his Department is doing in catching the welfare cheats, the dole fraud people and the rest. Last night, we heard a tremendous story on how much extra taxation revenue had been acquired by the new system which is operating in the Australian Taxation Office. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Social Security on the work that they have done, and on showing the lie of the ID exercise, because they already have the facilities to go after the extra revenue and the social security defrauders. We do not need the Australia Card.

We are told that the Australia Card system will be based on the one in Sweden. I will deal with Sweden in a minute, but let us look at some of the systems operated by other major nations-for example, West Germany, which has experienced continued security problems. In recent years it has gone through periods of assaults by terrorist groups, but even given those problems, great controversy surrounds privacy there. In recent weeks a new automated identity card has been produced, and West Germans will have to carry that card at all times. Authorities will store data on people's movements, and law and order agencies will have access to this. According to Press reports in the Australian newspaper of 4 March data protection officers in Bonn and in regional governments have already warned that the cards of West Germany will usher in a police state.

Hong Kong has an immense problem of illegal immigration, and the Government submission concedes that this is so. Wide powers exist in relation to immigration control, which allow the police randomly to request the production of an ID card. France has a system of identification, but it is voluntary and people have a separate social insurance number. The schemes are not universal, and cannot be compared with what is to be installed in Australia. Israel, for obvious security reasons, has an ID card as well. In Canada, people have a social insurance number, which has become a de facto identity number. It was originally introduced for unemployment insurance purposes. Solemn undertakings were given that its use would be strictly confined to this purpose. However, the 1981 Report on the Use of Social Insurance Number presented to the Canadian Parliament says:

There was widespread concern expressed about the fact that, while the Social Insurance Number, and its associated card, had been introduced solely for social security purposes, and assurances had been given that the card would not be used for any other purposes; the card is, in fact, now used for many other purposes. These include credit applications, employment applications, employee identification, health surveys, insurance, banking, library registration, car and accommodation rental, and even for the registration of children as junior sports participants.

We have been told that we do not have to worry about the identity card in Australia because they have one in the United States of America. However, that is a social security number only, and the United States of America admits that it has failed to control illegal migration and in its reports there have been a great number of objections to the infringement of civil liberties that that social security number has brought about.

My colleague the shadow Minister, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), mentioned earlier that the head of the data protection agency in Sweden had recently resigned because he could not control the system. Last Friday night I spent about three-quarters of an hour on the telephone with Jan Freese talking about the difficulties that are faced in Sweden. The plain facts are that Sweden introduced an identity card 20 years ago, but that system has become an absolute nightmare. Despite that, the Government tells us that our card will be based on that Swedish system. Jan Freese, the former head of the Swedish data protection agency, claimed that Swedish citizens had been stripped of their souls. This might seem emotive, but let me read a quotation from the Expressen, one of the Stockholm newspapers, which states:

The Data Inspection Board, acting unanimously, found in its demand for grants last year and in its annual report this year that privacy protection had continued to become still more limited. The Swedish people were no longer standing naked in front of the authorities and exposed to curious foreign observers. The Swedes had been more or less stripped to their souls. Swedish companies and organisations as well as authorities also have been pressured to become a form of extraordinary nudists-exposing both body and soul . . . It may be looked upon as timidity for me to leave after a dozen years as head of the Data Inspection Board. I knew what I was doing when I reached my decision. To jump off the merry-go-round when you can no longer control the speed may also be looked upon as responsibility not to take the further responsibility.

That is a most significant statement. While we might say now that we shall have only limited information on the Australian system, the plain facts are that as the system is accepted, more and more organisations and people will require further information and data. We see in the legislation itself clauses that will, virtually at the stroke of a pen, allow perhaps not this Government but a future government to set up any sort of information to do any sort of social engineering that it may require through the identity card system.

Look at what has happened in Sweden. Twenty years ago, the Swedes were convinced that this was the way to proceed. Now, the ID number is required for any reason, from joining a union to borrowing a library book. The interesting thing is that it has not retarded the underground economy, which is flourishing in Sweden. According to recent figures, the Swedish Government loses 20 per cent of current revenue through tax evasion. The Swedes choose to evade tax and the ID card by desisting from extra work. They go into the cash economy and have even got to the stage where one of the major industries in Sweden is the barter economy, which beats the system. One can go to the dentist and get one's fillings done and in return, if one is a plumber, fix his drain pipes or if one deals in that commodity, give him a load of bricks. The barter system is rife. I am not saying that that will necessarily come into Australia, but that is the prospect if people are going to avoid taxation. It is just not on. Criminals in our society will find ways and means around this system as they have done around overseas systems.

Let us get back to some of the questions that I would like to ask about the security of the ID card proposal. Can the Minister tell us whether the births, death and marriages register that will be established under the ID card will share the same computer as the central register operated by the Health Insurance Commission? Is it a fact that the births, deaths and marriages register will not be covered by the jurisdiction of the proposed Data Protection Agency, and if so what guarantees can the Government give that confidential information stored in that register will be protected from unauthorised access?

What notice has the Minister taken of some of the Government's reports? I suggest that he look at that excellent report Towards a Cashless Society, which goes into the whole system of credit cards. One of its recommendations was that the Government tread carefully in getting together data banks because of the tremendous threats that they pose to the civil liberties of all Australians. Is it a fact that the Australian Bankers Association has already said that the Australia Card legislation will be unworkable? What will really be the cost to banks, building societies and other financial institutions? We know what will happen about that. Those extra charges that banks incur will be passed on to the general population.

We are now debating, for technical reasons, the original legislation. We ask the Government: what changes will be made further down the track? What really are we letting ourselves in for if we pass this legislation now? We ask the Minister: will he at last tell us what standard of communications protocol will be used for the transmission of ID card data among various government departments? What method of data scrambling will be used? We do not know that. Is it true that the Government originally envisaged using Aussat or the existing Telecom Australia network to transmit ID information? What were the real reasons that that decision was put aside? What guarantee do we have that the standard of security of information stored in the ID card databases will be at least equal to that of banking machines at the moment? Can the Minister tell us whether it will be equal to that or what ways it will be better? We ask him to really spell it out.

Getting into the more human aspects, we ask the Minister: is it true that in the event of the death of an elderly person who has neglected to register savings with the ID card authority, all savings, deposits and valuables will be passed on to the Government, not to relatives? If that is true, can he tell us how much the Government expects to get in additional revenue from that proceeding? Will we now see another $2m wasted on a Government promotion campaign to try to get all Australians to accept this legislation? Those questions have never been asked.

Can the Government also tell us just how stiff the penalties will be? Does it intend to take them all the way? If a person fails to report within 21 days the loss of an ID card, does that automatically mean that the person will be fined $500? According to the legislation, it certainly looks that way. If an employer fails to see an employee's ID card number, record it and report it to the Government, will the employer be fined up to $20,000? We heard the example given yesterday of the baby-sitter. When the 17-year-old lass or 12-year-old boy does a bit of baby-sitting, will we have to say, `Give us your ID card number.'? Will we have to fill in all details and send them to Canberra?

Is it a fact that if an employer hires a cardless person, he or she will be fined $20,000? Is it true that if bankers, stockbrokers, accountants, lawyers and real estate agents fail to see and record someone's ID number when the person enters into a financial transaction, they will be fined $20,000? If a person's ID card is destroyed or defaced and he cannot prove that it was done accidentally, will he be imprisoned for two years, or fined $5,000, or both? If a person fails to attend a compulsory conference ordered by the ID card agency, will he be fined $1,000 and/or imprisoned for six months? So the list goes on. The penalty provisions in this legislation are really horrendous.

I get back to the original point that we really have to ask the Government: why do we need the card now when the Treasurer told us last night just how well he is doing in getting that extra revenue? Why do we need it when just minutes ago the Minister for Social Security told this House how well he is doing in catching up with fraudulent activities in the social security area? Why is it that every Australian from the moment he or she is born will be issued with a number and that number will be kept until the day that person dies? Is the real reason for having this ID card the fact that it will be able to provide perhaps not this Government but future governments of Australia with the capacity to undertake the greatest social engineering activity that has ever been seen in this country?

We should all be concerned at the extent of the interference into the affairs and activities of everyday Australians. We should be concerned about the facility and capacity of this Government to be able to protect any information that might go into that central databank. I for one am not convinced that we need the card. I am not convinced-and I do not think any member of the Government is-that the Government can provide the total security that would be necessary with the system. I am not convinced that there has been a full cost-benefit analysis on this proposal or that we will get any further taxation revenue out of this system. I am not convinced that we will fix up the criminals in our society through an ID card or that this card will do anything in terms of cracking down even harder on social security cheats. All Australians should ask this question: why do we need this scurrilous legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last few weeks have seen a very successful campaign to scare the living daylights out of the Australian population. To some extent this campaign has been both masterful and, in my view, sickening. Some of the contributions by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the previous speaker, certainly fit into that criterion of trying to scare the daylights out of the population. This campaign has as its central theme the objective of turning a legitimate, harmless and well-intentioned government policy into what is potentially the most divisive issue in contemporary Australian politics.

SPEECH.PARA: I will indicate some of the nonsense that has been coming into my electorate office in recent days. I use the term `nonsense' advisedly because obviously many of the people writing to me, although well-intentioned, certainly have been somewhat misled by the half-truths, deceptions and downright lies that have been told in this debate. There have been numerous references or appeals in this letter-writing campaign to biblical emotions. I was told by one person last week, `We have to get back to the Bible and not bring in this abominable card'. Another person said, `God is in control of our country, not man. He just allows us enough rope to hang ourselves if we choose to do so'. Someone else was kind enough to say, `I will be praying to God-maybe you have heard of him-to stop it getting through Parliament'.

There have also been some incredible sexist appeals based on the fact that the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) has carriage of this legislation. As we would expect in a campaign like this, and with some of the rednecks in the community, there has been an appeal to racist attitudes: `Why won't Aboriginals be required to carry an ID card-aren't they Australians too?- discrimination in reverse'. This is a repetition of, and continual reference to, the lie put forward in this debate-despite the fact that there is a specific provision in the legislation that people will not be required to carry the card-that people will have to carry the card with them at all times.

I have been talking about the Australia Card, I guess, for 2 1/2 years. I raised the issue in a debate within the parliamentary section of the Australian Labor Party in April 1985 in an attempt to have the parliamentary Party look at the feasibility of having a national identification system. The debate has rolled on from that point. I have even debated such people as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I debated him in Bathurst in February this year in front of a couple of hundred people. I have issued countless dozens of Press releases and answered hundreds of letters, as I am sure many of my colleagues have done. In my view, the Government's intentions have not been the sort of well kept secret that is now alleged.

Until six weeks ago all the polls indicated that between 60 per cent and 70 per cent of people support the card. What has happened since that time to drastically change those figures? I happen to believe, as I am sure most people here believe, that the statistically reliable and valid opinion polls that have been conducted are fairly accurate. In my view, the popular support has changed simply because of the emergence of a very odd coalition of opposition to the Australia Card with cult-like figures, such as Peter Garrett, whipping up hysteria about the card with a disgusting collection of distortions and half-truths about the card.

I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has entered the chamber. He has had some rather interesting attitudes. I noticed that the Orange Central Western Daily newspaper of 26 August this year stated:
Two Molong Central School students will lobby against Federal Government plans to introduce the Australia Card.
The article pointed out:
The girls prepared the petition from information supplied by Member for Parkes Mr Michael Cobb on bureaucratic procedures and legislation attached to the card.
According to the newspaper, the girls said, no doubt in good faith:

Most people have no idea of what the card is all about. It is our aim to educate them. We got all the information we could from Michael Cobb so when the petition was presented we wouldn't be shot down in flames by politicians.

That is the same Michael Cobb, the same honourable member for Parkes, who was quoted in an article in the Dubbo Daily Liberal of 7 May 1985 under the headline `Cobb backs plan for identity cards' as saying:

While some groups may reject the proposal, it must be recognised that it has merit. People should remember we already carry a driver's licence and a variety of cards for Medicare, Credit Companies, and the like. Photo identification would be just another card to carry.

The honourable member for Parkes has joined his colleagues in running around the place scaring the living daylights out of people. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has said many times in this House that what we need in Australia to fight effectively all forms of abuse is a proper identification of each Australian with a number, photograph and even a fingerprint. That is what he said on 16 May when he was the shadow spokesman for social security.

I put it to the House that something has happened to make those people change their minds. Also, something has happened to make people change their views in terms of the popular support for the legislation. The reason there has been a change in public attitude as measured by public opinion polls in recent days is that we are seeing a polarisation within the community based on the fact that many people in the Liberal and National parties who were once public advocates of the Australia Card are now saying that they are opposed to it and people who normally support the conservative parties are saying that, if they are opposed to it, perhaps there is something wrong with the legislation and they should fall in line with the people for whom they normally vote. It is significant that many of the Government's traditional supporters, who are incensed by what they see as the obscenity of tax and welfare abuse within the community, are very supportive of what the Government is doing in this regard.

Let us consider some of the comments that have been coming in about what the legislation purports to contain and the steps that have been taken by opponents of the card to whip up paranoia and hysteria. We have been told that the card will be necessary for a whole host of purposes which are absolutely untrue. For example, I have heard stories that the card will be required to be produced when a person applies for a job, when he goes to the beach and every time he uses his bank account. Some people came to my office and said that they had heard about the Government's secret plan. When I questioned them further they said that a person will have to produce his Australia Card every time he deposits funds in or withdraws funds from a bank account. I said, `If that is the case, how will people use automatic teller machines?' and they replied, `Aha, that is the secret plan; the Government is going to outlaw automatic teller machines in the Australian community and use the Australia Card as an excuse to do so'. That is the sort of nonsense talked about in the community at present. We all know that such a campaign of disinformation is often very difficult to turn around. At this stage I congratulate the Opposition on its relative success, but I can assure it that the Government has not changed its resolve on the Australia Card in any way. I believe that, once people have been given an opportunity to hear the real facts and to understand what the Government seeks to do, public opinion will change in time.

One of the more unsavoury elements of the Opposition's scare campaigns has been its campaign to scare the most vulnerable people in the community-the sick and the elderly. People have told me that a person will not be allowed into a hospital if he does not have the card with him. The legislation talks about the card number being produced as soon as practicable after the admission of a person to a hospital as an out-patient. The same thing applies essentially with admission to public hospitals under the current system, without an Australia Card. If someone turns up at a hospital for a normal admission he is usually required to produce his Medicare card number or show evidence of private insurance. Surely no one suggests that at present, if a person has a horrendous car accident, he must undergo a body search to find out whether or not he has a Medicare card on him before anything is done to remedy the situation. Yet when we have the Australia Card, the Opposition suggests that there will be some sort of body search for the Australia Card before any surgical procedures are performed.

The public has been told by our opponents that central dossiers will be kept on them so that the Government will be able to keep watch over them. But only the basic identifying information such as a person's name, address, date of birth, signature, photograph and identifying documents will be recorded on the Australia Card Register. People will have ready access, on an annual basis, or at any other time, to make any alterations or to see who has accessed the Register and why. The data bases of the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the Health Insurance Commission will not be linked. They are barred by Government legislation from such a linkage. The honourable member for O'Connor and others have told us that hackers will move around the system and will destroy its integrity. The opponents of the card have told the people of Australia that they will no longer have any privacy. Yet, if people examined the privacy principles enshrined in the establishment of the Data Protection Agency and the accompanying privacy Bills, I am sure that most of them would dismiss that claim for what it is-one of cheap politics and an appeal to emotional rhetoric.

Another interesting document that came across my desk the other day was a document circulated in the name of the New South Wales State member for Orange, Mr Garry West. It was a memorandum addressed to all members of the National Party of Australia in the Orange and Blayney sub-divisions dated 18 August 1987 and the subject was the Hawke Government's ID card. In that document, which comprised eight pages, Mr West pointed out some of the arguments that the National Party is using among its supporters to try to scare the living daylights out of the Australian population. I find it somewhat intriguing, when I read through some of the National Party's views on the Australia Card, to consider how they square with its views on privacy considerations. For example, under the heading `Under National Policy', I read:
We will set up a centralised register of births, deaths and marriages to greatly assist in reducing the opportunity to create false identities.

If the National Party's policy is to set up a centralised register of births, deaths and marriages, I suggest that, for a start, it talk to the Queensland Premier because I understand that he has some reservations about that. Obviously Joh is doing his own thing in that regard. More importantly, if the National Party has made the effort to suggest, as its policy, that we should set up a register of births, deaths and marriages, it must be for a specific purpose. However, we are not told in the document what the specific purpose is. The same people who are concerned about privacy considerations also indicate in the document that they:

. . . will streamline administrative arrangements, in co-operation with the States, to ensure maximum co-operation between relevant authorities and the Department of Immigration, to identify illegal immigrants in Australia.

We will improve co-operative arrangements between Federal and State Police forces to ensure more efficient action in the detection and apprehension of people involved in organised crime, illegal immigration and tax evasion, especially in the black economy.

When I read through this document it seems that a lot of it really does not square with the opposition that the National Party of Australia has been mounting to what the Government is proposing for the Australia Card. As I said a few moments ago, I find it a case of cheap politics with rhetorical appeal.

The Australia Card legislation has been debated in this Parliament on two occasions. It has been before the Senate on two occasions. It was the technical reason for the Governor-General granting this Government a double dissolution for the 11 July election. I remember reading full page newspaper advertisements on the Australia Card on the first Saturday of the election campaign. Yet the Opposition and the people around Australia who are now raising a lot of noise in opposition to the ID card were very silent during the election campaign. I do not think that it is incumbent on this Government, having raised the issue in the first instance, to continue talking about it when the Opposition did not want to talk about it during the election campaign. I find the Opposition's claim that we somehow do not have a mandate for the Australia Card pure nonsense. We certainly have a mandate. If the Opposition chose to ignore the matter in the course of the election campaign, so be it. I ask honourable members opposite not to claim that since the 11 July election somehow or other we have not got a mandate. Every honourable member knew that if this Government were returned on 11 July it would have an opportunity to have a joint sitting of the Senate and the House of Representatives to ensure that the legislation was passed. Honourable members opposite, irrespective of their comments today, cannot run away from that fact.

The Senate's first rejection of the Bill delayed the implementation of the Australia Card program by at least six months. That delay has meant the loss of about $440m in revenue. Every additional six months delay will cost honest Australians $440m. The mathematics-just like the Australia Card-are very simple. I am sure that most people in the Australian community if given a chance to hear the facts during the debate will be convinced of that, as is the Government. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once upon a time the Australian Labor Party was a fierce critic of any whiff of a suggestion of an identity card system. This was so even in wartime. When the then Minister for Defence and honourable member for Corangamite, Mr Street, introduced the National Registration Bill in May 1939 the Labor Party attacked it bitterly. That Bill was mild compared with what is proposed today. It merely proposed to use the Bureau of Census and Statistics to record on a register some basic information on the males in the population aged between 18 and 64 years. This would be done so that the Government would know what manpower resources Australia had for the war effort. It is instructive to read in Hansard this statement by the then Leader of the Opposition and later to be Prime Minister, John Curtin, about that proposal:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this is a land in which personal liberty is still a cherished possession, and that there are limits to the coercive authority which the State may exert upon the individual lives and liberties of the people. There is no hypocrisy about the determination of the Australian people to defend democracy. It appears to be a little absurd for us to be asking the people of this country to defend democracy in remote parts of the world, while, at the same time, we seek to sacrifice some of the fundamental principles of democracy here at home in the process.
Another Australian Labor Party member, Frank Forde, who also went on to become Prime Minister, used even stronger language when he said:
In those countries which Hitler and Mussolini rule with ruthlessness, such a register is likely enough, but why should it be necessary to compile one in this country?
He continued:
I have no doubt that the Government is tending towards fascism.

Another Australian Labor Party member, Ben Chifley, who became Prime Minister in 1945, took action to abolish the identity card system when he came to power. Goodness knows what these men would say if they could see this monster of a Moscow card that the Government is trying to foist on us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would turn in their graves.

—They would. They would see that in 1987 it is against the will of the people. I guess the deterioration in attitude of the Australian Labor Party to individual liberty since the time of Chifley, Curtin and Forde-a concern for liberty and privacy so eloquently expressed by Curtin back in 1939-can be shown by the regard the present Ministers have for privacy in 1987. As an example of that let me quote from a report of a speech of the Minister who originally introduced the Australia Card legislation into the House last year. Let us compare the view of the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, with that of John Curtin. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say, as a socialist, that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.
Lenin would have been proud to have written that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Duncan is embarrassed by it.

—I have no doubt that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support is embarrassed by it. Many people, even some members on this side of the House, were attracted to the idea of an identity card when they first heard that the Government was to introduce it. As was the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), I was attracted to the idea because I thought that it might have merits. People were told that an identity card would stop welfare fraud-an appealing proposition; stop illegal immigrants taking jobs; stop tax cheating; replace the Medicare card; and cut a swathe through organised crime. I think we all approached the matter with an open mind. At that time the opinion polls were running 85 per cent in favour of the card. However, when we looked at the legislation, saw that it was not going to work and saw the draconian proposals contained in it, we soon changed our minds. We opposed the legislation from day one. I compliment the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) for taking that courageous stance at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The next poll showed that only 75 per cent of people were in favour. I think that the figure was down to 67 per cent at the start of the election and had dropped to 55 per cent in favour at the end of the election. It is now running between 14 and 40 per cent, according to what poll one takes. As people become aware of what is contained in the legislation they are turning against the card in droves. At present I have in my room 500 petitions to present to the Parliament. I guess that with any new legislation such as the Australia Card Bill, which contains hundreds of pages, or the Bill of Rights Bill it takes some time-perhaps six or 12 months-to sink in with the media and the general population. But when they become aware of what is involved, just as they did with the Bill of Rights Bill, they turn against it. It is to be hoped that the Government drops this Bill just as it dropped the Bill of Rights Bill. I am sure that the Minister in charge of the legislation, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), does not have her heart in it.

One of the main reasons why we of course oppose the Bill is that it simply will not work. As far as stopping welfare fraud is concerned-a matter which attracted many of us in the first instance-we are told by the experts in the Department of Social Security that only 0.6 per cent of such fraud is due to false identity.
