Even if that percentage is pitched a bit lower than the actual figure, it is a very low figure. The Bill will have little impact in this area. Some 61 per cent of social welfare fraud is due to changed economic circumstances. For the Australia Card to work it would need weekly updating.

The card will have some impact in the tax area. Basically the card is a tax gathering card to catch up the small operators; the large operators will go untouched. Of course, the cash economy will go untouched too. The Government freely admits that. It is the Government's intention to pick up the smaller operator in tax fraud, but there are cheaper alternatives which the Liberal and National Party Opposition would support. There have been four or five reports now on the Australian Taxation Office and the inefficiencies that exist there. Those reports have pointed out how these inefficiencies could be rectified so that tax fraud could be picked up. Of course central to that would be upgrading the integrity of the tax file number. This would have virtually the same effect and could be carried out much more cheaply, and people in Australia today who wish to remain anonymous, for whatever reason, could continue to do so. Their tax details could go straight to the Tax Office and not be swapped with any other department. Of course no photograph would be used.

As far as illegal immigration goes, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs itself could not substantiate any of the Minister's original claims, and anyhow illegal immigrants often work for cash at lower rates. The Government's other claim is that it would cut a swathe through organised crime. The one person who has fought organised crime diligently in this country, namely Frank Costigan, before the Government cut him off at the knees, opposes the card. He believes that it will be useless and perhaps even counterproductive. So much for organised crime.

The card is clearly not cost effective. It will cost upwards of $1,000m of taxpayers' money to implement; it will cost business perhaps something in the vicinity of $2,000m to implement; and it will mean the employment of an extra 2,150 public servants. There are better and cheaper ways of doing it.

We in the Opposition are also concerned about the dangers associated with this card, first and foremost being the computer linking of departments that contain information. One has only to look at the information that will be contained on the Australia Card Register. Already we have seen problems of information leaks in this country, examples of which have been given here. The classic example of information leaked for political purposes is that involving doctors' incomes during the dispute in New South Wales a year or so ago. I refer to the information to be listed on the Register, as referred to in just one of the eight categories in schedule 1 of the Bill: a person's Australia Card number and the documents used to establish identity; a person's name and his recognised name; date of birth, signature and sex; current residential address and postal address; any title of the person; the person's status as an Australian citizen; his eligibility or otherwise for Medicare benefits; his record of right to obtain employment; and his previous names and previous addresses. The list goes on and on. All 16 million Australians will have to turn up for an interview and have their photograph taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be talking about Russia.
—One would think so. The logistics of that sort of thing are mind boggling. The mere fact that sick or elderly pensioners will have to turn up physically will lead to difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from that, this legislation turns around the attitudes we have had in this free country-and there are not too many around the world-that we are born with rights. As soon as we have landed on the doctor's table we have inherited rights, but now the Government wants to grant us the right to exist. If it does that, it does not take much logic to extend that to the Government taking rights away. If it takes one's card away there will be many things one will not be able to do.

The Government says people will not have to carry the card with them. Whilst that is true, there will be many things people cannot do unless they have the card on them, including normal day to day activities such as: opening a bank account or an account with a building society or credit union; continuing to operate existing accounts after the legislation is enacted; investing with any government body, any solicitor trust account or any interest bearing deposit; and investing with any cash management or property trust. Without the card a primary producer cannot open an account with an agent or be paid by a marketing authority. One must have the card if one wants to have anything to do with rent or wants to get a job, and if any government payment comes to a person such as happens with doctors and chemists. One must have the card if one wants to buy or sell land, operate a safety deposit box, buy shares, buy or sell futures, and if one enters a hospital, collects Medicare benefits or is a pension receiver, whether it be a Department of Social Security pension or an old age pension. One must also have the card if one wants to get an Australian passport. The list goes on and on. The card has to be presented for all these things.

The practical examples of how this may not work have already been listed. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) suggested that if someone bought some shares he may open an account with a stockbroker who would record his identity card number. The legislation says clearly that the stockbroker cannot keep it for any great length of time-that is vague enough as it is-and I suppose the number might be destroyed after 2, 3, 5 or 10 years. However, we all know that a person who buys, say, BHP shares might put them in his drawer and forget about them. Then someone rings him up many years later and says, `Look, Holmes a Court has pulled the plug. Sell your shares because they are going to collapse'. So the person rings up his broker, who says, `I am sorry, we have to sight your Australia Card number'. It will take two days to get the card number to the stockbroker or for him to get a section 36 certificate, and by that time it is too late-the price has collapsed and the person has been disadvantaged. The card is totally impractical and it is inconvenient in many ways.

So we have seen how the card will not work and we have seen how the Australian population is swinging against it, but we also have many other concerns. One is the offences in the legislation. I think someone told me he counted up 55 instances in which one may be fined or gaoled, the penalties ranging from $500, if one loses the card and does not report it within 21 days, up to $100,000 for particular offences committed by business. Penalties of several years gaol may go with these fines. For example, if one defaces or alters the card there is a penalty of $5,000 or two years gaol, or both; for forging the card the penalty is $10,000 or five years gaol, or both; and if one is in possession of someone else's card without reasonable excuse-my mind boggles as to what a reasonable excuse might be-the penalty is $10,000 or five years gaol, or both.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is even worse than if you forget your tax return.
—It is. There are some individuals in this country who are let off scot-free if they forget their tax returns.
—In this Parliament!

—Indeed. The maximum fine for social security cheats is $2,000, so where is the Government's heart in cleaning up fraud in this country? Even a single employer can be fined $20,000 unless he sights an employee's card. The legislation says that he is required to sight the card. To me that means that he must sight it, but the Government says that that is not necessarily so. All these sorts of legalities will be determined in the courts. The whole thing is a legal minefield.

SPEECH.PARA: The bureaucracies being set up or expanded also trouble us. The Health Insurance Commission is to be expanded into an administrative authority. The Data Protection Agency, which is supposed to look after the privacy safeguards when the legislation is in place, has to be set up. An Australia Card Register will be set up, containing all the central information. The Data Protection Agency Advisory Committee will be appointed and the National Births, Deaths and Marriages Register will be set up, et cetera. All the people involved with these things will have titles and salaries to match. It will all cost the taxpayers a great deal of money.

We can perhaps summarise this whole debate by saying that the Australia Card is at best a tax gathering card to hit the small operator. It will hardly touch welfare fraud and organised crime at all. It is definitely cost inefficient. There are better ways of going about curing the anomalies in our society that this legislation is supposed to be directed at. Above all else, it will change the very nature of our society. People will not be able to remain anonymous, as they have been. It is a part-this is what disturbs me-of the socialist agenda under which Big Brother can trace one's movement around the country. We have only to go back to the quote I read out from the Minister for Community Services and Health if we have any doubts.

I appeal to honourable members in this chamber to reject this plastic policeman, to stop this gross intrusion by government into the lives of ordinary Australian citizens. If by some miracle this legislation is passed we on this side of the House pledge to repeal it immediately upon return to government. The Government should at least have the decency to call a referendum on this issue to determine the true will of the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with great pleasure to support the Government on the Australia Card Bill 1986, having on the two previous occasions when this legislation was debated in the House supported the proposal. After listening to the speeches from the honourable members of the National Party of Australia on my right today I can see why the National Party did so poorly in the last Federal election. It took five members of the National Party collectively to put together one speech, and then the speech was purely negative and did not relate much to the Bill. It was a most useless contribution to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you see what I mean. It takes five of them even to interject. I know that National Party members are a very difficult act to follow, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I will do my best to bring some reality back into the debate. If we accepted what was just said by the Opposition we would probably burn 50 per cent of the legislation passed by this House since 1901. In reality, the legislation Opposition members object to is less draconian than the legislation which encompasses the Income Tax Assessment Act. I find it very strange that Opposition members on this side of the chamber, which I now find myself on because of the sheer numbers of Government members, really do not understand the realities of rights, liberties and freedoms. They have the weird and wonderful notion that the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, for example, would remove the freedoms of people. They opposed the Bill of Rights. They argued in this House that somehow the common law creates rights for individuals. They ignored the reality that the common law as established in medieval England was established to protect the rights of property, not the rights of individuals or human beings. Nevertheless, their view is that common law rights are the rights they wish to protect. The speeches by Opposition members today are designed not to protect the rights of individuals but to protect the rights of property, the rights of the people they represent.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that Opposition members opposed the Cash Transaction Reports Bill in this House, which was designed to tackle the problem of cash moneys flowing from fraud, drugs and criminal offences back into the legitimate banking transaction system and thereby becoming legitimate. The Government put the Bill up, a very prominent and proper proposal. Who opposed it? It was the Opposition. Anything which the Government does which is designed to prevent fraud and to tackle serious social inequalities in cash and wealth movements in this country this miserable Opposition will oppose. Opposition members, in opposing such measures, mask the real reason for their concern by using words such as `freedoms', `privacy' and `liberty'. That does not hide what they are really concerned about.

Who led in the debate on behalf of the Opposition? It was the great paragon of virtue, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the member who is so concerned about human beings, so concerned about the rights of individuals. The mere fact that the honourable member for O'Connor leads the debate for the Opposition indicates the paucity of the Opposition's views in opposing the legislation. That speaks for itself about the lack of real concern the Opposition has. It indicates the paucity of depth of talent it has. That concerns me. The honourable member for O'Connor has his angry face on now. When the honourable member for O'Connor stands in this House to debate real concerns for individuals and for privacy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask the honourable member to resume the debate before the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. This indicates the paucity of depth and the lack of ability to debate the concerns of this Bill. This Bill does not impose on the Australian people measures of concern worse than those which exist in current legislation. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) last night interjected that if he employed a baby-sitter the baby-sitter would have to produce an identity card.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member was in the chamber yesterday. It is his obligation to speak the truth if he is able even in the slightest sense. The fact is that the Minister agreed that in those circumstances the card would be presented.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—That indicates the paucity and lack of endeavour of the Opposition. That was a stupid point of order. The honourable member for Mayo and other members of the Opposition do not realise that if the honourable member employed a baby-sitter he would have an employee under the terms of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Under the terms of that Act the honourable member for Mayo should then register as a group employer with the Australian Taxation Office, fill in the forms, provide information about that employee or alternatively purchase a tax stamp sheet. Then he would have to require details of birth, age, address and all the other details required under the Income Tax Assessment Act to employ that baby-sitter. The failure to do that imposes the liability for draconian penalties. It means that the Australian Taxation Office, through its inspectors and its auditors, could without warrant, without a court order, enter the house of the honourable member for Mayo, search the house and seek documentation and information concerning the proper taxation which should be deducted because of the employment of the baby-sitter. That is existing Australian law under the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice the Opposition does not object to that law. It does not object to the fact that in any employment situation all of this information, by law, is required and the failure to obtain that information imposes the liability for draconian penalties. In fact, Opposition members supported that legislation; it was during their term of government that those draconian laws were enacted. Why were they enacted? Such laws were passed by this Parliament, quite properly, to ensure the fairness and equity of the treatment of the rights of all Australians in taxation law, to ensure that those who do not wish to comply with the majority view on taxation and wish to escape the obligations imposed by the taxation Act cannot do so. I do not suppose I will find any objection from the Opposition on such a very basic principle. Why then do Opposition members complain about the Australia Card? What makes the Australia Card legislation so different from the penalty provisions of the Social Security Act and the penalty provisions of Australian taxation legislation? They reflect the same principle and are based on the same foundation and impose similar, and I would suggest lesser, penalties as existing legislation now provides. One can go to gaol under the penalty provisions of taxation law if one does not comply with the legislation. There is no gaol provision in the legislation we are currently debating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is provision to gaol people in the legislation. Will the honourable member either evidence that he knows what he is talking about or stop telling fibs?
—I call the honourable member for McEwen.

—I will ignore the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I usually do. He is regarded as a joke by most people who watch the proceedings in this chamber and I regard him as a bit of a joke. The Opposition cannot cope with the intellectual part of this debate. Opposition members cannot say to this House why they support measures such as I have mentioned in the Income Tax Assessment Act and in the social security legislation and why they object to such measures in the Australia Card legislation. As I stressed earlier, these are the very people who opposed the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. These are the very people who opposed the Australian Bill of Rights. Heavens to betsy, what sort of rhetoric did we hear from them on that subject? What sort of rhetoric indeed! We are talking about deception; we are talking about distortion; we are talking about the use of rhetoric to inflame Australian citizens who lack a depth of understanding and knowledge of the English common law system, as do many of us. We saw what members of the Opposition did in regard to that Bill, yet they sit here today and accuse the Government of deception. They have a lot to answer for in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no objection to the concept of a plastic card containing my name, number and photograph. I have three ID cards in my wallet right now. As a member of the Law Society of Victoria who once dealt in part with criminal law matters, I require an identity card, issued by the Law Society, to enter Pentridge Prison in order to interview clients. The Law Society's computer contains my name, address, age, date of birth and other pertinent details about me. I need that card every year in order to get a current practising certificate. I have no objection to providing the information to the Law Society of Victoria under the Legal Profession Practice Act of that State. I have no objection to being required to carry an identity card which has my photograph on it in order to enter Pentridge Prison, or any other penal institution in Victoria, to interview clients; no objection whatsoever. I suppose that members of the Opposition would not object to that, or do they suggest that any person, on stating that he or she is a lawyer, could walk into a penal institution and have access to people in it? That is the option that they must discuss regarding that matter.

I have a Victorian drivers licence for which I volunteered and which I wanted. In the application form I provided quite personal details which are contained in a computer file held by the Victorian Government. I was issued with a plastic card which has a number and a photograph. That is another ID card. I have no objection to that ID card. Indeed, why should I? Do members of the Opposition suggest that ID cards which are issued for the purpose of allowing people to drive motor cars are somehow wrong? Do they suggest that the information stored in the databank of the Victorian registration and licensing authority is being leaked or sold to private enterprise? The fact is that those cards have been in existence for a long time. Neither the Victorian Government nor any other State government which stores this information on individual citizens in databanks has sold it, and they will not sell it.

Let us look at the information held by the Federal Government. What sort of information do honourable members opposite think the Australian Taxation Office holds on every Australian? The information it holds is far more detailed than what is held by any other Commonwealth department. Yet since 1901 what evidence has there been that the Australian Taxation Office, its officers and staff have ever breached the obligations of secrecy imposed on them? No one in this House-not least a member of the Opposition-has given detailed evidence of leaks of sensitive information from any Commonwealth department which has been to the detriment of any individual. I defy any member of the Opposition to produce in this House evidence that the Australian Taxation Office, its officers and staff have breached those secrecy requirements and have in any way, shape or form acted to the detriment of any Australian citizen because of information stored in databanks.

The Department of Social Security requires a recipient of a social benefit, such as the unemployment benefit or age pension, to produce a cardboard identity card issued by that Department. No person in receipt of the unemployment benefit in this country can walk into a Social Security office and collect the unemployment benefit without the production of that ID card. Mind you, being a cardboard card, it is torn or destroyed very easily. It is quite a problem to issue them all the time. Pensioners require an ID card issued by Social Security to get their pension. They require a concession card, which is an identification card, to obtain the concessional benefits provided by the Commonwealth and State governments, such as free transportation on public transport systems. Without that card, they would not get the benefit.

Do members of the Opposition object to that? No, they do not. They support such ID cards and such systems. Why, then, in all logic, do they object to a single card incorporating all of those facilities through a centralised system? The answer is very simple: Their real concern, as expressed in the debate, is the cost to their mates-the cost to business. It always comes down to the fact that the people they represent do not want to pay for it. When we debated the cash transactions legislation they did not object to the tracing of illegal cash through the financial system; their objection was based on the cost to the banking system. Their objection was based not on a proper notion of the legislation or any desire to catch crooks, but on the cost to the banks. If one listens to every member of the Opposition who will speak in this debate, their arguments will always come down to the fact that business does not want the card because it imposes an obligation on it. They are happy that people are able to use false names in the banking system. They are happy for people to cheat the system. They are always happy to allow systems which enable fraud to occur, to maintain themselves and to continue in the future. That was their history in government; it is their history in opposition, and they will stand condemned for it.

The Bill, if properly read and construed, does not take away the rights of freedom or liberty of any Australian. Those rights exist for individuals and can be expressed by individuals. There is no such collective notion of rights. The rights exist only within the state. It is only through a social system such as we have experienced in the last several centuries that those rights can flourish. The rights ultimately must flow from the system. They are not individual rights; they never have been. Any such notion is a misnomer. The individuals of a society such as ours owe that right to the state. Without that there will be no society; there will be no state. I believe very firmly that that notion is the only notion with which societies can operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principle of socialism.

—Have a look at Locke, Hume, Bentham, Smith and a few others who talked about rights and freedoms. The honour- able member should come back to the philosophical base of what this is all about. He should not talk nonsense. That is why I support this card. There is more for it than against it. On balance, it will provide a fairer, more equitable society. Those who would cheat and defraud the system will be made to pay their fair share. By doing that, it imposes an obligation. It is a two-way deal. Nothing comes cheaply in broad societies such as ours. All citizens, having regard to any new change, must bear some burden. I am prepared to bear that burden. I firmly believe that in the long term it will be beneficial for all Australians and will present a better and fairer society. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) was a perfect example of the attitudes of the Australian Labor Party. Last night we saw presented in this House a Budget which claims to be one of fairness and equity. In fact, the people who will pay for the Australian Government's mismanagement of the economy and pick up the deficit will be the families and small businesses of Australia. The Government is getting into their pockets to balance its Budget. In this case it is also attacking those who are honest and fair-minded in the community by asking them to tackle a job that it is not prepared to tackle in proper ways with proper and acceptable techniques of government administration.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the special ID card which will be issued to visitors who stay in Australia for more than six weeks is both unworkable and dangerous. That is the Government's proposal. Visitors who come to Australia and stay for more than six weeks will be issued with an ID card. Sure, it will be different from the ones that the rest of us carry. But let us examine the number of those cards that will be issued over 10 years. Approximately four million cards will be issued to visitors over a period of 10 years. Those four million cards will be used, I imagine, in the Australian community as some sort of internal passport. But when those visitors leave Australia nobody will collect the cards. So over that period of 10 years Australian ID cards in every country will be exposed to every forger and every person who wants to abuse our system and who can lay his hands on the Australian ID card from a friend who was a visitor to Australia.

The Government claims that part of the purpose for introducing the ID card is to reduce the number of jobs that are taken from Australians by illegal immigrants. Let us examine that claim for a moment. There is no need for any applicant for any job to produce a card. A person can say that he has lost the card, that he has left it at home, that he cannot find it for the moment, or that he had overlooked the requirement to get one. The employer is then required to establish that he has asked for the card and he has to inform the central authority of the fact that he asked for the card and it was not available. The employer may face a fine for not gaining access to a card but not the potential employee or the illegal immigrant. There is no penalty against them when they go for a job.

I bring to the attention of the House two instances over the last 18 months of apprehended illegal immigrants, one in the Dubbo district and one in the Shepparton district. Farmers were facing seasonal pressure to complete their harvests-in one case asparagus and in the other apples. There are many instances of seasonal pressures for work. They occur in industries that are basically affected by the weather, they can occur in the building industry, in the transport industry and in primary industries. In Dubbo and Shepparton seasonal pressures occurred with the crops that the farmers were harvesting. In one instance the employer had a permanent application for that part of the year with his local Commonwealth Employment Service for any staff that he could gather. A group of individuals turned up at his front gate. Those people presented themselves as having been referred by the local CES office. He employed them. It turned out that those people, who were referred by a government department to an employer, were illegal immigrants. How will the ID card do anything about that? There is no obligation for those seeking employment to produce the card. The employer takes as bona fide the telephone call from the manager of the local CES office and he takes as bona fide the fact that those people have a right to work in Australia.

How much responsibility will this Government place on individuals that it is not prepared to accept itself and which its employees are not prepared to accept? That is part of the problem. Whether we are dealing with people in the Department of Social Security, the Department of Community Services and Health, the Commonwealth Employment Service, or the Department of Immigration, they are not prepared to accept the responsibility to implement the procedures of their Acts as they are required to do. Because of their failure and the Government's failure to direct them to devise laws and regulations to solve those problems the Government has come forward with an ID card-a brilliant Sir Humphrey solution; a great big plastic card that will necessitate the employment of thousands of public servants who could be better employed implementing the Acts as they currently stand in Australia.

In the Shepparton case where illegal immigrants were employed, I do not believe they were directed by the local CES office but there was a raid some time later and they were apparently picked up by the Victorian police under the direction of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. That problem could not have been solved by an ID card. There are two elements to which the Government has not given attention: firstly, the desperation of somebody seeking labour; and, secondly, that there is no need for a person supplying labour to present a card to show that he can legitimately work in Australia. There are two basic failures in this system that the Government will not overcome.

Let me make a prediction. If the Government should proceed and not withdraw this legislation those cases will continue. The Government will drive the whole process underground. The Australian economy will become a black economy. Commentators, legal advisers, privacy committees and employers have all told the Government that it will create a black economy and that it will not be able to tag the people it is seeking to tag, certainly in the area of illegal immigration. The whole process will be driven underground.
For the benefit of honourable members and those in the gallery I will quote what was said by the New South Wales Privacy Committee in regard to illegal immigrants. It stated:

The Australia Card system can have little direct impact on this area of illegal immigration, and indeed, the black economy generally. Its most significant effect may be to force the illegal immigrant who participates to some extent in normal community life, into an existence entirely in the `black economy'. Surely this would be an unintended, and undesirable, consequence of the Australia Card.

This was said by members of the New South Wales Privacy Committee-the Government's own guys in the New South Wales Parliament who were looking at the ID card. They have examined it. No wonder Barrie Unsworth is opposed to it. The New South Wales Government has done its homework; this Government has not. This Government got on a high kick of going after the pinstripe criminal but it has not thought the thing through. It has not thought about the normal battlers and the normal person seeking to harvest a crop. It has not thought about the way in which illegal immigrants will look at the situation on arrival in Australia and how they will seek to use the system to suit themselves. But the New South Wales Government has. With a forthcoming election it is no wonder that the Premier of that State is so absolutely opposed to what this Government is doing.

I made some remarks about the desirability of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) checking to see whether a person is an illegal immigrant. That provision is not in this legislation. I would have thought that it would be a simple matter to ask people to produce their passports. That would clearly show whether a person was here legally. If anybody opposite says that a passport is not good enough evidence let me tell him that a passport will be used to create the ID card that visitors will have. Passport information will be the information on that card. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) can shake his head but photographs will not be taken as people come through the front gate; the photographs will be taken away from the airport some time after they have entered Australia. If the Minister does not think there are risks in that even he is more simplistic in his ideological commitment to this issue than I would have dreamed. The mind boggles when we realise that the ID card that visitors to Australia will have will not be based on the information in their passports. What other documentation will the Government use? Will it use an arabic birth certificate? They are not produced too frequently in Lebanon and people do not travel with them in their pockets either. What will the Government use as evidence to establish that a person coming through the front gate is who he says he is?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor with a passport.

—Nor with a passport, I admit that. So why the ID card? The Minister has proved the falsity of his own argument by that interjection. He has proved that there is no advantage in the control of illegal immigration by government departments by the use of temporary ID cards for visitors to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Government has said that if people get through the network of social security, the CES and all the rest, the Australian Taxation Office will pick up these illegal immigrants when their employers submit their tax returns, or some time later when they are required to submit tax returns. Of course, we depend on them maintaining the same name and acting consistently as law-abiding citizens once they have arrived here illegally. We can make that assumption because that is the assumption on which the Government has based the ID card.

I have already outlined the fact that cash will be paid. No records will be kept by employee or employer in these circumstances. They do not want that. One wants the money and the other wants the job done and that is the way they will work. People will get together to solve that problem and they will forget the ID card. It will be the least of their worries. Cash will be paid and there will be no returns to the Tax Office.

Suppose there is a return to the Tax Office. Let us look at the Tax Office and the way in which it handles things. I bring to the attention of the House the prescribed payments tax which is a similar situation whereby employers, their subcontractors or employees are required to submit separate returns to the Tax Office just to check that there is no cheating in the subcontracting system around Australia. This applies mainly to the building and transport industries. It is a similar system of reconciliation of records. That is the point I am making. That is what we are hoping for with the ID system. We are hoping that there will be a reconciliation of facts that have been kept on the central computer and the facts coming in. The prescribed payments tax is only a small proportion of the whole tax gathering exercise of this Government, but it is a valid comparison.

I refer to the Auditor-General's report of September last year. He looked at the processes used by the Tax Office to match up all the records coming in from contractors and subcontractors so that the Tax Office will know who is cheating and whether the boss, employer or subcontractor is telling the truth. There are pages of criticism but this, in part, is what the Auditor-General, an officer appointed and reporting to this Parliament, said:

The large number of reductions of and exemption from the standard deduction rate is significant because there is no comprehensive system to check that the payees who are granted these entitlements disclose as income the payments they received. If the PPS is to continue to be limited to deduction of tax at source, the ATP should seek to limit the reductions in the standard deduction rate and exemptions from deduction.

He goes on to argue the processes of slackness within the system of the Tax Office where these reports have not been matched up. The Australian Tax Office does not know what deductions have been claimed; it does not know the right levels being claimed by subcontractors; it is really lost in this whole area. The administrative cost of the prescribed payments tax system is much greater than the tax collected. Honourable members would not believe it. The little bit saved is much less than what it costs to collect that money. The Australian Tax Office, in a small part of its administration, is flawed in the reconciliation process. Can anybody honestly tell me that this massive system employing thousands of people will be any better once the information starts to flow? Will the Tax Office be able to reconcile it? Of course it will not. It will be stacked away in warehouses and it will rot and mould. This Government will have its system in place, but then it will not be satisfied and will want to improve that process. Nothing is more certain.

I just want to raise briefly the exit and entry process for illegal immigrants because it has nothing to do with the ID card. It needs to be said that the control of entry and exit into and out of Australia by people visiting this country is a matter for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It is up to the Department to keep its record straight so that we know who is in Australia. Currently there is about a two-month delay in getting the computers punched up in order to find out whether people have actually left Australia. So we do not know who is here. We have about 50,000 illegal immigrants, as governments have said for a long time, and that is increasing by about 16,000 each year. But nobody really knows because nobody has kept these records about who has come in and who has left. Those are the circumstances we find ourselves in today. If we want to know who is here or whether they should be here, we just need to fix up the records at the point of entry and exit. It has nothing to do with the ID card. The real fear about illegal immigration into Australia goes back to our front gate where people come in and leave. The matching of those records is the critical factor in the illegal immigration process.

I want to refer briefly to some of the other major problems that I believe make the card unworkable in the control of illegal immigrants. What about the time delays for these cards that will be issued to temporary residents or visitors? Will they get them promptly in the six-week period, or will there be a delay? What happens if a person wants to extend his three-month visitors visa? I guess he will go along and get another card. That will be really easy. There will be a fair queue for that. Maybe that can be handled. What if a person wanted to stay in Australia and decided to go through the change of status process which is an interminable process under this Government taking up to 18 months? It can be consistently extended by the appeal processes that are available in the system. Does a person have to get a fresh card every time there is an extension? What about the court cases? Does the Government make a judgment on when the court cases that these people undertake will conclude? What is the expiry date on these cards? That is what we are talking about. There should be an expiry date and there is an expiry date, but nobody will be able to tell when it will be under this system. This is where I believe there is a real danger because there is no compulsory requirement to hand in the card. It can be forged. A person going out through the front gate after staying nine weeks in Australia can pass it on to his mate who has a similar appearance. He will come into Australia with a card and will not have to produce his passport anywhere, he just produces his mate's card. He can do what he likes. He becomes legitimate in the system. He can wander around and present himself as a visitor and do whatever he likes, but he is not who he says he is. I believe the exposure for nefarious activity is very great indeed. If I wanted to work the system this is the way I would work it: I would set up a group of people doing exactly that, not the first one through the gate, but the second or third one through the gate using the same card. That is what can be done. This card could be used for the six months less six weeks period that it is open for usage. As I have said, hundreds of thousands of cards will be spread around the world.

I come to the final point in illegal immigration, because this does concern me. The Government says that illegal immigrants will be controlled by this card. The fact is that the inspectorate process and the actual apprehension of illegal immigrants is 12 months behind notification. The Government is running 12 months behind in catching the people it knows of. How will the card help? What will it do to assist in gathering illegal immigrants? Nothing! We will have heaps of mouldering information, but it will not produce the results. Apart from that-here is the classic of the lot-the officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs can ask somebody to produce his card but because they are prescribed persons they will face a fine of $5,000. The Government is crazy in what it is doing in Australia today. Why does it not scrap the card? There are enough members of the Government with conscience and understanding of what they are doing to persuade the Government to gently fade away from this card. There is no need to take it to the barricades. This is the pride of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is all honourable members are supporting in this House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak in this debate. I have been a firm advocate of the Australia Card ever since it was first mentioned at the National Taxation Summit. I feel the Australia Card is important in bringing about fairness and equity in our taxation system. It is an issue that I feel should be explained in very simple terms.

SPEECH.PARA: A large amount of misinformation is now being spread about the Australia Card. I think it is time we went back to basics. What is really contained on the Australia Card? What is contained on the central data base? We are led to believe by the opponents of the card that large amounts of information are contained there that can be accessed by all sorts of different people. In reality, on the central data base will be the name of the person, his date of birth, his sex, his address-residential and postal-and a digitised photograph. That is all that is contained on the central data base of the Australia Card. There is nothing else. There are no secret agendas, as was pointed out yesterday. What the opponents of the Australia Card would like us to believe is that there is a secret, hidden agenda to this card. There is not. This card is about fairness, equity and in bringing about a taxation system and a social security system that the Australian people can have faith in. As we pay tax there is a compulsion on those people to help support the less needy. There is a willingness to pay the tax if they are conscious that the less needy are receiving the benefits and that people are not ripping off the system. We have seen, through the measures taken by the Government over the past two years, a great deal of social security fraud caught and eliminated, but there is much more with which the Australia Card will deal. I have no fear about the Australia Card and I have supported it since its inception. I am sure that when the Bill is presented-we may have to do it through a joint sitting-it will receive overwhelming support.

The Australia Card brings emotional responses from different people. Those opposing it are, as the Prime Minister said, a strange collection of people. It is important in this debate to make people understand that fears are being raised for political motives. The Opposition, and the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, have been calling for a referendum. As was also said yesterday, we had an election on 11 July, and in that election the Government was returned with an increased majority. In my seat of Rankin, my majority went from 0.7 per cent to nearly 5 per cent. I campaigned heavily on the Australia Card, which was the central theme of my re-election campaign. I fail to see how people can now say that the Australia Card was not an integral part of the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to your majority?

—It went up by 400 per cent. The Australia Card was the basis of the double dissolution. The Government went to the Governor-General because the Senate had rejected the card twice. We won that election with an historic third Labor victory and with an increased majority, so much so that we have had to push over to the Opposition side of the chamber and take some of the places vacated by former Opposition members who opposed the Australia Card. In particular, I am thinking of the former member for Fisher who was opposed to the card.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that people say about the Australia Card is that there will be a lot of access to the information on it, and privacy will be invaded. The privacy provisions in the accompanying legislation provide for a secure data base with heavy penalties for those who may access illegally. Only three institutions have access to the central data base: the Australian Taxation Office, the Health Insurance Commission and the Department of Social Security. No other government instrumentality or agency has access to the very limited information on the central data base. There is no cross-linking of information between the departments. There is no composite file. All these suggestions of a huge data base on every Australian are just so much baloney.

Opposition members should try to bring some integrity to this debate. They should try not to confuse the Australian public which is easy to scare. So far the debate on this issue has not been informed. I have listened to Opposition speeches and I am sad to say that the standard of debate is probably deteriorating. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), talked about illegal immigrants, and at one stage called them normal battlers. I do not see illegal immigrants as normal battlers. What they are doing is taking jobs off normal battlers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the honourable member has taken me completely out of context. I did not call illegal immigrants battlers.
— Order! There is no point of order.
—Perhaps because the honourable member for Mitchell had to pad out 20 minutes, he did not realise what he said; but he did and I picked it up.
—We shall see. Hansard will prove the point.
—That is after you change it.
—I object to that. You withdraw that remark. Mr Deputy Speaker, I require the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Rankin to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. As the debate continues, it becomes worse and worse. The Opposition does not realise the significance to the revenue base of the introduction of the Australia Card. Perhaps it does. I am not one of those who have said that the Opposition is protecting the tax cheats and the dole bludgers. I think that the calibre of the Opposition is so poor that it could not protect anybody, even those reprehensible people whom the card will pick up. However, other and fundamental issues are involved. Over time, the Australia Card will bring to the Government over $4 billion revenue. That money can be spent on providing a more equitable and fair Australia and providing the services and infrastructure that are needed by Australian society. Why should such an innocuous piece of plastic, as this will be, raise so much ire, anger and frustration in various sectors of the Australian community?

SPEECH.PARA: Many of those who are opposing the Australia Card have opposed every reform and innovation by Government. They are the people who chase causes, if not on one issue then on another. Later this month, I shall be addressing in my electorate a rally opposed to the Australia Card. At that rally will be the same 600 people whom I addressed when they opposed the fringe benefits tax-the names change, but the committees do not.

We have to try to get this debate on an even keel. As I have said, the debate has shown that we are prey to all the phobias and fears that can be manifested in the Australian community. The Queensland Premier referred to the Australia Card as a plastic tattoo, but he and his Government were the first to introduce identity cards-one for 18-year-olds so that they could go into hotels. They were not as generous as the Australian Government-young Queenslanders had to pay $5 for the card and they queued up for it. Now, the Queensland Government is opposed to the Australia Card.

In Queensland, as in other States such as Victoria, the drivers licence contains more information than the Australia Card will, and it is all recorded on computer. Recently, I took my wife to get her new driver's licence and they accessed the computer to do so. I do not think that is anywhere near as secure as the Australia Card computer system will be. There is no privacy provision in the Queensland legislation of which I am aware. So why the phobia? It is because the Opposition has realised, particularly after last night's Budget, that it has nowhere to go. It is looking desperately for a cause and it figures that, because public opinion has been confused on the Australia Card, it can perhaps boost its public support, albeit on a temporary basis. Fundamentally, the only reason why the Opposition does not support the Australia Card is it needs to oppose. That is a sad reflection, because many Opposition members, including the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), had previously supported an Australia Card, and a more detailed and comprehensive one than we are introducing. I am sure that this sudden change of heart is only a reflection of the need to oppose.

One of the other provisions about which I would like to talk is the preconception in the community that the Australia Card can be some sort of internal passport. It will be no such thing. It will be used on a limited and selected number of occasions. It cannot be demanded by unauthorised persons. I stress that it is not an internal passport. There is no requirement to carry it, and it must be produced only on a limited number of occasions. For the record, I shall inform the House of those occasions. They are: when opening a new bank account; buying or selling real estate; sending funds overseas; investing in shares and futures; receiving rental income; commencing new employment; receiving payments from marketing authorities or produce agents; and applying for Commonwealth benefits including Medicare and social security. What is more, it has to be produced only on first contact. If people are buying shares, they produce the Australia Card for the broker when they first make contact. If people are opening a bank account, they produce the Australia Card when they first open the account.

I worked for a bank for 12 years. I wish that in those 12 years we had had a secure form of identification because, like anybody who worked in the banking system, I saw the large cash accounts that were opened in false names. I saw the money coming in and flowing out, but the people involved could not be identified sufficiently. Many such accounts were opened, no doubt, by people involved in illegal operations such as drug pushers or, in particular, SP bookmakers. One bookmaker was a client at a branch where I worked. He was prosecuted, but only after many years of illegal operations. The Australia Card will be a great boon to the banking system because it will enable the bank to legitimately identify its client base. In this society it is necessary for that to take place.

The Australia Card is a high integrity identification card, which means that we will have probably one of the most secure and reasonably fair identification systems anywhere in the world. It has a limited amount of information on it. I have no personal objection to it. When I talk to people about the Australia Card I find that very few of them have a legitimate objection to it. Many people have concerns that have been raised by the misinformation put out by the Opposition and groups opposed to the Australia Card. When this is explained to people, particularly what is contained on the database, their fears are alleviated. I stress again: the information contained on the database is very limited. It contains very insignificant information compared with what is compiled on every Australian by a whole range of institutions.

Everyone who has worked in the financial system knows that before approving financial transactions a mercantile agency is approached to find out a person's credit history. Mercantile agencies, which provide that data only on a fee for service basis, certainly provide a lot more information than would ever be contained on the Australia Card. Those mercantile agencies, as I said, are available to anybody who is a subscriber.

With this legislation, the individual is protected by the privacy provisions in the accompanying legislation. Those provisions contain severe penalties for anybody who transgresses or abuses his position within the Australian Public Service. I am sure it is a comfort to many people that this Government has pushed very hard to have those privacy provisions enshrined in the legislation accompanying the Australia Card Bill.

I hope in vain that after this legislation passes this House it will pass through the Senate. For only the second time in Australia's history, later this year or early next year, we will have an historic joint sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate. I am confident that at that stage the Australia Card Bill will be enacted. Once that has taken place, the overwhelming number of Australians will become supportive of the Australia Card. I commend the legislation to the House.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESERVE BANK OF AUSTRALIA: FOREIGN RESERVES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia which states that the average price at which the bank's portfolio of foreign reserves was acquired is close to the current average market price and that any transaction at current exchange rates would therefore accrue little or no profits. I ask: Does this mean that the record $2.7 billion revenue from the Reserve Bank's profits expected in this year's Budget is not sustainable and will fall significantly in 1988-89?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts behind the question are broadly correct, but let me say this about that which has been said about the Reserve Bank's profits: a lot of bunkum has been spoken about the Reserve Bank's contribution to the Budget. We have always taken the profits from the Reserve Bank to the recurrent Budget. Every other central bank in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development relates to its own national Budget. Unlike the days of the coalition Government, we pay the full market rate of interest on the Commonwealth Government securities which the bank holds on the Commonwealth's account. So there is an outlays transaction for that public debt interest, which we pay at the full going rate-not the 2 or 3 per cent which was the concessional rate paid in the days of the former Government-and that lifts the profitability of the bank. That reflects in the dividend which the bank then pays the Budget. It is an entirely sensible transaction.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I make is that if the Reserve Bank sells American dollars, Japanese yen or pounds sterling and realises a greater stock of Australian dollars due to parity of our currency with those currencies, it produces a profit which is akin to selling any other Commonwealth asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is below the line profit.
—Order! The honourable member will cease interjecting.

—If we sell an asset which is part of the Reserve Bank's gold reserve or currencies, the profit accrues to the Budget. The honourable member for Kooyong asked whether that will diminish if we do not support the rate in the way we did over the previous financial year. The answer to that is yes, of course it will. However, what will be sitting in its place in the starting point deficit is the improved outlays position of the recurrent Budget. That is why, if one looks at the outlays to gross domestic product ratio for next year and the discretionary savings from the recurrent changes this year, one sees that they will be greater next year than they are this year; in other words, they are ongoing. If the implication of the question is that we will have some sort of a hole which we will not be able to fill, I merely say that we have heard all this before. It has always been wrong and it is wrong again.

Exactly who will benefit from the family package and how will the package contribute to the Government's overall strategy to help families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The Melbourne Herald has claimed today that the Government may be tilting at the truth by including potential beneficiaries of the child support scheme in terms of its estimates of the number of children who will benefit from the package. That is wrong. The additional assistance which sole parent families will undoubtedly receive as a result of the introduction of the child support scheme has not been included in the estimates in terms of the family package. In December, the family package will immediately benefit around 440,000 children in low income working families. In addition, 740,000 children-children of pensioners and beneficiaries currently in the social security system; the children of the unemployed, the sick and sole parents-will benefit. Around one million children will benefit by Christmas this year. Families on less than $300 a week will receive $22 a week for children under the age of 13 years-$17 for the children of pensioners and beneficiaries-and $28 a week for young people aged between 13 and 15 years. To clarify the point, that is an addition of $11 a week for pensioner and beneficiary families. ANSWER.PARA: Apart from the family allowance supplement, we should note that disabled children are also major beneficiaries of the family package. From November, the new child disability allowance of $112 a month will replace the handicapped child allowance of $92 a month and it will be paid without income test. It will increase payments in November to 32,000 children and up to another 10,000 children who missed out in the past, because of a distinction between severely and substantially disabled, may benefit from the family package now that that distinction has been dropped.

I think that honourable members would agree, in terms of the pleas that have been made equally by honourable members on both sides of the House that income support ought to be directed towards the most needy members of the community, that there can be no criticism of this package. Indeed, it was suggested to me yesterday by a member of my Department that up to 60 per cent of all family income support paid by this Government will be directed towards the lowest quartile, the lowest 25 per cent, of the Australian population. It is undoubtedly the case that the family package is the start of a new deal for the neediest families in our community. I think that all honourable members would recognise that over the last decade this country has gone through a time of considerable stress and economic difficulty. Even in those times of stress and economic difficulty it behoves a society which believes in citizenship and fundamental principles of fairness to make resources available for the most needy families in that community.

At the centre of the Budget the promise has been launched of a decisive economic recovery to benefit Australian families across the board. No one on this side of the House, least of all the Treasurer, has ever suggested to Parliament that recovery from our economic difficulties will be easy. I think it would be agreed that in terms of that Budget we are moving along the way. Within an hour of the Budget statement the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd had dropped its interest rates to 14.5 per cent. Other banks should follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a novel deduction to realise that relatively strong growth in employment implies a utilisation of labour in the system which, on a purely mechanical analysis, tends to diminish productivity. ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that these are all novel notions for honourable members on the Opposition front bench, probably few of whom could spell productivity.
