It would have been a corker because it would have torn the Opposition tax policy to shreds. Such a letter was presented to the Prime Minister and me in 1983. An equivalent letter was written for the Australian Labor Party. This document refers to the massive runaway in fiscal policy over 1982-83 and the projected Budget deficit of almost $10 billion; it is signed off by the Treasury dated 28 February 1983. Of course that would have had a covering letter from the now shadow Finance Minister. So we know what the situation would have been had the coalition won that election. So do not hee haw about the $10,000m; that is what the previous Government left us and we had to get it down. I table the document.

—The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be aware that Statement No. 2 in Budget Paper No. 1 forecast that farm output will fall by at least one per cent in real terms this financial year and by an even greater amount if the inflation rate is higher than the projected general inflation rate of 7 per cent. How can the Minister justify his glowing comments about the prospects for agriculture when the Government's own economic advisers are forecasting a contraction in rural production?

—Most of the explanation for the decline in farm output centres on the fact that we have sold off the wool stockpile and on the fact that the wheat crop will not be as big as it could be as plantings are down. Farmers are planting more oats, barley and lupins because the livestock industries are doing very well. The assumption made on production estimates with respect to the livestock industries is that basically we can maintain our sales while the cattle herd is rebuilding. There is also some evidence of that in the sheep flock. Basically the corner has been turned by Australia's primary industries in regard to income and terms of trade. Particularly after this Budget, with inflation levels and interest rates coming down, the farm sector faces a far better situation due to the Government's superior economic management.

—Has the Minister for Defence seen a statement today from the Opposition spokesman on defence, the honourable member for McPherson, that the Defence White Paper has been derailed? Can the Minister assure the House that the White Paper is on target and that the essential re-equipment of the Defence Force, improvements to defence housing and other conditions of service have been properly allowed for in this year's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I have seen a statement from the Opposition's rotating non-Cabinet shadow Minister for Defence, and I suspect the first thing he needs to do to assist the defence function is get himself into the shadow Cabinet. It is quite unprecedented for any Opposition party to treat this important section of government responsibility in such a cavalier fashion. No doubt that is a situation that at some time will be corrected.
—Where was Scholes?

—He happened to be in the Cabinet. The second point I make is that if we address the honourable member's Press release we might get some sort of clue as to why this should be the case. The Opposition has been operating in here since the election essentially on a 24-hour memory. The first thing to point out to Opposition members in this regard is that the cuts in defence expenditure are in this Budget as they were announced in the May economic statement. The Opposition endorsed what was said in the May statement, and when questioned specifically about the defence area it said it would not increase defence expenditure. The Opposition ran into the election campaign on that policy, and indeed half the National Party ran in the election campaign on the basis that a further $75m would be cut out of defence expenditure.
—The National Party did not.

—That was the Bjelke-Petersen end of the National Party, I will admit; it was not the Sinclair end. Nevertheless, the point was made. We will no doubt learn more about the Opposition's policy when it makes its reply to the Budget tomorrow. If it maintains the position that it took in relation to the May statement, clearly it will propose nothing else. The Opposition said a bit more than that in its defence policy statement during the course of the election campaign. Much in the Opposition spokesman's Press release concerns equipment. The fact of the matter is that, within the parameters that the Opposition laid down, it was suggested by its spokesman that more should come off equipment and go on to the personnel side of the defence budget. He complains in his statement:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no commitment to three of the most important programs so necessary to Australia's defence-the upgrading of the F111s capability . . . the conversion of the 707 aircraft to an aerial refuelling role and the acquisition of airborne early warning radar.

One wonders exactly how the Opposition spokesman would have intended to achieve these things. A couple of hundred million dollars coming off the equipment vote to go on to the other side of the ledger repeated over a five-year program comes to $1 billion off the equipment vote. One wonders how the honourable member intends to include that new capital equipment within the framework of a defence budget that this Opposition would bring down.

Of course it would be completely impossible. The Defence White Paper happens to set out a 10-year program. All those elements are in the 10-year program of the Defence White Paper, and we are into year one. So if they do not appear for another month or two, I think the Opposition spokesman should be able to be patient.

If we go further through this Opposition statement we come across some genuine little gems. For example, in the housing area, for which we have dramatically increased the allocation by over about 15 per cent in an overall reduced defence budget, he says it is a sleight of hand trick, and goes on:
Of the $75m allocated to housing-
this is very smart-
$65m is for projects commenced in earlier years.

What does he expect? Does he expect when we budget in the defence area that we complete all houses at the end of the year and then say, `Right, that program is finished; now we start running again, acquire the land and get another set of houses and go for another year, and then we will stop'? What does he expect us to be doing? What does he expect that extra $10m to be for? Of course that commits us in the next year. That $10m will produce another $75m in the subsequent year.

He then complains further that some $28m of the housing budget is to be spent on housing at Tindal and the new housing program at Rockingham in Western Australia. This is a bit like the Leader of the National Party's question yesterday-we cannot include in the Budget the product of asset sales; now we cannot include in the defence housing program housing for defence personnel at new bases. Who does the honour- able member think will fill these houses-gremlins? Where does he think the sailors and the airmen will come from? Of course they will come from bases in the eastern States and elsewhere. The honourable member then comes to his piece de resistance when he discovers that the new tactical fighter program will come out at $585m in 1987-88-a reduction from the $1,000m budgeted in 1986-87. What are we supposed to do? We have paid the money for the FA18s. Are we supposed to keep spending $1 billion every year when we do not need to in order to keep the defence budget in perfect symmetry?

This is a totally absurd Press release. I suspect it is, to get back to the point I made at the outset, the reason he is being kept out of the shadow Cabinet for better days. If this is the best he can produce in his response to the Budget, he clearly has a great deal to learn. The Chinese have designated this as the Year of the Rabbit, and I think we have a white one running around in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the savings of $107m claimed by both himself and the Treasurer as a result of the restructuring of Commonwealth departments. Is it not true that whilst staff savings of 3,137 have been agreed, they have been offset by a massive increase of 3,077 in Public Service staffing levels provided in the Budget? How does the Prime Minister justify his claim of significant savings when there are none?

—It is for the very simple reason that as a result of the changes I initiated in the organisation of the Public Service there will be the staff savings of 3,000 in the full year to which I referred. I said they would flow from that; they will.

—Will the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advise the House of the current state of industrial relations on Christmas Island? What does the Government intend to do in relation to this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Christmas Island is part of the vast electorate of the honourable member for the Northern Territory. The industrial situation on Christmas Island is not good. The Government last year decided that it would expend something like $4.2m subsidising the activities of phosphate mining on Christmas Island in order that there would be an orderly wind down at the end of 1989. That included an agreement from the trade union, the Union of Christmas Island Workers, that it would continue to perform its task and continue to resile from industrial problems. I must inform the House that over the last 12 months industrial problems have increased quite incredibly there. In the past the Government has made several threats about closing the mine and these have appeared to be just threats. I can inform the honourable member for the Northern Territory-he may like to pass the message on to the trade union on Christmas Island-that the Government is firmly of the resolve that if all industrial bans and limitations are not lifted the mine will be closed forthwith.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that the Union of Christmas Island Workers is entitled to a great deal of respect. After a generation of workers on the Christmas Island phosphate mines-mainly Malays and Chinese-being subject to slave wages and slave conditions, in 1975 there was a move towards Australian pay and conditions and the Union of Christmas Island Workers is entitled to great credit for the work it has done in the meantime. There have been two redundancy schemes in the last year, one voluntary and one compulsory. The present situation is that there are 300 miners in work. There is work for them until the end of 1989; that is, 2 1/2 years of work, 750 man years of work. There are 300 ex-miners presently on the Island who are out of work, who have received redundancy payments ranging from $50,000 to $150,000 and generous resettlement packages of the order of $9,000 each. These payments were particularly to encourage them to go to Western Australia where jobs are available in the mines. Most of these unemployed miners have not taken up Australian citizenship although they are permanent residents. Unfortunately, most of these people have refused to take that offer. We have the sorry spectacle of 300 miners who have achieved quite large redundancy payments now organising against 300 miners who are in work to close the mine down.

I would like the honourable member for the Northern Territory to remind the Union of Christmas Island Workers that if the mine closes because of industrial problems those 300 workers will lose not only 2 1/2 years of work, but also their redundancy payments. So it seems to me to be not very good union principle for 300 workers now unemployed who received full redundancy payments to be working against the interests of members of their own union who would face the spectre of losing their redundancy payments if the mine were to close. I assure the House that the Government is very firm in its resolve that if the Union of Christmas Island Workers does not work and continue to operate the mine as we hope `profitably' until the end of 1989 the Government is prepared to close it forthwith. This is not a threat; it is not a promise; it is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. As the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory, will he confirm the report which appeared in the Canberra Times of 11 September that he is considering recommending the approval of a casino for Canberra? As his position to make a recommendation on this important question would be compromised if he were known to have been at or to have participated in the activities of an illegal casino in New South Wales, will he confirm to this House his evidence to a New South Wales coronial inquiry that he has at no time been at an illegal casino?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am prepared to confirm to the House and to the honourable member for Dundas, who should know better than to ask the question, that I have never in my entire life been on the premises of an illegal casino. With regard to the bulk of the question, the more honourable part of the question, yes, I did float the idea of a casino in Canberra at a seminar held by the Canberra Times here, probably on the date to which the honourable member referred. I consider this proposal to be part of the sophistication of Canberra, a broadening of its economic base, to achieve sophistication as the national capital. I cannot see any reason not to have a casino here. I think it is fairly well known that at 6 o'clock in the evening the footpaths in Canberra are rolled up and everybody goes to bed! It is time the national capital did have some sort of sophisticated night life.

ANSWER.PARA: When this idea was floated some years ago there was terrible revulsion in Canberra about this naughty concept of a casino and theories were abounding about the Mafia taking the place over and Canberra becoming a cesspool of vice and corruption. I think the advent of casinos in Perth, in Adelaide and in that marvellously sacrosanct State of Queensland-on the Gold Coast and in Townsville-has not brought about those undesirable results. It is time that the people of Canberra had a look at the future of this city. It is the most attractive and one of the most important national capitals in the world. I am concerned, as the Government is concerned, that this national capital stand on its own feet. The Budget last night has certainly given it an opportunity to achieve some sort of relativity with the States inasmuch as Canberra now has a balanced Budget. We are concerned that there is a wider economic base for this city and I think one way of achieving that, with all the spinoff benefits, would be to have a casino. The idea has not yet been floated with the Government but I can assure the honourable member for Dundas that at the end of a suitable period of public debate I may go to the Government with such a proposition.

I reiterate my answer to the first part of his question. I hope he will get this into his head and keep it there. I gave evidence to a coronial inquiry in Sydney-it seems to me quite odd that he has asked me to repeat that evidence here-that I have never, ever been associated with or entered into the premises of an illegal casino anywhere, with or without Reeboks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training participated in the launching of the important Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) document Australia Reconstructed. What examination will the Government undertake of the proposals in that document and the possible implementation of them?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I did participate, along with Senator Button and representatives of the ACTU, in the launching of the report to the Trade Development Council and the ACTU. The report grew out of the mission to western Europe which the ACTU undertook last year. I think the report has been a very valuable contribution to the kinds of issues that Australia has to confront as we try to repair the damage that was done to our manufacturing sector under the policies of our predecessors. I think the Government has not yet given detailed consideration to the recommendations that are contained within the report. Many of the issues raised in the report address the policy concerns of Senator Button and other Ministers. I think the recommendations in relation to industry training are broadly in line with what the Government would wish to see; that is, a stronger commitment on the part of employers and employees to the needs of training within industry. I think the paper that was presented last night entitled Skills Formation in Australia provides an appropriate framework in which we can address those concerns with the ACTU and with employer bodies around Australia.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications confirm advice given to the House yesterday by the Prime Minister that the transfer of confidential ID card database information via landlines will be totally secure because all ID data transmissions will flow through encryption devices? For the information of the House, will the Minister explain what is an encryption device? Can he also assure the House that such devices are totally secure from interference and decoding?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. If the Prime Minister said yesterday that that was the case, that would be the case. As to the part of the question relating to encryption, my understanding of encryption is that it involves a machine that is used to encode material to be sent on the line. That is exactly what it means, in my understanding. I imagine that anybody else who has a passing knowledge of these things would understand that that is the case. I imagine that that was what was being referred to.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. Has the Minister seen Press coverage suggesting that Telecom Australia intends scrapping public phone boxes due to vandalism? Would he care to comment on it?
—Has the Prime Minister answered this for you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the vindictiveness of the vanquished must be seen to be believed. I did see yesterday's Press reports. As the day wore on, the stories grew more extra- ordinary and got further from the truth. Telecom has no intention of withdrawing the public telephone service. Telecom has been rationalising the service over a number of years, because where phone boxes are so subjected to vandalism that Telecom finds that these boxes are more often out of service than in service, the situation dictates that there is only one choice available to Telecom. But there have been recent improvements in public telephone boxes, which some people may have noticed, which have made many of the services more vandalproof than has been the case in the past. As a result of various changes that have taken place, such as vandalproof or vandal-resistant handsets, receivers and the like, Telecom has been able to ensure a much better percentage performance of the public telephone system throughout the nation.

ANSWER.PARA: There is another aspect that I think is important-that is, Telecom has entered negotiations on a national basis and in the various States with the Neighbourhood Watch program to try to ensure that Telecom public telephone services are included in the Neighbourhood Watch program. That is an important initiative which should lead to less vandalism of Telecom's public telephone facilities in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. I refer the Minister to the Budget announcement that the Government will introduce an auctioning system for the issue of new commercial broadcasting licences, including those licences for which applications have already closed and for which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) is currently conducting hearings. Given the likelihood that a number of the existing applicants for FM licences in the Gold Coast, Gosford-the case that is of interest to me-and other areas, especially those with modest funds, will withdraw their applications because they cannot afford to engage in the auction process, will not the substantial amounts of money initially outlaid by such applicants be lost? Is there not a case for providing compensation to those applicants who incurred such outlays on the basis that there would be no auctioning system, but who will now be forced to withdraw their applications?

—I do not believe that there is. In any event, the way in which the Government is proposing to introduce this scheme will ensure that those persons who meet the ABT's criteria-in other words, those who present themselves as appropriate people to hold a licence-will still be able to involve themselves in the auction system. If they are prepared to put up the money, they will get the licence. I do not think anybody in Australia was very happy with what happened in relation to the granting of the third television licence in Perth. Everybody here will know that before that licensee was able to commence broadcasting, the licence was sold at a very large profit. In these circumstances many people throughout the nation believe that that was an inappropriate thing to do and that something should be done to ensure that such huge windfall profits should not be made in the future. The Government has taken steps to ensure that that will not occur in the future.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Dr Hewson,Mr Kent and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth. that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos. Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia present you with this petition to consider.

In reference to sole parents on the Supporting Parents Benefit or the Widows Pension, whose youngest child has turned 16 years old and who will lose their pension or benefit from September 3, 1987, regardless of whether that the child is still at school or not. These women especially the ones that have been out of the workforce for years are finding the loss of this pension very traumatic as it is a loss of security and choice for them. That, as a consequence of the Hawke Government's decision to introduce a two dollar coin in 1988,

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The wasted opportunity resulting from the failure of the Hawke Government to bring down a budget that will address the fundamental problems facing Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? He produced a Budget figure last night that was illusory and we cannot even get him in the House at present. I dare say that he will be coming. At the outset of my remarks may I say briefly, in summary point, a number of things about last night's Budget which both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and I have described as illusory. Firstly, the Budget is nowhere near balanced. Secondly, the underlying Budget deficit is about $2.5 billion, comprising $1 billion of assets sales plus, say, $1.5 billion of extraordinary profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Royal Australian Mint. Thirdly, the Budget is a squandered opportunity to address the fundamental imbalance in the Government's accounts and thereby put the economy on a firmer footing. Fourthly, economic growth is still sluggish; the outlook for investment in plant and equipment is poor, reflecting high interest rates, recent increases in corporate tax rates, and uncertainty about the wages outcome. Fifthly, the pace of adjustment to the external situation is stalling. Net foreign debt is expected to increase in 1987-88 as a share of gross domestic product (GDP). Sixthly, wage and price inflation is still above that of our major competitors in the international market-place. Seventhly, the outlook for productivity-honourable members heard about the compositional difficulties in regard to productivity at Question Time today-is poor and appears to be at odds with the second tier wage awards. Finally, current outlays rose by 6.9 per cent while capital outlays fell by 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a simple proposition wrapped up in all that. Let us face it, many in the media are commending the Treasurer on his Budget. It has been described by one person from Melbourne as a dream Budget. What has changed? Has our foreign debt been reduced? Are the difficulties on our current account going to evaporate? Are we in fact going to get significant increases in investment? Are we going to get tax relief? What has changed? There is an illusion about that $27m and last night the Budget was a missed opportunity to get Australia's house in order.

The $27m deficit is an interesting figure. It is the product of what is euphemistically called these days creative accounting. I think the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), has a different phrase. I think he refers to cooking the books. But creative accounting appears to be it. If we delete the $1 billion, being the proceeds of asset sales, the transfer of the extraordinary profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia, which today in the House the Treasurer has confirmed will not be there in the next financial year, and the profits from the Australian Mint, the figure is closer to $2.5 billion.

Quite clearly the Treasurer rolled Senator Walsh. Honourable members will recall that some six weeks ago Senator Walsh produced a very engaging, very interesting and very tough statement in which he indicated that there were 13 areas that required significant cuts-they would be quality cuts-denying the Government the difficulty of having to face the need to raise more taxes to pay for these expenditure areas in the future.

I thought Senator Walsh's statement was a commendable statement. One significant area with which I did not concur in discussing taxation was where he said we could cap it at the present level but then we ought to proceed to cut in these 13 areas. Senator Walsh was clearly rolled because what we have in this Budget is a continuation of what the Leader of the Opposition consistently described during the election campaign as the biggest spending, highest taxing Government in Australia's history. Expenditure has not been tackled and this Government at the moment is awash with revenue. Who is producing it?

Do honourable members recognise in the figures the addition of $5.5 billion in tax revenue which is flowing to the Government-$2 billion from individual pay as you earn taxpayers and $1 billion from non-PAYE taxpayers? Throughout this nation there are taxpayers who know their situation has not changed other than that many of them will have to pay even more tax to continue to fund the big spending programs of this Government. There is no endeavour to give them genuine tax relief; there is tax reform, but no genuine tax relief.

Last year this Treasurer described our nation as heading toward a banana republic. Following that Australia's international credit rating was downgraded for the first time in our nation's history. The Treasurer said that we will have to quicken the pace of adjustment to the external situation. It was a significant matter that had to be addressed. That adjustment from the Budget last night will stall. The investment in plant and equipment is shown to rise by only 3 per cent in this Budget and that is from a very low base. The Government says, `Ah, have no worry because we are turning this around'. Why? `The papers we have produced will show that by 1989-90 our current account deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product will be only 3 per cent and that will allow us to stabilise foreign debt at 40 per cent'. This is deemed by the Government to be quite satisfactory, but when we look at the composition of that foreign debt, it would require, as the Treasurer had said prior to the Budget last night, a significant improvement in the pace of adjustment to the external situation. All we will find is that the overwhelming amount of that foreign debt goes toward funding consumption expenditure and not growth in capital stock. The real test of such foreign debt is the extent to which it may be contributing to growth in capital stock and productivity. It has not yet been addressed in the Budget itself.

The fact is that behind all the rhetoric in that short, sharp speech last night this economy is going nowhere. Foreign debt is rising and we have the worst business investment climate in decades. Why is there no significant investment? There are three fundamental reasons. First, high rates of tax; secondly, uncertainty over wages and likely wage restraint; and, thirdly, high interest rates. The fact that there will be some diminution in interest rates announced last night does not mean we are heading for low interest rates. We are moving downward from near record heights. Unless we are addressing those fundamentals of high rates of taxation, uncertainty as to wage increases and high interest rates we will not get the injection of growth in business investment.

Incidentally, I mentioned foreign debt. What I have noted is that the Treasurer has some difficulty when one mentions the additional debt burden, namely, that of public debt itself. An examination of the figures indicates that interest on public debt is 10 per cent of outlays. We are, therefore, quite apart from having to retire that debt, having to pay in interest amounts greater than this Government is spending on defence and education.

I raised the question of productivity at Question Time. Productivity, of course, is extremely low. The Treasurer admitted today that the second tier system is certainly at variance with what is placed in the Budget Papers. It was equivocal; there were compositional difficulties, but the reality that flowed through that was the inability to address the particular element in the question put to him. As for unemployment, this caring, compassionate Government has, once again, produced figures that indicate in the Budget Statements that it will remain constant despite the rhetoric of the number of jobs created. What of the much vaunted arena the third term of the Hawke Government was going to address? Honourable members will recall the phoney figures that were used to show that the task of the first Hawke Government was to fix what we had left it; in the second term of government it was to address the great macro-economic issues; and the third term of the Hawke Government was to deal with micro-economic issues. The Government made a significant start with privatisation. It has not yet been able to spell out why it is embarking on a course of privatisation. The chaos in the Australian Labor Party, split between whether it is motivated for ideological reasons or simply to fund expenditure, has not been placed before it. We do know that the Government is using it though this Budget to fund additional expenditure programs, but it has even hauled off a statement it made three months ago that, in fact, it would be selling international airport terminals.

The Government has forecast that there will be a small deficit on the balance of goods and services in 1987-88. While this item remains in deficit we are actually borrowing to pay the interest on our foreign debt. The build-up of our foreign debt to the current high levels has been largely due to our borrowing to finance consumption expenditure. In 1987-88 consumption spending is expected to increase by 1.5 per cent in real terms. Investment in plant and equipment is forecast to rise by 3 per cent. We will again borrow to finance consumption, both public and private, this year. The projected increase in domestic demand and the continued erosion of our competitiveness make the Government's projection of no increase in imports sanguine to say the least. The social costs of the Government's failure to achieve a faster pace of adjustment are large indeed. The continued large current account deficits add to our net foreign debt which has to be serviced in the future. With a net foreign debt of $83 billion that is equivalent to $5,155 per Australian. As I said earlier, if the borrowing from abroad were being used to build up our capital stock the situation may well be sustainable. However, we are borrowing from abroad to service our net foreign debt. Business investment in plant and equipment-the engine of economic growth-is declining and in the current high tax, high interest rate environment it is unlikely to recover significantly, notwithstanding the Government's projections.

What is the solution? An underlying reality flows from what the Leader of the Opposition said during the election campaign, and I remind the Government that, in response to his urgings, he and the Leader of the National Party achieved a greater proportion of the votes than the Labor Party. The solution is to reduce the tax burden and cut Government expenditure, so that Australian families can retain control over their incomes and get on with the job. With smaller Government, both capital and labour will be released from the non-tradable goods sector to move into productive employment in the tradable goods sector. In short, it is possible, through a combination of economic reforms and smaller Government to lift productive capacity in the economy, to service our huge foreign debt and to raise our standard of living. Australian people are fed up with tightening their belts while the public sector demand continues to grow.

In the meantime, we have made little headway in dealing with the foreign debt problem to which I have referred. If, for some ideological reason, or simply to maintain control over people's lives, the Hawke-Keating Government refuses to decrease the size of the public sector tax burden, the least that it can do is make a responsible effort to pull the Government's accounts into order. It is here that it has failed, by bringing down a Budget with an underlying deficit of almost $2.5 billion. Assets sales and Reserve Bank profits should be used to reduce the Government's outstanding debt, not to finance Government expenditure.

The Government is continuing to mortgage our children's future. We raise this matter of public importance to remind the Australian community that what I said last night remains the reality today. There is no significant change in Australia's economy. We are heading nowhere. The increase in foreign debt and taxation and the increasing burdens remain on the Australian economy. The figure that was used last night was illusory. The Budget deficit is not really $27m as announced by the Treasurer. He underestimates the call of the Government on national savings--

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall being in opposition in 1976 when the Australian Labor Party had lost the election, and following a period of great fiscal deterioration. I recall its spokesperson standing in the Parliament, arguing a case about fiscal and monetary economic policy and having not a shred of credibility. That is the position of the Opposition and of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). If he wants to draw to himself some recognition that his views have justice or validity, he should do so by wiping the slate clean on the manic policy that he and his Leader were associated with in the election campaign. That policy, a crude attempt to buy votes, was fashioned by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who said, `This is my chance to be Prime Minister. I am going to run for the wire and hang the consequences'. The fact that the resultant blow-out in fiscal policy would have destroyed the country's recovery and put us up for grabs was the price that he was prepared to pay to make himself Prime Minister. Fortunately for this country, the people saw through that and rejected it. Last week, the honourable member for Kooyong tried to distance himself from that policy. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise if you cut taxes, immediately you will lift the propensity to save but you will also increase the potential for imports to rise substantially.
Now I won't mind so much if those imports are going into investment and you are increasing your capital stock but you don't have altogether much control over that.
Dead right! He went on to say:
We were intending to begin the tax cuts in February if we won the election and then found them over a lengthy period of time.
I would be re-examining the funding element of the tax cuts and their introduction. It's not just a matter of credibility, it's a matter of sensible economics.

Well, too right it is. He was correct to imply that the Opposition's policy in the election campaign was an economic disgrace and a piece of economic vandalism from which he began to repair, but he was pulled into line by his Leader, and he made a statement about a day or two later saying that that was not really what he meant. The fact of the matter is that he is now standing up and talking about funding consumption expenditure in this Budget. Minus 2.5 per cent real growth in outlays, a zero deficit and he is talking about financing consumption expenditure in this Budget. He ran with his Leader in an election campaign on tax cuts unfunded, which would have produced for this year a Budget deficit of $6 billion; that is $2.5 billion on top of the forecast $3.5 billion from last year. It is some $6,000m compared to zero and he says that he is worried about consumption expenditure.

If the honourable gentleman is worried, he should get his little mate there and tell him the facts of life about economic policy. He has lost that knowledge since he left the Treasury in 1982. The honourable gentleman should tell his friend what a shocking, irresponsible, squalid policy this was and is, and how if we had had it in this country, the country would have had it, with a massive surge in imports and a massive deterioration in our current account deficit. If the honourable gentleman is worried about these things he should start at home and remedy the problem there rather than trying to give the Government a lecture.

The honourable gentleman's argument is inconsistent. A few minutes ago he was talking about funding consumption expenditure and what a terrible thing that was, but at the same time he criticised the high interest rates that were employed to dampen that demand all through the last financial year. High interest rates are bad, but the honourable member cavils at them while at the same time complaining about consumption expenditure. Yet the high interest rates were tailored to diminish consumption expenditure. The honourable gentleman seems to want to have it both ways.

The one thing that comes through in this matter of public importance is my friend, the honourable member for Kooyong, after all these years both in government and in opposition, talking about the trading goods sector of the economy. Should not the penny have dropped before, when the honourable gentleman spent all those years in that useless Cabinet with the former Government, when the oil prices set by the Arab states rocketed and their wealth rose? The penny should have dropped when our oil and coal prices went with that, but we never saw the commensurate lift in wealth here. Why was that? It was because the Government had the exchange rate overvalued. It was a managed exchange rate. It was not worried about the traded goods sector. In fact, in those days the former Secretary to the Treasury said that we needed more imports because otherwise we would be embarrassed by an appreciating exchange rate. The Government was not worried about the traded goods sector or the factories. It decimated manufacturing in Australia. It wiped it out. The Government said that commodities would do us. Resources boomed, there was the water resources project and the infrastructure program. That was the great El Dorado of which the honourable member was a part. He was a senior Minister. He was there. Now, he has discovered the traded goods sector.

The honourable gentleman is also into the capital stock. I will tell honourable members about the capital stock. The decline in that sector is one of the most sorry stories of any country. In this country the decline started in 1955 or 1956 and went on until 1985-86-all down hill. Should not the penny have dropped among any of the members opposite? Should they not have worried about the decline of the capital stock and wondered how they could lift the productive base when the equipment base was falling to bits? Should they not have done something about it? Should they not have got the balance right and lifted the profitability of the traded goods sector? What are we doing being run by the damn National Party all the time with its foolish preoccupations about what it saw to be the interests of the farm sector, although it butchered farmers with the overvalued exchange rate all those years? I can remember the late Phil Lynch's list, coming out with a big project starting up around the country. That was Liberal Party policy.

Now, the honourable member for Kooyong is concerned about capital cost and consumption expenditure. He says the economy is going nowhere. I can tell him where the economy is going. It is reducing dependence on overseas debt. It is reducing the current account deficit. Those opposite left us horribly exposed. I remind them that the current account deficit in 1980-81 was 6.1 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), when there were much better terms of trade than we enjoy today. What caused that deficit? It was due to the failure of structural policy under coalition governance-in the Liberal Party of Australia in particular. It seemed to repair temporarily in 1982-83 and 1983-84 under the weight of the massive recession. But as soon as demand popped out, out it popped again. When the terms of trade collapsed, it jumped right out.

In table 10 of the Budget Papers honourable members will see that three years of net exports, as a result of this Government's policy to float the exchange rate, make the wage system competitive and change fiscal policy, has improved in a structural way the current account deficit by $6.6 billion. That sum is not all reflected in the balance of payments because the terms of trade have eroded it. But the underlying change in volumes is worth $6.6 billion. That is what this Government has done about Australia's capacity to repair from this position. It has done it by taking speedy and swift action on fiscal, wage and monetary settings.

We really do not need the honourable member for Kooyong to come in and say certain things. I do not cavil or remark about his enthusiasm for his new portfolio, but it all rings pretty hollow because the Leader of the Opposition says, `My policies were right'. The honourable member for Bennelong was a one-shot chance for the prime ministership for the Liberals. He missed. The fact is that he is prepared to punt up the lot, wreck the place to get there, and then try to repair afterwards. If he had been in the position to present a Liberal Budget, he would be now trying to say how he would repair with tax cuts and everything else from the position he had created. He ran with the old 1950s and 1960s philosophy of Ash Street-that is, to regard all the people out there as suckers and mugs, run to the line dropping dollars all the way, and the suckers will take the bait. Well the `suckers' did not; they took the quality instead. They left him. It will not take Opposition members long, if they survey the empty green leather seats on the other side, to work out that they lost and that they will keep losing until they realise that they must get some structure and discipline into their thoughts. They have never had it.

Those opposite won government easily in 1949. They picked up all the easy days of post-war growth and bludged their way through until the end of the 1970s until they ruined the country. They are sitting back on the other side of the House like the born-to-rule brigade-except, as I have said before, we think we are born to rule them, and we are right. They think they are born to rule-`No need for any policy. A few flash words; drop a couple of Press releases'-skating down to the wire-`Journos? Don't worry about them, tell them nothing'--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few antique clocks around.

—Yes, I have a Paris obsession too. We know that it was the express policy of the honourable member for Bennelong not to unveil his fiscal policy-his tax changes. All through the last Parliament he said to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke): `We will see about tax. We will see who runs to the wire on tax'. Well, we did see, did we not? And we will see more. It was all very clever-dick stuff-`Tell them nothing. Fob the journos off. Treat them like mugs at the Press conferences. Dodge the questions'. It shows the Ash Street view; that he could slip and slide around, and dart between people right up to election day-and not have to declare a policy. Well, the only problem is that there was a pick-axe right between the shoulders from the public, who said: `No, thank you very much: this Government is taking us out of all this and we do not want to go back'.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the honourable member for Kooyong tries to take a rise out of this Government he has to change the basic philosophy. He must understand that when this Government floated the exchange rate it took a lot of the power in this economy that was abused by coalition Cabinets and gave it to the markets. The Government gave this power to the markets basically because the leadership of this Government does not trust the long-run deterioration in the political process, particularly in the hands of coalition governments. We have put much of that power to the market and it will put a stick across the back of anybody, Liberal or Labor, who is not prepared in the future to face the disciplines.

In the past, over the Monday morning cup of tea, the gang of three set the exchange rate. Can honourable members imagine anything more ridiculous than three people having a cup of tea and a scone at 9 a.m. on Monday and deciding at what price we will buy American dollars or the rate at which we will exchange dollars for pounds. Is it any wonder that we had an uncompetitive economy? This was macroeconomics Liberal Party style. We are now supposed to say, `Well, Andrew is here. He has some views. What are we to do about that?'. I will tell honourable members what we will do about that. Essentially we will ignore it until those opposite do something.

The honourable member for Kooyong, in his briefing from my former Treasury advisers, has been told about productivity. He says, `Today I cornered you on this question of productivity. You have a 4 per cent productivity case in the economy but not 4 per cent in the forecast'. I made the point about the implications of productivity and employment. I should have thought the point was understood but apparently it was not. I make the point again. The 4 per cent award has not been paid. At this stage probably about 6 per cent or 7 per cent of the work force has gained the 4 per cent rise. This is coming through very slowly and will appear in the measurement of productivity somewhat slowly. But we never assumed that there would be a full offset for productivity in year one. It will accrue as we move on and as the pace of the 4 per cent wage movement comes through. That is why the numbers in the Budget square with what is happening out there. But there are compositional difficulties in measuring productivity in the service sector of the economy, in the Australian Public Service and elsewhere.

Consumption spending-the 1.5 per cent real increase-involves 1 3/4 per cent for gross national expenditure (GNE), of which the fastest growing component is investment. If we abstract the investment and dwellings, private consumption expenditure is running at about 1 per cent. Growth is at 2 3/4 per cent. Growth of 2 3/4 per cent is sustainable in this environment because one percentage point is coming from net exports, from the very thing we need to turn the current account around. The demand components are 1 3/4 per cent for GNE. If we abstract investment out of that we are back to about 1 per cent, which is a very modest figure compared with the long run of 2.6 per cent and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of about the same. We could never have kept household disposable incomes at the levels they were at last year. They had to rise. They are rising now in an environment which can accommodate them.

I say in conclusion that when the Liberal Party gets its conceptual act together and realises what it has to do to be a government and gets a decent policy, then we will take notice of what the honourable member for Kooyong has to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), probably wonders at times why he is not liked in the community. We have just heard a tirade of abuse and trivia, telling us that everything is on course. I do not know whether everything is on course in Blaxland but I know that in my electorate of Parkes, and every other electorate around the country, the economy is not on course. Businesses are going broke. People who are doing the right thing and working are being crushed. This is the result of the policies of the fellow who is disappearing from the chamber, who does not even have the courtesy to stay to listen to the debate and perhaps learn something.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Friday, 11 September, was a significant day. It was the first anniversary of the downgrading of Australia's economy by Moody's Investor Services Inc. Who caused that? Overseas independent judges said that we were managing the economy badly. I ask: who is responsible for managing the economy? It is the man who has just disappeared out of the chamber. For the first time in Australia's history we have gone from an AAA credit rating to a AA credit rating-and we are still sliding down. It is interesting to reflect why that has happened. It has happened because of the overall mismanagement of the economy and in particular the burgeoning of our overseas debt. Nothing that was presented in the Budget last night will get that AAA rating back.

All the media presentation, media hype, et cetera, has concentrated on that so-called magical figure of $27m for the domestic deficit as though that were the be all and end all of the economic salvation for the gigantic economic mess in which Australia finds itself today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disaster.

—It is a disaster. Not one question has been asked as to how the Government arrived at that figure. Honourable members have concentrated on just the figure. It is a bit like a farmer who, having lost $30,000 for the year, sells his back paddock or tractor to balance the books and says, `I have had a reasonable year; I did not lose money'. That is just having oneself on. It is like a businessman who sells his assets to balance his losses. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) pointed out in his good speech that there are some unique circumstances, such as the sale of assets. The Government will receive $1 billion for selling off the family silver. The profits of the Reserve Bank of Australia are at a one-off high. Normally the figure would have been about $1 billion, but it was $2.6 billion. When one adds those things together one finds that the true domestic deficit is about $3 1/2 billion. So the Treasurer's presentation last night was not so magical after all.

SPEECH.PARA: Many other disturbing aspects, which the honourable member for Kooyong highlighted, go with the Budget. Receipts, mainly from taxes, were up $8 billion last year. The Treasury's coffers reaped in those receipts from the wealth creators of Australia. The figure went up from $64.2 billion to $72.2 billion and it is predicted to go up next year by a further $6 billion to $78.1 billion. That has come about because this Government has put just about every tax imaginable in place and it is now sitting back and doing nothing but raking in all the new taxes. We have had the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, superannuation taxes, assets test taxes, new sales taxes, increased sales taxes, negative gearing-I will return to that in a moment-and the indexation of excise taxes. Farmers in the honourable members' electorates would know all about that with fuel. So the list goes on. As the honourable member for Kooyong said, the Government is awash with tax money. What has it done about it?

In addition, Australia's inflation rate is massively higher than that of our overseas trading partners. To use the Treasurer's words, the penny still has not dropped. The higher rate of inflation is pushing everyone into higher tax brackets. Even though we have had those so-called Clayton's tax cuts, everybody is paying more taxes than he did before. Whatever way one looks at it, this Treasurer of four years is the highest taxing Treasurer in Australia's history. Taxes now form a higher proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) in this country than has been the case over the past couple of years. The Treasurer is fond of referring to things as a percentage of GDP. He might refer to that figure.

If we had combined spending cuts, which we did not see in the Budget, with the tax money coming in, we could have cut massively our borrowings on the domestic market and overseas and, therefore, stopped crowding out the private sector which also has had to borrow. The combination of both has forced interest rates up to record levels in the last three to four years. This Budget was largely wasted. It was an opportunity which slipped through the Treasurer's hands. Australia is being left behind. While inflation and interest rates have gone down in overseas countries in the last three to four years, because those countries have got their act together, Australia has gone the other way. One has only to compare the Australia of today with what it was when the Government took office in 1983.

Goodness knows, we had problems then but let us compare those problems with the ones that exist now. I ask: are we better or worse off now than we were in 1983? It is undeniable that the wealth creators of this country are worse off. Inflation, interest rates, and taxes are up. The standard of living is down. The current account deficit is at a record level and today a monthly figure of $850m has just been added to the statistics. Unemployment is stagnant despite all the jobs that the Government is supposed to be creating. The length of time for which the unemployed are out of work has doubled. Home starts and business investments are down. Whichever criterion one takes, we in this country are worse off today.

The Government has been the biggest instigator in creating such problems because of the economic policies which it has pursued. Now, when we get a marginal dipping of a record interest rate or a current account deficit that tips a little under the $1,000m mark, Government members throw up their hands and say that the economy is on course and that they are the economic saviours of Australia. They say, `Send us another medal for the world's greatest Treasurer' and so on. Have we ever heard such nonsense? The Treasurer is far from being the economic maharishi that he paints himself to be. It seems that no matter what he does the media will portray him as being correct. If he does something one day which we criticise, he is right and if he accepts our advice and does the other thing, he is right. One has only to look at the inconsistencies in his speech on negative gearing. It is worth quoting what he said to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on negative gearing in 1985:

I cannot believe that any leader of a major party would come into this Parliament and seek to have restored one of the most blatantly abused tax shelters in the system where people can minimise their income by running interest cost deductions against property. To try to defend this behaviour, this outrageous rort, on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary. The great majority of rental properties are not affected by negative gearing and negative gearing has not succeeded in providing an adequate number of rental properties.

What an inconsistent flip-flop that is. That epitomises the way in which the Treasurer has run the Australian economy. The Grim Reaper has scythed the Australian economy in a totally irresponsible fashion over the last four years. When he has had a chance to do something about it, when the increased revenue has been coming in because of all the new taxes which are in place, he has let the opportunity slip through his fingers-to use his words once again. If ever there was an issue on which the Treasurer stands condemned it is the way he has lost total control of the overseas debt. The gross overseas debt was about $30 billion when he took over. Today the figure has almost quadrupled to $110 billion. It took 196 years to get to $30 billion and it has quadrupled under the present Treasurer to $110 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great record!

—What a record. It is the composition of it which particularly alarms me. The Government proportion of that overseas debt has leapt markedly vis-a-vis the private portion of it. The length of time for which we are writing overseas loans has dropped from years to months. If they are ever called in, if our rating drops again, we will be in trouble, because all the debt will fall due at once. I am alarmed at how the money is being spent. It is not being spent on wealth creation areas as was previously the case; it is being spent on handouts and welfare. In addition, the interest bill has burgeoned out to $7.9 billion. We are spending more in interest payments than we are on health, education and defence individually.
—That is our biggest export.

—It is equivalent to almost 20 per cent of our exports. The debt continues to grow. None of that was mentioned in last night's Budget. It is only the fortuitous increase in the price of wool and cotton, et cetera, that is holding the economy together. The J-curve has been almost turned upside down to become a walking stick for the Treasurer. That would be the case if it were not for wool and cotton. Despite the Government's expected euphoria about the low domestic deficit, the major underlying problems remain untouched. No cuts of substance are evident in the Budget. The Government and the Treasurer stand condemned for wasting the opportunity that they had last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In politics we are sometimes accustomed to using hyperbole to describe things as a disaster and so forth when they are not. For the first time since I have been in politics, I believe that it would have been an absolute disaster if the Budget which we are now considering had been a Budget brought down by the Opposition. A Budget of the kind which the Opposition would have brought down would have destroyed this country's chance of a future. It would have meant that our children would have been emigrating to some relatively prosperous country such as Argentina. It would not have continued the excellent and sustained attack on Australia's major problems as this Budget does. I believe that this Budget is a `thing of beauty and a joy forever'. It is excellent for what it tells us about the Government's past economic management; it is excellent for what it tells us about the Government's present priorities; it is excellent for what it indicates about the future of this country under the stewardship of the third Hawke Government, including the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.PARA: I will look at the past economic management aspect first. The salient point is that essentially the Budget is a balanced Budget. We were urged by the Opposition and the business community to bring about a balanced Budget. I do not think they really believed it was possible. But that is the outcome of the Budget. It has been brought about partly by a growth in revenues. Where has the growth in revenues come from? It has come from a widening of the tax base which has been undertaken progressively over the past 18 months to two years since the National Taxation Summit Conference. The fringe benefits tax has contributed significantly to the balanced Budget. I believe that the result of the last election gives the lie to honourable members who now stand in this place and say that they regard the fringe benefits tax as unfair. Some people tried to make an issue of it but it could not in fact get off the ground.

The balanced Budget has been brought about by an increase in revenue from the capital gains tax. I think that Australians were sick and tired of entrepreneurs being able to buy an asset one day and sell it a week later for a $100m profit that was totally non-taxable. In fact the capital gains tax has contributed substantially to the Budget result we see today. The stock market boom brought about by some policies of this Government also has contributed markedly to that Budget result. As well the balanced Budget has been brought about by a more efficient administration of the tax system. Too often it has been the case that people have been able to conceal income from the Commissioner of Taxation but I believe such concealment will be prevented by the Australia Card-the introduction of which I entirely and fully support. We have brought about a fairer tax system. Contrary to the suggestion that this Budget has meant a rise in personal taxation, the Budget in fact incorporates the $4 1/2 billion in decreased personal taxation brought about in the course of the last financial year. Of course, this has involved decreasing personal taxation rates from the top marginal rate of 60 per cent to 49 per cent.

The balanced Budget also has been brought about by reductions in outlays. The major part of the reduction in outlays was accomplished in the May economic statement, which this Government had the courage to bring forward before an election rather than after. The overall effect has been that in this Budget there have been real declines in outlays and cuts in spending of 2.4 per cent. That is on the basis of a 7 per cent price deflator for non-farm gross domestic product. That follows a nearly one per cent real reduction in outlays in the previous financial year-the only case of two consecutive real declines in outlays in the last 30 years. There has been great discipline shown in this Budget, although that is not the only excellent aspect of it.

The second thing I would like to look at and something which the Treasurer touched on in his remarks is the composition of growth. The major point is that the Government's strategy has been to confine growth to the export and import replacement sector. All the growth in the last financial year has come from that sector and much of the growth in the year in prospect will come from that sector. In other words, the Government's strategy of making Australia a more competitive exporter, particularly in the area of manufactured goods-manufactured goods have contributed a large part of that growth-is working. I might mention that all this has been accomplished against a background of a fall in the terms of trade and that it is only in the year in prospect that we see some slight possibility of a rise in our terms of trade-perhaps by as much as 2 per cent. So much for past economic management.

I now turn to the present priorities exemplified in the Budget. One of those priorities concerns the major new spending commitment in the Budget, namely, the family assistance package. This Government is to be congratulated on not shrinking from its promise to bring forward a major family assistance package. The details of that package have been widely published but I will just mention them here. Some $250m is to be spent on poor children to begin to give effect to the Government's promise that no child will be living in poverty by 1990. As has been widely publicised, more than one million children will benefit from the new family assistance package. Subject to a very generous income test, the new scheme will provide a family allowance supplement of $22 a week per child. For older children of 13, 14 or 15 years that supplement will be $28 a week. For low income families who are renting there will be extra assistance of $15 a week. That means, for example, families with incomes of up to $324 a week who rent privately and have three children will receive a supplement of almost $90 a week free of tax. Compassion for the needy is a large part of the priorities in the present Budget.

Another large part of those priorities involves the creation of jobs. The Budget estimates that there will be something like 2 3/4 per cent growth over the forthcoming year and that that will result in the creation of another 100,000 jobs in the year in prospect. I remind the House that that will bring the number of jobs created by this Government and the Treasurer to over a million by the middle of the Bicentennial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great achievement.

—It is a wonderful achievement. I refer now to some of the remarks about productivity. It was alleged that we will be looking at a decrease in productivity over the year. Productivity is notoriously difficult to measure particularly when employment growth is taking place, as it is taking place, in the services sector. I refer to the boom in tourism and the job growth which is taking place in the hospitality industry. I remind honourable members that there has been a considerable real reduction in labour costs in the course of the last two years. That naturally leads to the substitution of labour for capital; in other words, the creation of jobs. That is not something for which the Government apologises. The Government set out to create jobs. It said it would create jobs, it has created jobs and will continue, as a result of this Budget, to create jobs. The second tier wage arrangements will tie the creation of those jobs to increased productivity-something of which I think all honourable members and all Australians will approve.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time that remains to me I want to deal with the future strategy of the Government to attack the major problems facing us. I refer to foreign and domestic debt. These are serious problems which the Budget recognises by making an attack on them for the first time in 50 years. This Budget will repay $1,000m of domestic debt and $1,000m of foreign debt. The projected improvement in our current account performance over time will reduce that problem to manageable levels. But we ought not underestimate the seriousness of that problem. To claim, as is claimed in the matter of public importance, that we have not addressed that problem in the Budget is a travesty. We have indeed. I commend the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Excise Tariff Proposals Nos 7 to 10 (1987) and Customs Tariff Proposal Nos 14 to 17 (1987).

The tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1982. Excise Tariff Proposals Nos 7 to 10 (1987) and Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 14 to 17 (1987) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notices published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette following the dissolution of Parliament. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 7, operative on and from 1 July 1987, introduce a package of major excise concessions for stabilised crude petroleum oil, naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas and condensate obtained from existing on-shore and off-shore production and new projects where excise and royalty apply. The new concessions, as announced by the then Minister for Resources and Energy on 4 June 1987, are designed to achieve the Government's objective of attaining the maximum level of self-sufficiency in petroleum production consistent with an efficient allocation of resources. In addition Excise Tariff Proposals No. 7 impose a surcharge of 3.9c per litre on aviation gasoline as part of new charging arrangements for general aviation. This change was announced by the then Minister for Aviation on 10 June 1987. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14 (1987), operative on and from the same date, provide for corresponding alterations to rates of customs duty.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14 (1987) also provide for phased reduction of duty on certain plastics and textile fabrics of New Zealand origin. Part 1 of annex C to the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement requires that tariff phasing for certain plastics and textile fabrics commence on 1 July 1987. However, because of the scheduled introduction of the harmonised tariff on 1 January 1988, these proposals implement only the first tariff phasings which will have validity to 31 December 1987. Negotiations are currently being undertaken between Australia and New Zealand to determine the further phasings which will apply with the introduction of the harmonised tariff.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 15 (1987), operative on and from 23 March 1987, provide for the duty free importation of certain lambskin or sheepskin leather, known as taipan leather, garments of New Zealand origin. Imports of taipan leather garments had been ruled ineligible for the concession which provides duty free importation for certain leather products of tariff sub-item 42.03.4. That decision became effective on and from 23 March 1987. After an approach from the New Zealand Minister for Trade and Industry agreement was reached between the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the then Minister for Trade to reinstate the concession. This action was necessary to ensure Australia meets the requirements of the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement. The amendment was made effective on and from 23 March 1987, the date of the decision to discontinue the concession.

Excise Tariff Proposals Nos 8 and 9 (1987), operative on and from 18 July 1987 and 15 August 1987 respectively, provide for altered rates of excise duty on certain refined petroleum products resulting from the Government's decisions on the pricing of indigenous crude oil and related issues. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 16 and 17 (1987), also operative on and from the same dates, provide for corresponding alterations to rates of customs duty. Rates of diesel fuel rebates for eligible uses have also been altered in conjunction with these changes. The changes on 15 August 1987 also incorporate increases in duties imposed upon certain refined petroleum products as a result of an increase in the consumer price index in the six months ending on 30 June 1987. These increases also came into operation on 15 August 1987. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 10 (1987), operative on and from 22 August 1987, amend the schedule to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to provide for an excise by-law to allow duty free treatment of certain petroleum fuels. This is a technical legislative amendment to clarify the existing policy that such fuels are duty free when blended with non-excisable goods to produce solvents, mould release oils et cetera used as intermediate inputs to industry.
Summaries of alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
