SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As members of the House are aware, this is the second time that we have debated the Australia Card Bill. The important thing is that we are doing so in a very changed environment. Before the last election the majority of people, according to opinion polls, favoured the proposal. After the election the majority of people quite clearly do not. Despite that inexorable fact, Government speakers in this debate, particularly the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), have complained loud and long that they are the people who have suffered at our hands, that we are running a campaign of deception and that we are misrepresenting facts and confounding reason, about which they believe they have a monopoly. They cannot understand why it is that a few short months ago their proposal had support when today it has so little, if any. I go further: if it were not for the tight discipline of the Labor Party Caucus, many members of the Government would cross the floor. That is what they would do if they had the opportunity. People such as the former Mr Justice McClelland, an ex-Minister of the Whitlam Government, have warned against the ID card proposal.
—A top man!
—As the honourable member says, a top Labor man; what he has told the Australian public is abundantly clear: he will have none of it.
—He is a Labor rat.

—We hear that he is a Labor rat. Perhaps to have a conscience, Mr Deputy Speaker, is to be a Labor rat. If that is to be the standard of morality to be wrought upon this nation over the next three years by the Hawke Government, God help us all. To have a conscience is to be a Labor rat! The former Justice Jim McClelland said in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 November 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . even if the ID card would ensure that every cent of dodged tax would be caught in its net, I still don't think that it is worth the price of making every citizen wear a dog collar.

It is interesting to recall the history of this nation and note that next year we will be celebrating our Bicentennial. In 1788 the majority of the first European settlers of this land were convicts, the flotsam and jetsam of British society. They were men and women who for whatever reason had transgressed in what was undoubtedly a difficult community in the eighteenth century. They came here with a number and individuals were known by a number. In our Bicentennial year, when we are supposed to be looking to Australia's future for our children, the Hawke Labor Government wants to give us an ID number once again. It is absolutely contemptible that in an effort to clothe this concept with the cloak of nationalism the Government has called it the Australia Card. It is not an Australia Card; it is an identification card.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all card subjects.

—As my colleague has just pointed out, we have been called `card subjects'. Whatever terminology the Government uses it is simply introducing an identification symbol for every single one of the 16 million-odd men, women and children in this land. Yet the Government regards that as a great achievement. Only last night during the Budget Speech we were told by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), gloating at his achievement, of the great rises in taxation revenue which in 1987-88 will rise by $5.6 billion, or 8.5 per cent, to $71.2 billion. That represents the highest taxing government in Australia's history. The important point is that that additional revenue was gained not through the imposition of an Australia Card or any other form of card; it was achieved by laws passed through this Parliament, right or wrong, and it was achieved by an improvement in the administrative arrangements within the Australian Taxation Office and departments such as the Department of Social Security which are responsible for reducing fraud, as is their duty.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet we are told that the reasons we need this card are to stop taxation fraud, to stop social security fraud and to stop illegal immigration. All these subjects were brought before a committee of this Parliament and a majority of its members, including Government members, said quite conclusively that the introduction of a card would not be the answer. I quote from section 4.53 on page 147 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. It reads:

Having considered the Government's proposal for a national identification system, as well as alternatives such as the use of photographic cards and the extension of the use of the current tax file system, the majority of the Committee rejects all proposals for the issuing of identity cards, with or without a photograph.

I find it extraordinary that the Government at that time was prepared to establish a parliamentary committee but was not prepared to accept its recommendations even though Labor Government members were prepared to support those recommendations. We are facing a very serious issue in relation to the introduction of this legislation. It appals me to see that so many Government members apparently take the view that civil liberties can be trifled with. If Government members have studied the modern history of Western Europe one thing should stand out. It is this: the Australian people, ever since the inception of this nation, have had a very healthy disrespect, if not distrust, for giving any government too much power. Many men, going back to the days of ancient Greece and its great philosophers, have said that whatever the regulations may be, if they are in the hands of ordinary men ultimately they will be misused.

I have not heard a single person on the other side say that he is prepared to guarantee that some future government, of any complexion, may not be able to build on the edifice which the Government is putting in place. Whatever controls the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and members of this Government may put forward, the simple fact of the matter is that the Government's writ runs only as long as the people of Australia allow. Government's change, and maybe in 50 years time the then government may wish to misuse the powers that the present Government is putting through this Parliament. The names of every one of the present Government members will go down in the history of this nation as the men and women responsible.

These are not issues which any of us can regard with anything but the greatest concern. In the previous Parliament the Minister who was mainly responsible for this legislation was the Minister for Health, now Labor's Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). On 10 June 1986 he said:
We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy, because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

Having Ministers making remarks such as that, is it any wonder that a growing number of Australians from all walks of life, of all political persuasions, are now standing up and saying: `Hey, wait a minute. Let's have another look at this idea. What exactly is this Government all about? Why is it doing this to us? What is it going to get out of it? Why can we not, through a referendum, have a say in this attempt at social engineering which this socialist Labor Government is making?'. Yesterday, when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) attempted to introduce legislation for a referendum, it was rejected out of hand because the great democrats on the Government side work on the simple premise that power gives them absolute right. They are going to learn the hard way that in a democracy there is no such thing as absolute power. They are also going to learn that the Australian people will not forget what the Government is doing to them. It will take the Government all of two or three years to get the system in place. The Government will have to fight every inch of the way and many times it will rue the day that it ever suggested that it take this particular route.

Very recently, Sweden's former head of its identification system, Mr Freese, resigned. He said that Australia should think very carefully about introducing its own version of the system which Sweden has. We are well aware that large segments of the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade union movement have some passionate love affair with the Swedish system. I grant that Sweden has made some quite outstanding achievements in social policy, but it is perfectly clear that Mr Freese believes that the idea of a tightly controlled identification system, as applied in Sweden and as the Australian Government wishes to apply to Australians, simply does not work. Why did it not work? The Government's Data Protection Agency, which is to be modelled on Mr Freese's Data Inspection Board-same function, slightly different title-would not protect the rights of the Australian citizens any more than Mr Freese was able to protect the rights of the Swedish citizens. Mr Freese said:

It may be looked upon as timidity for me to leave after a dozen years as head of the Data Inspection Board. I knew what I was doing when I reached my decision. To jump off the merry-go-round when you can no longer control the speed can also be looked upon as responsibility-responsibility not to take further responsibility.

In other words, he knew that computerisation and data collection had reached the point where it was effectively beyond the powers of ordinary, individual public servants, no matter how well intentioned to control the flow of private information in and out of the system.

The fundamental question which many people are asking today is this: in a system founded on the principle that a citizen is innocent until proven guilty, why should people have to live in an environment where, in accordance with this legislation, there is going to be a built-in presumption of guilt? The individual, the subject of the card-the `card subject', as we were told in this House-is going to be in a position where his rights as a citizen will undoubtedly be managed and controlled by whether he has access to a card. The point I made earlier was that any future government could equally amend that legislation to say, `You are a non-citizen unless you have the card and we, the Government, will determine what are the criteria which will determine whether or not you may have a card'. We hear rubbish from the Prime Minister and other Ministers to the effect that the card will not be compulsory. They say that one does not have to have the card. How ridiculous could the Government possibly be?

TALK.START.PARA: —How could you survive without it?

—As my colleague said, how could you possibly exist in a society without it? The Department of Social Security states that most fraud involves overpayment, not false identity, yet we have been told by the Government that one of the three principles or reasons why one must have the card is to stop social security fraud. False identity, according to the Department, is responsible for approximately 0.6 per cent of fraud. Most fraud is caused by mispayments and simple administrative incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said, during Question Time today and yesterday-the Treasurer made the point in his Budget Speech last night-that over $100m was saved in the last financial year from unemployment benefits which otherwise would have been paid illegally. That was not because there was a card; there was no card. It was because systems were improved. Better systems of identification were demanded. Review groups travelled around the countryside checking people's availability and right to unemployment benefits. In some cases they made substantial savings-and that is good; that is precisely what ought to happen. But surely the Opposition has the right at this time to say to the Government, `Exhaust all alternative means'. It would then have the right to ask for extraordinary solutions to what it and the Auditor-General have admitted-and members of its own parliamentary party have admitted in this Committee report-are not extraordinary problems; they are normal problems created by incompetence and inefficiency, whether it be in the Department of Social Security, the Taxation Office, or anywhere else. For the Government seriously to say to the Australian people, `We need an elephant to crack a relatively small nut', is not only absurd; it shows a gross lack of judgment and is fundamentally dangerous. That is why people in Australia are worried today.

We have been told that the card will catch illegal operators of the cash economy because cash transactions will be identified by the card. Of course cash transactions will not be identified by the card. What the Government will put in place is a huge black economy-for all intents and purposes, an illegal banking system which will run parallel to the official banking system. How many government members, for example, are aware that people can wash their money today by taking out purchasing accounts with major companies? These purchasing accounts are used to purchase ordinary clothing and daily requirements. People can put thousands of dollars into those accounts and not even buy anything in those shops. They are entitled to do it, and some people do, as a means of avoiding tax. Such schemes will not be caught by the Australia Card, unless the Government is now prepared to admit-this makes the situation even worse-that people cannot go into a shop and buy anything without producing their Australia Card. Mr Deputy Speaker, indeed we are going from the sublime to the ridiculous. I trust that the Minister is only being jocular, because if people really thought that we would see that sort of absurdity, there would be absolutely no hope for this Government on this subject.

As I have made clear-and I reiterate it-the ID card represents a massive attack on the civil liberties of every Australian and is an unnecessary extension of the powers of a gross, centralised government bureaucracy. Anybody who has dealt with the bureaucracy for as long as I have must admit that it does not work on the basis of conscience; at times it does not even work on the basis of need. It works on the principle that information is valuable; information means power. What the Government is saying in this context is that some people will have access to information of enormous consequence to hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australian citizens, who have broken no law, who have not transgressed any regulation and who simply ask to be left alone to conduct their lives as normal Australian citizens.

There is no doubt that once the ID card is introduced it can be used for any purpose, legitimate or illegitimate, depending on the government of the day and, as I said, on those who instruct and are meant to support the government of the day. It has been said, for example, that it will not cause inconvenience. How can people carry on financial relationships with financial institutions and banks, initiate investments and have transactions with trusts or cash management funds and how can primary producers carry out their transactions, when they will be expected to show the card on every occasion? How can people arrange foreign remittances? How can they arrange land transactions? How can they use a safe deposit box? How can they have investments in shares in public companies for transactions relating to future contracts, even for employment? The card is required for all those purposes. Yet we have been told: `You don't need the card.' One thing is perfectly clear: if a person does not have the card, ultimately he will not even get a job. I made that point earlier: Why should any government have the right to hold such a sword of Damocles over the heads of ordinary Australian citizens who have not broken any law?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that not much has changed since we went to the election. The Opposition, as usual, is very negative. One thing that stands out in all the speeches of honourable members opposite is that they will never put up an alternative. There is nothing constructive in what they say; it is all destructive. Not only that; as we have just heard, it is hypothetical in the extreme and also not very accurate. In fact, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who has just spoken, talked about the amount of times one would need the Australia Card to transact business. He told us, in other words, that every time people went to the bank they would have to show their card. He should know, if he has read the legislation, that that is not so.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House are dealing with facts. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, the Government has a responsibility to ensure the integrity of the taxation system and has a responsibility to make sure that those who claim social security benefits from the public purse are entitled to them. This Government, from day one, has always taken those responsibilities very seriously. I remind the House of our record in terms of social security. One of the first things we did when we came to government was to end double dipping with regard to superannuation schemes. We brought in the assets test to stop millionaires getting the pension, because they did not need it. Also, the Maintenance Collection Agency, which will come into operation next year, is another initiative of this Government to make sure that those people who claim social security benefits are entitled to them. On every one of those occasions we were opposed by members of the Liberal Party and their National Party colleagues. On every occasion their predictions of doom and gloom have been proved wrong.

In regard to taxation, we moved early in our term of government with respect to prescribed payments. The predictions of those opposite were that the building industry would collapse. Yet five years later the building industry has never been in better shape. We brought in a capital gains tax-the first time we have had a decent capital gains tax in this country. What did those opposite say? They predicted that the industry would collapse and prices would go through the roof. Again, they were proved wrong. In regard to the fringe benefits tax, the prediction of those opposite was that business in Australia was about to close down. They were wrong again. They said that prices would rise; wrong again. When we ended the deductibility of business lunches they predicted that up to 80,000 jobs would be lost in the catering industry. There are more people working in the catering industry now than there were when we took away that deduction; wrong again. In regard to substantiation, there were predictions about receipts and all the hardships that were supposed to ensue from that reform; wrong again.

We are continuing that reform by bringing in the Australia Card to ensure that the taxation and social security systems in this country are intact. We are opposed again. We have heard the outlandish projections of those opposite. I can make one prediction with certainty: in four to five years time when we are debating some other measure in this House members on this side of the House will jump up and say that the Opposition was wrong again on the Australia Card. It has never been right yet and it will be proved wrong again.

Let us look at some of the assertions that have been made against the Australia Card. We heard the honourable member for Bradfield talk about information-the power of information and all the information that the Government will get because it has this card. The amount of extra information the Government will get from this card will be nil. We will not get any more information for the different government departments than we already get. We will not-with one minor exception, to which I will refer-get any more information. So how can those opposite talk about the card as being the terrible thing that it is? How can they say that people will have to give all this information to the Government? We will not get any more information, with one exception. The one exception is that there are people in the community who do not tell the Australian Taxation Office about all their earnings and all their undeclared interest. One thing we can say about the Australia Card is that when it is brought in the Treasury will get that extra information. But that is the information we are after because, after all, by not providing that information to the Treasury, those people are bludging on all other taxpayers.

In the last financial year there were over 250,000 unattached group certificates. That means that 250,000 people took phantom jobs in Australia. They never showed up at taxation time. Do honourable members think those people were honest taxpayers? Do honourable members think for one minute that, if we do not bring in the Australia Card, we will end that? Nobody has mentioned what people get up to in the wider community-the people who really cheat the system and the people who hide behind the honest people. But last year there were 250,000 unattached group certificates and that is a conservative estimate. The Australia Card will end that abuse.

What about the information that people will have to supply to get the Australia Card? Let us look at it. As citizens in Australia people will have to tell the Government their names, their dates of birth, where they live, and whether they are male or female. They will have to prove that by bringing in their birth certificates and then they will have to have photographs taken. Is that not terrible! We could go down to the post office and find out about most of those things, yet we are led to believe by those opposite that providing this information will change the whole fabric of Australia. I repeat that people will have to supply their names, their dates of birth, their addresses and whether they are male or female. They will have to prove this, usually by producing a birth certificate, and they will have to have photographs taken. Is it not terrible that people will have to give that information to the Government?

I really do not know where members of the Opposition get off. They really cannot find an issue. They did not initiate this public debate on the Australia Card; they came in at the tail end of it. But the opportunists opposite-that is all they are-say: `There is a bit of dissension in the community. Let us take advantage of it and see whether we can stir it up a bit. Let us go and get a few petitions, pose in front of the television cameras and voice our concern'. Let us look at the cost of not having an Australia Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't start it because we didn't want it.

—The honourable member says that people did not want it. How would he know? How many people has he asked? We heard the honourable member for Bradfield talk about opinion polls. He talked about how everyone was in favour of the card and how they are now against it. The honourable member goes only by opinion polls as he has nothing between his ears. No one has talked about what the Government could do with the estimated $1,000m that the Australia Card will bring in and I remind honourable member that every estimate we have made has been conservative. Let us look at some of the things we could do if we brought in the Australia Card and our projections were right.
—Are you sure you're right?

—I am sure I am right because I check the facts, unlike the honourable member. If we chose to, we could reduce the top marginal tax rate from 49c to 40c. We could wipe out the top tax rate and still have $200m left over. The Opposition went to the people in the last election campaign with its sham tax policy of 38c. With the Australia Card we could get the tax rate down to 40c and have $200m left over. If we chose to, we could give pensioners an increase of $8.50 a week. If we had the Australia Card we could increase the age pension, invalid pension, sheltered employment allowance, rehabilitation allowance, widows pension, supporting parent's benefit, unemployment benefit, sickness benefits and special benefits, by $8.50 a week. Honourable members opposite never mentioned that in the community when they were collecting signatures on their petitions and when they paraded before the television cameras as the born again civil libertarians. Honourable members opposite do not tell people that we could fund another 100,000 places in higher education. I will tell them. We could have a combination of those things; I will not be prescriptive about it.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government takes its responsibilities seriously. We do not go to water when the going gets tough. When there is a bit of heat in the community what do members of the Opposition do? They buckle. They race around getting signatures on petitions because they think that will do them some good. They did that with the fringe benefits tax (FBT) and the assets test. What happened? The people do not want to know the Opposition. With all those things in and working, the people of Australia re-elected this Government with an increased majority. It just shows us what mugs members of the Opposition are. They have not learned. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said, what honourable members opposite ought to do-we know that they will not because they are too lazy-is get down to the hard work of coming up with policies. This debate shows what a sham the Opposition is. Members opposite have never come up with a constructive proposal.

I see that the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), is in the chamber. He will jump up next and he will speak again of doom and gloom. But one thing we will not hear from him is an alternative. Honourable members opposite are too lazy actually to sit down and work out a policy. Their path is the old sleazy one. The honourable member for Bradfield who spoke earlier put his finger on it. He said-this is the hope of the Liberal Party of Australia-that the card will take two to three years to introduce. Honourable members opposite hope that during the next election campaign the card will still be being implemented. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is nodding his head in agreement. Does the honourable member know why this is the hope of his Party? It is because honourable members opposite are too lazy to get into government the proper way. They want the old, sleazy way in. They are trying to mount the fear campaign that they mounted with the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Please yourself. You won't be back.

—Honourable members opposite said that I was going to be a oncer. I have been a twoser and I am now a threeser. I will be a fourser. Before the interjections from honourable members opposite I was saying that they want a sleazy way into government. They want to run a fear campaign at the next election because they think the Australian people are mugs. Honourable members opposite have always thought of the Australian people as mugs. In 2 1/2 years time the opinion of the people of Australia, whose instincts I trust, will be reflected in the sort of public opinion polls about which the honourable member for Bradfield spoke because their first instincts were right. Once we start telling the people of Australia the truth about the Australia Card they will start accepting it and honourable members will not get their sleazy way back into power; they will have to work hard for it and we know that they cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the fears in the community about the abuses of power that this card will somehow engender. As I have said before, the simple fact is that we will not collect any more information. The Treasury will still get the information that it has always received. One thing the Australia Card will do is to make sure that the information we are getting is accurate. That is where we will get tax cheats because only the tax cheats either do not give information or give incorrect information. The Australia Card will make sure that that information is correct but we will not collect any more information. The Treasury and the Department of Social Security will still collect the same amount of information. To listen to those opposite one would think that Australia was suddenly going to change overnight.

I have already said that the Australia Card will not provide the Government with any more information than it already collects. Honourable members opposite would do well to dwell on that and not go out in the community repeating the sort of stuff they have been repeating. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is a born again civil libertarian and there are born again civil libertarians in the Liberal Party. The Queensland Premier is a born again civil libertarian. Can honourable members imagine the Queensland Premier as a born again civil libertarian? He is the bloke who knocks down hotels in the middle of the night because someone might be concerned about them. He is the bloke who says that people cannot march in the streets if they want to protest. In Western Australia we have Bill Hassell, the born again civil libertarian, jumping up and opposing the Australia Card, yet when he was the Minister for Police he brought in the anti-assembly laws that stopped more than six people congregating in the streets of Perth. The civil libertarians are great!

Anybody who believes that the Liberal Party is mounting a campaign against the Australia Card to benefit the Australian population really does not know what he is talking about. As I have detailed before, every decent thing we have tried to put back into the taxation system the Opposition has opposed all the way down the line. I have read out the benefits that could accrue to people in the Australian community if we were to bring in the Australia Card. I know that there are some genuine concerns in the community. I know that all the people who oppose the card now do not do it for the same reasons that the Liberal Party does it. The Liberal Party's reason is pure political opportunism-nothing more. There are people in the community with genuine concerns about the card, about civil liberties and about privacy. This Government has gone to extraordinary lengths to make sure that those concerns are addressed. I think the Government's task now is to make sure that the misinformation campaign that is being put about the card is put right to make sure that the genuine concerns out in the Australian electorate are addressed and people are told the truth. The born-again civil libertarians who sneak out from behind a rock when they can sniff some political advantage to themselves do not prosper from the genuine concerns in the community.

I would just like to finish by reiterating that all the easy decisions of government have been made. If this country is to get back on its feet tough decisions have to be made. This Government has not gone against making tough decisions. We have seen the Opposition go to water in opposition. It would never do the tough things when in government. Many of the decisions it did not take have led Australia into the position it is in today. We are not concerned about the campaigns against the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the ending of business lunches and we are not put off by the campaign against the ID card. We know we are right and in the end the people of Australia will benefit because we have fought the good fight and won it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) has just recited for us a litany of why there should be no identity card. He referred to a number of proposals. Essentially he is suggesting that we ought to have an alternative. Although I really do not suggest that anybody should listen to the matter that he brought forward, he did say that no more information was going to be available for the production of the identity card than is already collected by the Government. I ask everybody who is interested in this subject to think about that. If the Government is already collecting the information that is now to be made available and if it is already available to the Australian Taxation Office and to every other arm of the bureaucracy, I ask: Why should the identity card be introduced? Of course, there is no answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal from the honourable member for Canning is that there really should be an alternative. Why does the Government need an alternative if the material has already been collected? He knows that there is far more to this identity card than meets the eye; he knows that it is a part of the ideological commitment of elements of the Labor Party. We know the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) who is nominally in charge of it-although under the new arrangements I do not think any of us are too sure of who is in charge of what-and first introduced the proposal well and truly set down for people to understand the circumstances of what he sees as the total irrelevancy of privacy. He set down the circumstances where he claims that social welfare fraud and tax evasion required the introduction of an identity card.

What I intended to do by speaking in this debate this afternoon were several things: First, I want everybody in the community and certainly in this Parliament to understand that as far as the National Party is concerned we are, have been and will be totally opposed to the concept that lies behind this particular piece of legislation. We have been opposed to it from the beginning. It is because of our opposition both here and in the other place that a premature double dissolution of the Parliament was called and because the Liberal and National parties voted in that way there has been now brought back, for the third time, in identical form, a piece of legislation which the Government is afraid to submit to the electorate by way of a referendum. The legislation runs quite contrary to the principles on which the National Party is based; it runs contrary to our concerns about the privacy of an individual; and, above all, after a Budget that fails abysmally in addressing the fundamental problems for ordinary Australians, it provides yet another intrusion into the circumstances of ordinary business operation and domestic operation.

We have heard about baby-sitters; we have heard about the problems there are in employing somebody to come in and help mow the lawns, do the garden and do all those chores. We have also heard in this place and in the public debate of the consequence and the penalties that are imposed. They are not minimal penalties; they are extraordinary penalties. Everyone needs to know that not only are the penalties monetary penalties; behind those monetary penalties is an order for them to be extracted from the poor, innocent citizen. There is an obligation of gaol if the person does not comply.
The circumstances we need to consider in this House are manifold: First, without any doubt, the Australian Labor Party is not united on the introduction and passage of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you believe it.

—I would not take the honourable member as speaking for the Labor Party. Secondly, I think we need to understand that within the community there has been already, both by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card and by a significant public scrutiny, a recognition that the Australia Card Bill and the identity card proposition do not achieve what the Government pretends they will. All this rubbish about trying to overcome tax evasion and social welfare fraud was initially laid to rest by the Joint Select Committee which, on its number, had Labor members who agreed with its conclusions which said that this particular package would not achieve what the Minister pretends. In other words, it is not a matter of identification of the individual which is the prime concern in trying to overcome tax evasion and social welfare fraud; it is ordinary administrative practices. Until the Government comprehends that there is, as indeed a few minutes ago the honourable member for Canning admitted, already available to the Government the information that the identity card will present, it will not get anywhere. It is no use collecting more information if the Government does not know what to do with what it has got now. That is what the whole thing is about. The Government should not go out and collect more and more bits of paper. That seems to be what it is all about. The Government wants to get that information in a different form. The form it will get it in is downright dangerous. The circumstances in which it wants to collect the information not only will be intrusive but also will very significantly disrupt the opportunity for ordinary individuals carrying on their ordinary way of life. I am afraid that until such time that this Government understands that unless it get its bureaucracy in order it will not be able to govern with the confidence of the people the worse off we will all be.
—That is why they voted for us.
—That is why the honourable member did not get a majority overall in numbers in the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a number of aspects of the legislation. Let me again assert that nobody on this side of the House and nobody in the National Party has supported, does support or will support the concept of an identity card proposal of the ilk of the one that has been submitted today.

There is no doubt that it is only now after the election that many people are coming to understand just how serious an intrusion these will be into civil liberties and privacy. We have heard some incredible responses. We have had Senator Susan Ryan come out and say, `Oh yes, but it is not going to go through the normal communication facilities; it will only go to some sort of especially allocated landline'. We heard a very interesting answer from the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) in the Parliament today on encryption devices. What the honourable gentleman obviously has failed to understand is that even this morning in the Australian we read of a number of West German hackers who were able to infiltrate probably what one would suspect to be the most secure information system that could be developed anywhere in the world. They, in fact, infiltrated the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) research system of the United States of America. They implanted their own programs which automatically gave them access to all of the work that the branches in the United States, Japan, France, West Germany, Britain and Switzerland have. I ask: If NASA is unable to secure its computer program on its transmission lines, what arrant nonsense it is for these people over here to say that somehow or other we will be able to keep sacrosanct Telecom lines. All of us on this side of the House know that one of the Government's former State colleagues is now incarcerated in the New South Wales prison system. One of the reasons he is there is because of the bugging of telephone lines.

We all know about the Age tapes and the fact that a former Premier and a few others in the Labor Party system should jolly well be before the courts for one reason or another as a result of other intervention in our telecommunications system. But in case the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support does not understand, could I suggest to him that international yachtsmen and multimillionaire, Ted Turner from Canada, made his original fortune in decoding encryption devices and selling copies to persons wishing to access pay television stations in the United States. What about all the absolute rubbish that Senator Susan Ryan comes out with when she says, `Oh, we are going to have a dedicated landline. Don't worry. Nobody will know about it.'? I have never heard such absolute rubbish in my life! We all know as she does if she is honest with herself that any information that is available through the computer interconnecting system can be both interceded and collected, and it can be automatically connected as we have seen with NASA in a way that must threaten the civil liberties and personal privacy of individuals.

I find it fascinating to look at the basic principles of the Australian Labor Party as they were enunciated at the thirty-seventh Federal Conference of the Labor Party in Hobart in 1986. Members of the Labor Party talk about the commitment by the Australian people to the creation of an independent, free and enlightened Australia. How does one get that if one introduces a table of every individual set down in a documented record and if there is a card to make people either a card carrying citizen or a non-citizen? The Labor Party is creating a circumstance whereby the Government will be able to determine whether a person is a citizen or not. The Government will have the right to issue or withdraw the card and if one does not have a card, one will be a non-citizen. The Labor Party talks about an independent, free and enlightened Australia. What poppycock! Well might the members of the Labor Left express their concern.

Let us look at when the card will have to be produced. A great deal has been said about this, but people should remember that financial institutions will not be able to open accounts, accept deposits or give withdrawals without the production of the card. State and Federal governments and companies will not be able to pay interest or repay loans without the card. Legal practitioners will not be able to accept money for making investments or loans on behalf of any person. Cash management trusts, property trusts and unit trusts cannot issue or buy back units, or pay income from them without the production of the card. Marketing authorities and produce agents cannot make payments for the proceeds of the sale of primary produce without production of the card. People will not be able to buy livestock over the phone in the manner that thousands of farmers and graziers have for generations without the production of the card. No one can buy or sell land without producing the card. Financial institutions will not be able to make safety deposit boxes available; share dealers will not be able to buy or sell shares on behalf of any person; futures brokers cannot deal in futures contracts without production of the card. Employers will not be able to pay a salary and payments will not be made under the prescribed payments system without production of the card. Medicare payments, payments to doctors and hospitals, treatments in hospitals and in nursing homes will not be possible without the production of the card. We already know that the card will not prevent tax evasion and social welfare fraud. Identity is not the problem. We know that it will have to be produced in a range of areas, and it will be deliberately intrusive on the rights of ordinary individuals. My friend the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) quite properly yesterday--

TALK.START.PARA: —A very well known name, too.

—Yes, a well known and redoubtable man with an electorate that takes the name of a distinguished colleague of mine. The honourable member is a good member at that. At Question Time yesterday, the honourable gentleman commented about child care treatment. How many people, in the conduct of their ordinary affairs, employ a baby-sitter so that they can go out for the night? That baby-sitter cannot be employed without the production of the card. If one employs a baby-sitter, a gardener or a guy to clean the windows, or if one carries out any ordinary transaction without requesting the production of a card, one will be liable to a penalty of up to $20,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Canning suggested that this was all a fear campaign. It is about time that a few people in the Australian community realised that it is the Government which has introduced the fear and the coalition which is trying to introduce realism. The sooner we understand that and these penalties are removed and the identity card concept is totally scrapped the better off we shall be.

The card will not achieve its aims. It will not help in removing tax avoidance or combating organised crime. It will not prevent illegal immigration or contain social security fraud, so why is it being introduced? It is all part of the great design to which the Labor Party seems to be committed of regimenting the Australian community more and more. It will intrude on civil liberties and privacy. A significant cross-section of Australians are opposed to the card. For example, Ben Lexcen says:
The Australia Card is an obscenity. It will destroy this country. If the government is allowed to get away with introducing it, I will turn in my citizenship and leave Australia.

A moment ago a member of the Labor Party interjected. He seems to think that if a person objects to the Australia Card that is a good reason for making that person a non-citizen. We have already heard the Minister for Community Services and Health talk about Australians as card subjects. It is about time that the Labor Party members tried treating individuals as individuals and recognising that even though a person's politics are not the same as theirs, he is just as good a person. If the honourable gentleman does not like Ben Lexcen, perhaps I can try him on Peter Garrett, who said:
The I.D. card is the greatest threat that Australia has ever faced. It will split the community and imperil democracy. It must be deposed.
Sir Noel Foley, former Chairman of the Westpac Banking Corporation, said:

The Australia Card, based on the most tolerant interpretation, is a clumsy, heavy-handed and expensive measure to ease the tasks of public servants in taxation and welfare departments . . . a serious threat to the privacy, liberty and safety of every citizen.
Dr Bruce Shepherd said:
I am appalled at the prospect of my country being under such awful control.
The Hon. Mr Justice Michael Kirby, President of the Court of Appeal, said:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society and the power and authority of the state in relation to the individual.
Greg Chappell said:
The I.D. Card will infringe the rights of individuals and should be rejected for the sake of democracy.

I find this fascinating. It does not matter that distinguished Australians oppose the card. It does not matter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the members of the Government that card subjects and calling people by numbers instead of by their names and instead of looking on them as citizens is an intrusion into their privacy. This arrogant, high-handed Government is taking an action which the Opposition and the National Party believe must be rejected.

The Government cannot give ironclad guarantees about the security of the system. Senator Susan Ryan's talk about somehow trying to encrypt the information and put in a dedicated landline we all know to be rubbish. We have not even considered the question of fraud. I am told that already it has been admitted that about 20,000 unofficially prepared duplicate Medicare cards are in circulation. We all know that forgery of currency has been rampant as long as currency has existed.

The card will require an enormous bureaucracy and will be a large financial cost to the community with some 2,000 more public servants. Throughout this exercise, the Prime Minister and the Government have ignored the fact that the costs of introduction to the individual will far outweigh the revenue gains. No one should be mistaken. The cost of approximately $700m or $1 billion-whichever we use-to the Government is not the only cost. There is the cost to the individual. We all know, interested as we are on this side of the House in small business, that the intrusion of bureaucracy makes life difficult. We know that the card will cost the private sector not only lost working time but administrative time and one could well expect that cost to be about twice that of the cost to the Government. That is $2 billion to the private sector and $1 billion to the Government. It will create inconvenience to the community and it will be particularly difficult for isolated people. Those of us who represent the far flung areas of Australia, like the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and others in the National Party, know that their constituents will find this extraordinarily difficult. They have to rely on the telephone. They have to ring up to get business. What do they do if they want to ring up to order a few things from the store or get things sent out from the wool broker in town? How will they produce their cards? The whole thing is ridiculous.

As for the aged, the disadvantaged and the handicapped, they will find it almost impossible to carry on their normal lives. People will have to carry the card all the time and they will not be able to go about their ordinary business. The punitive provisions are ridiculous. If one loses one's card and fails to report it, one can be fined $500. I have not worked out who will be responsible if somebody undertakes negotiations on one's behalf before one is able to find it. Failure to produce the card at the Tax Office on demand can result in a fine of up to $20,000 for an individual or $100,000 for a company. The Government has estimated the cost as $700m. I think that is an underestimation to a considerable degree.

Another furphy in the deal was pointed out by Mr Roger Clark, Reader in Information Systems at the Australian National University, who has said that the legislation will cost private enterprise $636m over 10 years, and we all know that lost work time and costs to the banking industry will add significantly to total costs. Behind all that are other questions. Will there be some special list? I know the Government has said there will not be one and has denied reports at the weekend that some special category will be developed. What I find quite fascinating is that nobody has denied that a report has been prepared by an officer of one of the government departments, which reveals that other changes are involved. Mr K. J. Hazell of the Health Insurance Commission has talked about procedures without the need for any notification to the card subject.

We on this side of the House believe that the card should be scrapped. If it is not scrapped, at least there should be a referendum. I commend to everybody the announcement that was initially made on 10 August by my colleague Senator Ron Boswell, when the first proposal for a referendum on the identity card was advanced. If the Government will not go to a referendum, the best thing it could do is look at the consequences for individual liberties, look at its own platform and recognise that in every respect the identity card goes against what all of us in Australia believe should be the free rights of every citizen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great honour to follow in this debate the great civil libertarian in this chamber, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). His strong stand on the affirmative action legislation and the human rights legislation--

—As my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur says, it will be long remembered throughout Australia. So it is a great honour to follow that great civil libertarian. They will be the people who will be caught. The ordinary, honest Australian citizen will have a card.

SPEECH.PARA: We also heard about the terrible infringement of civil liberties when people are involved in financial transactions. The right honourable member for New England did not say that the card will also mean that such people, for the first time in their lives, will be paying their fair share of tax, which for too long they have avoided paying. Those opposite looked for an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —They sure found one.

—They thought they had found an issue. They got such a drubbing that they had to do something to try to gen up their spirits. So they started this campaign about the Australia Card. SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting that the person who is running the campaign against the Australia Card in the southern highlands happens to be a guy called Forrester, who happens to be the strongly defeated Liberal candidate for Macarthur. If members of the Small Business Association were concerned with small business and its problems instead of other campaigns, small business might do quite a lot better. SPEECH.PARA: The election was fought on this issue, yet the Opposition says that the Government does not have a mandate. Let me assure the Opposition that it does. In my electorate of Throsby this was a major issue. I put out more statements on the Australia Card than on any other issue. I put out numerous Press releases. I attended numerous meetings and I debated the issue all the time. The Liberal candidate in my area avoided the issue, as did the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). I am sorry that he is not in the chamber. Now the honourable member is sending out petitions from his office. I remember that some two years ago the honourable member for Gilmore ran around challenging me to state where I stood on the Australia Card. When the right honourable member for New England said that National Party members had opposed the Australia Card from the word go, he was incorrect. The honourable member for Gilmore came out very strongly in support of it, as did the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). A whole litany of honourable members opposite supported it. The honourable member for Gilmore was very vocal in supporting it and in challenging me to state where I stood. I stated where I stood. We have heard a lot in this chamber today about civil liberties. The National Party has learnt a few new words today-encryption, hackers and so on. In Queensland there was a meeting at which people spoke about civil liberties. What a place to talk about civil liberties! They have been protected in Queensland for a long time, have they not? The cheek and audacity of people standing there talking about the Government's measure, which will cut out fraud and rorts in the system, as being a threat to civil liberties really makes one wonder. It is almost as ludicrous as what is happening in Queensland now. Some members of the Queensland police force are being investigated for corruption and sexual activities and yet at the same time the other half of the force is ripping out condom vending machines from universities so as to protect the morality of the young. We have a strange system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ryan would support you on your views and on relations with the Queensland Government.

—Far be it from me to cast aspersions on any member of this chamber. I have no doubt that honourable members opposite will run a great campaign against the Australia Card. I remember that the same stories were used about the affirmative action legislation. I received letters from women saying that they did not want to work in a road gang. It was said in this chamber that suckling children would be taken from their mother's breasts and put into creches. I received many crazy letters. A group came to see me one day saying, `Mr Hollis, please protect the little babies'. We have had affirmative action legislation now for two years and civilisation has not stopped.
