SPEECH.PARA: From the way the Opposition talks one would think that people open a bank account every day. One does not open a bank account every day unless one has something to hide. One does not get a new job every day. The Opposition asks what will happen if a person loses the card. I was interviewed on Bowral radio the other day and the interviewer asked me, `What would happen if a dog ate my card and I wanted to get a job?' I said, `Are you in the habit of feeding your dogs your plastic cards?' If a person is crazy enough to give his dog a card and the dog is crazy enough to eat it, I think that he should be examined. Nevertheless, if a person is stupid enough to feed his card to a dog and the dog eats it, the person does exactly the same as if he had given his dog a credit card and the dog had eaten his credit card; he applies for a new one. It is no great deal if one loses a credit card.

I have carried credit cards and a drivers licence around for many years. I have never lost a drivers licence or a credit card. One would think that people in this country lose their cards all the time. Most people are responsible enough to look after their credit cards and their Medicare card. It will be the same with the Australia Card. People will not feed it to their dogs. I am sure that the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) does not feed his credit cards to his dogs and he will not feed his Australia Card to them. If he does, or if he loses his card, he will be able to apply for a new one and get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you fail to report it within three weeks--
—Has the honourable member for O'Connor ever lost his Medicare card or a credit card? I bet he has more credit cards than I have.
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.
—I don't get fined if I don't report it for three weeks.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—He will not get fined. We have heard a lot about holding a referendum on the issue. We held a referendum just two months ago and we got an overwhelming majority. The referendum was called a general election. I invite honourable members opposite to look at our policy speech which was delivered at the Sydney Opera House so magnificently. We said in our policy speech that when we were returned to government we would re-introduce the Australia Card legislation. I invite honourable members to look at the leaflets which the honourable member for Macarthur, the honourable member for Grey and the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) put out in their electorates. The leaflets all said that we would re-introduce the Australia Card legislation. We have a mandate from the people of Australia to introduce the legislation. We have introduced it and it will be passed quickly. If honourable members opposite want to continue blocking it in the other place that is their concern. If they want to continue protecting those who have rorted the system for far too long I suggest that they explain to the Australian people why they would do so.

SPEECH.PARA: There are far too many honest people in this country who have no way of avoiding the tax that they pay. We all agree that taxation is too high and we would like to reduce it. This is one measure in that direction. I pay over half of my salary in tax. If we have to pay a high amount of tax we would much rather see it going to the more disadvantaged in the community or being spent on roads, hospitals and so on.

Finally, I heard many scare stories around this chamber when we brought in the fringe benefits tax. There were predictions of what would happen, how many businesses would be thrown out of business, how many jobs would be lost and so on. We learnt from the Budget Speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night what he and this Government could do for the more disadvantaged in our community. We can do that only because for the first time since we took over in 1983-we inherited a dreadful fiscal mess from the Fraser-Howard years-we have been able to restore equity to the taxation system. We have restored equity by ensuring that all pay their correct share of taxation. Last night we saw one of the benefits of that. We saw how we could give money to the more disadvantaged, the more deserving in this community. That is the reason, if no other, why I support the legislation so strongly. Obviously, we will reject the Opposition's foreshadowed amendment. I strongly support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am constantly amazed at the Government's arguments to defend the intrusion of the Australia Card on the individuals of Australia. None of the speakers in this debate have addressed themselves to the plight of the ordinary citizen who runs his own business-who has to fund and run his own accounts-who is already heavily bogged down with a vast array of government paper to fill in for what is euphemistically called in the bureaucracy `compliance costs'. What a wonderful term! There are so many forms today that people who are involved in business have to fill in. In particular I refer to small businesses which do not have in-house accountants; the boss has to fill in the forms at night. The average small business employing less than ten people is involved in very heavy additional cost.

SPEECH.PARA: All of a sudden we are to have the identity card. We must ask the basic question: why is it so important to have an ID card? Why has the Government introduced this objectionable legislation? The reason is that the Government has been sold this idea by the Public Service. I well recall on many occasions when in government in the past that the Public Service would come to me with the proposition, `Look Minister, we are in a difficult position. Give us the discretion and we will not worry you about it'. Honourable members know that that is the way it is, and that proposition was put to us by the Commissioner of Taxation. He said, `Give us the discretion and you will have no need to worry about it'. What a way to opt out! The ID card approach is no more and no less than an extension of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Sir Humphrey special.

—Indeed. It is the Public Service that has called on the ID card. Not only does it want a little discretion; in addition, because of the sheer mismanagement within the Taxation Office-and other areas-it wants more figures in order to carry through the job which it ought to have been doing in the first place. Because of that we have to brand a number on every Australian citizen. That is not the way that members of the Australian Labor Party necessarily want. I venture to say that it is not the way that the majority of members of the Australian Labor Party want. However, members of the Government have been sold this job by the Public Service in order for it to extend its power and its ability to control the collection of funds in this nation and, ultimately, the spending of that money within the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The politicians of the day have walked away and said: `Yes, we will go down that track'. They bought the soft option put to them by the Public Service in relation to how this matter should be handled. It makes me cringe to think of how the Government of the day could have been sold that one. However, I am convinced that that is what happened because not one speaker so far has been able adequately to answer to my satisfaction the question why the Australia Card is necessary, except to use that catchcry of its being necessary to stop the cheats and the rorts. In my estimation those cheats and rorts ought to have been caught up with by any reasonably managed department. I am not saying something now which I did not say to my department head many years ago. The proposed numbering system which has resulted from the neglect of basic management skills is to be forced on to the individuals of Australia at the behest of the Public Service.

What do the people out in the community think of all this? I am not talking about the people who live in Canberra or the people who live at the end of a dedicated telephone line-which is the greatest lot of nonsense I have heard in my life. The other day a journalist who works for a television channel told me of these dedicated telephone lines. Secure? He said that quite frequently they get another channel on their dedicated line. These are dedicated lines which are supposed to have great security. What a lot of nonsense.

On top of that intrusion on the individual what else is the individual to get? The individual does not want an identity card. Identity cards were rejected immediately after the war. Not one citizen in my electorate has said to me: `Look John, we really all ought to have a number. I have enough numbers now but give us another one'. I have no demand in my electorate for that and there is no demand in the electorates of Wide Bay or O'Connor for that. There is, however, a demand in the electorates of Australia for less government, fewer forms, lower business costs and fewer regulations to comply with so that the individual can get on with his or her life and make of it what he or she would want.

I do not believe for a moment that the Australian Labor Party which was established to defend the individual and to represent people in the work force would want to see the people who form part of its genuine base numbered, directed and intruded on in this manner. I am quite sure that the majority of the Government members and members of the Labor Party's rank and file would be as utterly opposed to this as I am. Because of that the Opposition is supporting a proposal for a referendum to give the citizens of Australia a fair go. It is not, as a previous speaker said, a principle that was enunciated in a great policy speech in Sydney. What a great day that was for ordinary citizens! The modern day pharoah boats across Sydney Harbour to pronounce to the masses. I did not hear too much about an ID card that day as we watched the admiralty barge.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not listening.

—I ask the honourable member whether he was asked to cross on the admiralty barge as a representative of the workers. I bet that the people in the honourable member's electorate were very pleased that the modern pharoah was on the admiralty barge sailing across to the great Opera House. That has a lot to do with the ordinary members of the Australian Labor Party today. It is because the Government is so out of touch with them--
—We got re-elected.

—We scored more votes. Even in Queensland we know that more votes do not necessarily get one government. However, as I said, honourable members opposite became the government. To suggest that the matter was well aired as an issue in the last Federal election is a nonsense. Ordinary citizens ought to be given a say in relation to this matter through a referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the cost of the Australia Card to the ordinary citizen and to business. The proposals in relation to this are quite significant and, I think, will create an enormous cost to business. I quote from an article which states:

Given the rather ad hoc manner in which the idea rose during the second quarter of 1985 it is only to be expected that the significant cost elements would have been overlooked by the early estimates. From an initial seven year estimate of $380m by July 1985 the Government's estimate in December stood at $820m-comprising $127m establishment cost; operational cost of $100m per annum-

That is quite a figure. As we sit here and wonder at the cost of the new Parliament House, let us remember that the cost to government of setting up the Australia Card is in the same order. The article continued:
An ID card for everybody--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Those figures are right. They come from a Government source. The figures that I have cited here are identical to the figures provided by the Government's business review committee. That is a committee set up by the Government not so long ago to look at government regulation. I will come to that matter later. In view of those figures it can be seen that the ID card and the new Parliament House are costed at the same figure. As the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) knows better than I, those sorts of expenditures certainly are not acceptable to the ordinary citizen. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Some very significant cost elements have been entirely omitted from the official estimates. It is proposed that the integrity of identity would depend heavily on State registrars of births and deaths. Few of these are computerised and even fewer have captured retrospectively the birth details of the whole of the present population. To fulfil the Federal Government's needs the States would need funding support. In addition, a companion system to identify entitlees has been announced, but not costed. This would involve yet more bureaucratic registration, requirements to companies, trusts, partnerships, co-operatives, associations, business names and other legal persons.

We can see that that cost, which is not in the official Government costing, would run into many millions of dollars. We all know that that would only be with the compliance and co-operation of the State governments. We already have a clear indication from Queensland that it will not co-operate. So the cost of these State registers, which are absolutely integral to the ID card, will run into many more millions than have already been specified.

I turn now to costs to the private sector, because that is the area in which a lot of the proposal falls down. The Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit-the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) will be interested in this-a body set up by this Government to look at regulation, reported to the Government. I challenge the Government to table the report in Parliament so we can all see its contents. The truck drivers association has informed me that one item in the report says that the cost to the Government will be $1 billion, which I have previously stated and which is agreed to by the Government's own unit, but that whatever it costs the Government it will cost private enterprise ten times more in compliance costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—Compliance costs will be ten times more. That is the Government's body that has said that, a unit set up by the Labor Party Government.
—It should produce the report.
—Yes, it should produce the report because that is what is in it. So the business sector of Australia will be called upon to contribute $10 billion towards the establishment of this ID card system.

SPEECH.PARA: This will have to be paid for by our business sectors, and I turn first to big business. We have already seen what the Australian Bankers Association has said about it. The impost on bankers will be $100m. Honourable members opposite can take that matter up if they do not believe me. Honourable members should not think for a moment that those institutions will not pass that on to the users of their accounts. Of course they will, all around the country. This will also affect other major companies. I have cited the banks because these days they play an integral part in our whole financial operation. I am surprised when I walk down the street these days at the number of people who use banks compared to 10 years ago. Because of that the cost to big business in this area will be substantial. But big business can look after itself; after all, I have noticed around here that the Government and big business have a very close and mutually beneficial association. The parties involved and so forth are well identified.

Let me identify now with small business, and the people who really do have to carry their own concerns. These are the people who run the smaller businesses that are required under this legislation to meet these costs. I do not refer to the ordinary citizens of Australia or the Australia Card subjects, as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) called them yesterday in Parliament. The individual has gone out the window; we are now down to these more computerised names which I am sure Australians will enjoy.

Let us assume one is dealing with a stock and station agent, most of which are in the country. Such agents do not run a big organisation. A farmer may wish to sell Daisy and three or four other cows, or the honourable member for O'Connor, for example, may have to catch his horse. Because they cannot ring the agent they must take their ID cards to town to sell their stock. The organisation involved does not run to accountants but this legislation will require it to establish more of the compliance procedures or face substantial fines. Ultimately the cost of that is not borne by the Government; it is borne by the taxpayer. It is part of the multiple of 10 indicated by the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit.

In these days of rising stock markets the number of people involved with brokers is quite significant. To think that a stockbroking business can be run without the substantial use of telephones is to deny the obvious. As an old broker I can tell honourable members that something like 95 per cent of a stockbroker's business is done on the phone. In the quickly moving and dynamic stockmarket one cannot check people's identity when handling every transaction, except at considerable cost to one's own company. I can speak from experience in this area. To comply with this one would need to have, depending on the size of the firm, at least another accountant per 100 clients to keep tabs, and this is an industry which is already completely sucked down by the scrip overhang or overload within the market.

I go on to the ordinary store, with which the Minister said yesterday he had no problems at all. When he answered a question he accepted the assumption that there would be forged identity cards. His answer implied that. If he accepts that there will be forged identity cards, what are we doing with the system? The guy in the corner shop who runs a very small staff will be required to go through this whole identification process, at quite enormous cost to him. It is people such as this who will bear the grudge, the hurt and the cost of this identification process.

While on the very real concerns of the small operators of Australia I turn to some of our far flung operations, to people who are employed in the bush, on cattle stations and the like. How on earth does the Government think the identity card system will operate in those areas? The communications are not good. They may have a slow mail service and bush telephone services are not great at the best of times, so as a consequence the burden on the individual is enormous.

I have referred to the commercial operators, but the ordinary individual who has enough trouble dealing with his own personal financial matters now has to line himself up with this procedure. He will have to have a card and take it with him when he carries out commercial transactions, for example at a stock and station agent's or at the bank. He will have to queue up and get his name in the book and go on with all that sort of nonsense. The people of Australia will not thank the Government for that. The ordinary citizens of Australia are honest people. The ID card will not impinge on the dishonest. They will find their own way around it. That was admitted by the Minister yesterday when he accepted that there would be forgeries. As a consequence, I find the Government's whole approach to the ID card to be irrelevant. It will be introduced at a huge cost to business, be it big or small, and will be a massive intrusion into the privacy of the individual citizens of Australia. I am convinced that members of the Australian Labor Party, given a go, would say exactly the same thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we come to vote on the Australia Card Bill I will be crossing the floor to vote with the Government. That will occur because on 11 July, for the first time, the Government's numbers swelled so much that it is necessary in this place for Government members to sit where traditionally Opposition members have sat. It is the case that so overwhelming was the mandate given by the Australian people on 11 July for this legislation that our numbers increased to such a level.

SPEECH.PARA: We will find, of course, that many on the Opposition side will say that it was not their fault that they lost the election. When the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) opened the batting for the Opposition on this legislation he said that it was not the Liberal Party's fault but in fact the fault of the media that this issue did not surface during the election campaign. He seized upon the old loser's lament: if at first one cannot succeed then fix the blame. He suggested that this legislation would be terribly inconvenient. I question to whom it might be inconvenient: to those who are at present cheating on the welfare or taxation system in this country. I refer to the comments of Mr Greiner, the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, when the legislation was first proposed in 1985. He said: `The identity card is in the interests of the community. Only people who are acting dishonestly have anything to fear'.

The honourable member for O'Connor also suggested that those who wanted to would very simply forge alternative identity cards and therefore wreak havoc in the system. It is much easier to forge currency than an identity card. That being so, I cannot understand why those people who are so clever and so able to do so are not in the business of forging currency at the moment.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) suggested that the massive impost of compliance costs would be so great that businesses would be falling all around our feet if the card were implemented. In the previous debate on this legislation the compliance figure was suggested as being twice the Government estimate. Now the Opposition has added a factor of five and it is suggested that the cost will be ten times the Government's estimate.

Every time we debate such issues in the House and the Opposition is struggling for an issue it suggests that the penalties are draconian. If I fail to fill in a Medicare form correctly I can be fined $50,000. Not many doctors are worried about that penalty because doctors know that they will be liable to such a penalty only if they try dishonestly to defraud the system. If I am caught driving my car too fast, with a high blood alcohol level or without a licence I can be put in prison. But nobody objects to having a drivers licence number or a registration number on his car to drive on the road. It is the old story of the Opposition trying to inject fear into the debate and trying to draw a red herring across the path.

The highlight of the speech of the honourable member for O'Connor, as we have heard so many times before, is that the solution to the social security problem is making people work for the dole. He said, `Australians are not energetic enough to turn up for jobs'. He suggested that we make people work for the dole and allow illegal immigrants to work as much as they like and do their best. If that is the honourable member's answer to the problem I have great difficulty in agreeing with his point of view.

I have been a member of parliament for a few years now-not as long as some others-but I have never before heard such gross misrepresentation, such hyperbole and hysteria. I have never before heard such deception and such fear and ignorance. I understand that the Opposition seldom likes to hear clear logic or reason in debates. It has never allowed public interest to come before political opportunism in a debate in this place. I remember early in my time here having some respect for the position of the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) with respect to the assets test. I believe his view on the assets test was motivated by economic rationale. We never heard him speak against it. It was only when he became Leader of the Opposition that he did a back flip and suddenly changed his economically rational stance.

We have heard the hard luck stories. Unfortunately I am getting them every day in my office. I spoke to a pensioner who called me the other day. He said, `Bill Hassell told me and I heard on the radio that I would not be able to go down the road unless I had my identity card with me'. It is not necessary for one to take the identity card everywhere. It is suggested that one cannot live without it. I asked the pensioner, `When was the last time that you applied for a job?'. He said, `Well, 40 years ago was the last time I applied for a job'. I asked, `When was the last time you opened a bank account?'. He said, `I have not opened a bank account for 20 years'. I asked, `When was the last time you bought shares or transferred money overseas?. He said to me, `I have never done that'. I then asked the pensioner, `How are you going to be required to use your card every day for everyday purposes?'. He had heard the misunderstanding and misrepresentations and unfortunately had believed them.

Why do we require an identity card? We need to recognise that over the last 50 or 100 years there have been significant changes in the world. There has been a transportation explosion. Up to 50 years ago people did not get into aeroplanes to fly across the world or across the country. They did not drive the great distances they do now. They did not travel the great distances they now travel by train. They did not have the opportunity to be mobile that they have now. There was much more stability. Indeed, people lived in smaller environments, smaller towns and suburbs. Even in the growing cities there were more cohesive local suburbs. Most business was transacted by people with others that they knew. It is only over the last 50 years that the majority of our commercial and other transactions have become anonymous. So increasingly there has come a need to identify people accurately. American Express, Bankcard, Visa, et cetera, are in the business of providing reliable identification for commercial purposes. Increasingly we accept the need to use those methods of identification. More than nine million Australians have already provided substantial information to those private organisations for identification for commercial purposes. No longer are we transacting business every day with people we know; that is the exception rather than the rule. It is therefore reasonable that a government-and this Government-when it collects money from its taxpayers and citizens and when it pays out benefits and entitlements to its citizens should make sure that people are accurately identified.

The identification system in the United States of America developed in the 1930s following the Great Depression. It developed because for the first time the Government became responsible for paying public relief and public insurance-social security insurance, dependent children's aid, assistance for the unemployed, the disabled, the aged and veterans. Suddenly the Government was in the business of supporting people in need and it was necessary for it accurately to define those people and therefore identify them. That is the origin of the social security number in the United States. It became necessary to increase the accuracy of identification of people to make sure that payments were made to those who deserved them. It is perfectly reasonable that this Government-any government in this country or in any Western country-should want to make sure that it collects its due amount of money and pays out to those who deserve it what they are entitled to.

All the legislation we discuss in this place balances the community interest against that of the individual. If I suggested that we intended to set up an organisation to search people every time they get on public transport people would reel in shock and horror. But that is what happens. If one goes to board a plane at Tullamarine Airport one has to be searched beforehand. This is because the public interest is served by people being shown to be not carrying a weapon. We realise that there is a fear of hijacking in Australia and therefore legislation enabling such procedures is acceptable. We legislate in this country about speed limits, how much alcohol a car driver may have in his blood, whether one wears a seat belt and all those things which are intrusions on individuals' rights. We accept those intrusions because we believe the community interest is served by them.

Likewise, when one comes to this country one cannot barge through and refuse to identify oneself. One has to establish that one has a right to be in Australia; one has a valid visa or passport. In the same way, one can be searched by the Customs officer because one might be carrying drugs, wildlife, animal products or something that could be detrimental to the community interest. We accept all of those things. I find it very difficult to say, `Okay, you have to do all of that, but when it comes to paying your fair share of tax or receiving your entitlement, you can be anonymous'. I have great difficulty accepting that argument.

Members of the Opposition are carrying on about privacy. They are all concerned about privacy. We have not heard about it before, but suddenly they are concerned about privacy. The Data Protection Agency that will be set up-and the privacy legislation that complements this legislation-for the first time extends the security and protection from abuses to the private sector. We have been concerned about it. What about all of the legislation and all of the things that happened regarding social security and maybe taxation? Nobody on the other side has said, `What about privacy?'. But for the first time we have legislation that starts to set out principles of privacy and we are starting to provide some principles of privacy within the private sector. I believe it should be supported.

I do not accept that there is a right to remain anonymous if people want to enjoy the benefits of our collective community. If they want to drive on our roads, send their kids to schools and use our hospitals-all of the facilities that are provided by taxpaying Australians-I do not believe there is some sacred right to refuse to identify themselves when they are engaging in transactions which can affect their income tax liability, social security entitlement, residential entitlement or Medicare entitlement. All of those things require identification. I do not believe that we should be entitled to be anonymous on those occasions. Just as a person who is speeding or driving dangerously and does not have a licence can be fined and put in gaol, perhaps it is reasonable that he or she can be fined in other circumstances. The drug smuggler has no right to carry his heroin past the Customs officer and sell it in the community; nor should there be a right for those who want to defraud the tax system, those illegal immigrants who want to work and not pay tax, and those who want to receive entitlements to which they are not entitled.

I will have no difficulty, when we vote on this legislation, in supporting the Government. I wholeheartedly support this legislation and I hope very earnestly that members of the Opposition can put aside their political opportunism and see that in this legislation we have a further opportunity to increase the fairness of our system and to provide a more equitable and efficient system of governing Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) concluded his contribution to this debate by exhorting the Opposition to put aside political opportunism and asking the Opposition to support the Government in a bipartisan fashion on this measure. One of the reasons that I have entered this debate as it draws to a close is that the Government, in the course of pushing its own argument on the ID card, has once again, as it so often does on any matter of controversy, resorted to what we all understand to be the Goebbels technique-that is, if one says something that is untrue frequently enough, sooner or later the public will start to believe it. That is what the Government has been doing on every single public issue of any controversy. The ID card issue has been no exception.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the elements of the Goebbels technique in the ID card debate is for the Government to allege that I support the proposal privately and that some of my colleagues support it privately. I want to spend a few moments dealing with that canard because it deserves to be rebutted. It is part of a systematic attempt by the Government to deceive the public. The basis is a comment I made in an interview on the Sunday program on 15 September 1985. In many ways I like and respect my colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), but I am sorry to say that he has fallen into the error of doing what his colleagues the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) do by second nature. I am sorry that he has learnt the bad habit. What he does is to give half the quotation. I was asked:
We've heard a lot about your views on economic policy. Can we just get your opinions on some current social issues, Mr Howard . . . where do you stand on the proposed ID card?
This was my answer:

I personally see some merit in having an I.D. card, providing the civil liberties concerns that people have voiced can be looked after and provided the Government can satisfy the community that there is some cost benefit in it.
That was the basis of my approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair enough.

—My colleague the honourable member for Wakefield says that that was fair enough. That was the foundation of our approach to the Parliament. When the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) moved a motion to send the matter to a committee, he said that we may be persuaded to support the proposal if we can be satisfied on two or three elements. Two of those elements were the elements that were laid down in that interview. That was the whole basis of our approach, and I have never deviated from it. I say to the House that any suggestion that I harbour some kind of covert support for this proposal, and that some of my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties harbour it, is absolute nonsense. We have been consistent. We, almost alone with the Australian Democrats-I do not normally heap any kind of accolade on them-in 1986 came out against this proposal. If we had wanted to be politically opportunistic, the smart money in late 1986 was on this measure being passed. If ever the media of Australia have conspired with the Government to induce a sense of complacency about something in the Australian community, it has been in relation to the ID card.
—The media again!

—Yes, I will have a go at members of the media on this issue, because not only were they negligent in getting into bed with the Government on this issue late in 1986, but now some of them, in their unctuous manner, have turned around and said, `If only the Opposition had said more about the ID card, we would have been spared all the attendant horrors'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. Let us go back to June 1986-15 months ago. The Australian, in an editorial, labelled coalition opposition to the Australia Card as `ill advised as there seem to be few defensible grounds for such opposition'. The Courier-Mail of 4 June 1986 stated:
The Australia Card is a fair and sensible method of saving social security benefits and preventing tax fraud.
That was the good old Courier-Mail. On 5 June 1986 the Australian claimed:
. . . a national identity card will go a long way towards ensuring that the cheats are stopped. The Opposition and the Democrats should support the legislation.
The Sydney Morning Herald, in criticising the coalition's opposition, stated:
. . . the Government deserves the benefit of the doubt. The Senate should pass the legislation and let the voters deal with the Government . . .

And so it goes on. Mention was made of it on 12 November in the Australian, after we had announced our opposition to the final form of the legislation and our intention to vote against it. That decision was almost universally condemned by every major media outlet and media commentator in Australia. Yet they are now falling over themselves to line up against the card. In the process they are trying to blame the Liberal and National parties for not having argued more strongly against it. The reality is that they were part of a conspiracy of silence about the ill effects of this card. They did the Government's bidding as far as the dubious benefits of this card are concerned. They carry a very heavy share of the responsibility for a very latent arousal within the Australian community of the concerns that now abound about this legislation. They do not have those concerns.

The only people who have been consistent on this ID card issue are those who have said from the word go, `We will only accept an ID card if you can discharge the responsibilities on privacy, on protection of the individual, on cost benefit and the other criteria that were laid down when we sent it off to a parliamentary committee'. We, on this side of the House, have been utterly consistent on that. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card and one of the Government's own colleagues from Victoria came out against the proposal. Honourable members opposite know the depth of feeling in their own ranks. They know what the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) thinks about this. The Prime Minister, in his post-election mode of getting swept off his feet, was running around saying that anybody who was against the ID card was a friend of the tax cheat-the Goebbels technique working overtime.

We have all done a bit of research about attitudes on ID cards. It may surprise the Prime Minister to know that two of his great Labor Party heroes, Ben Chifley and John Curtin, railed in the late 1930s, even under the exigencies of war time, against the concept of an ID card. Yet this Leader of the Labor Party now runs around and says, `Anybody who is opposed to the ID card is a friend of the tax cheats'. That is what the Prime Minister said. In 1939 Curtin said:

It appears to be a little absurd for us to be asking the people of this country to defend democracy in remote parts of the world while at the same time we seek to sacrifice some of the fundamental principles of democracy here at home in the process.

Those are the words of a man whose memory the present Prime Minister is pleased to invoke. Was he speaking as a friend of the tax avoidance industry? If honourable members opposite really want to find out how much impact this ID card will have on fraud and white collar crime they should listen to what members of the Australian Federal Police say about it. The Australian Federal Police, who have the heavy burden of trying to do something about white collar crime in this country, are very sceptical about the benefits. They say that if they were provided with more resources they could do something about the $4 billion, $6 billion, $8 billion or $9 billion of undetected fraud that goes on every year under the present Government. Honourable members should listen to what Frank Costigan had to say about it and they should listen to the great gaggle of arch conservatives they are talking about; people such as Garrett and Michael Kirby-I should say Justice Kirby but one should not talk about the political inclination of somebody on the bench. I do not think we could describe him-I know him very well and I quite like him-as an arch conservative and a running dog of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. The list is almost endless.

Honourable members opposite have to understand that this is one of those issues where public anger and concern have been slow in being roused. I repeat that part of it was a glib acceptance by large elements of the media of this country at an editorial and a commentator level-I make no bones about saying that at all-and, as a consequence, there was a false sense of security within the community.

The proposal has now been understood for what it is. It is a major invasion of individual privacy. It will involve the recruitment of an additional 2,000 public servants. It will impose unacceptably large additional costs on business operations. It will concern and worry a large number of elderly citizens in Australia. But, more importantly, it proceeds upon two fundamentally flawed assumptions. The first of those assumptions is that if a bureaucratic process is not working properly, instead of finding out why it is not working properly we should go along to the government of the day and if it is gullible enough we get another bureaucracy out of it in order to cure that part of the bureaucracy that is not already working. That is a technique that public services all over the world have employed. Some governments are gullible enough to be fooled by that. When we were in government in the late 1970s this proposal was looked at--

TALK.START.PARA: —You looked at it.

—Yes, of course it was looked at and I was open-minded enough to support its being examined. We sent a working party to the United States of America to look at the operation of systems in North America. That working party came back here and said: `Forget about it. It will be in the hands of the Mafia within a few months'. That is what has happened in the United States and in North America. Given the failure of this Government's brother governments, particularly in New South Wales, to deal with organised crime we can be certain that--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have struck a very tender nerve on the Government side. The failure of the Wran and Unsworth governments to deal with organised crime will guarantee that it will occur in this country. Well may Government members react. We were told in the late 1970s-and it stands true today-that there was a capacity for fraud and abuse of the systems in the hands of criminal elements. It is not just the view of that party; it is the view that has been expressed by the Australian Federal Police and many other organisations associated with law enforcement in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not speaking from a position of conservative, blind opposition to some kind of proper surveillance system. On each and every occasion it is a question of balancing the public interest against the private right. But, unlike the Australian Labor Party, I start from the assumption that the private right is superior to the right of the state. That must always be the starting assumption. Anybody who seeks to erode the private right must carry the onus of proving that there is an overwhelming public benefit in that private right being eroded. It is just not good enough, as this proposal assumes, to say to a government, `We have a problem. We cannot collect enough tax', or `We cannot stop enough welfare cheating'. In other words, to use what will become a memorable phrase of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), we have a systems failure under the present system so we have to turn everybody into a card subject to deal with that systems failure.

Basically, that is what the Government is doing with this proposal. It has not really discharged the onus of proving that there is a superior public claim to justify the erosion of the private right. It has not discharged that obligation and until it discharges it by satisfying the Australian public on privacy grounds and on cost benefit grounds-it is a long way short on both of those-it will not put a glove on the cash economy. No serious student of the taxation system of this country could fairly argue that this proposal will even touch the sides of the cash economy. If Government members are talking about eliminating taxation fraud they have to do something about the cash economy. This does not even get into the same playing field as the cash economy because it has nothing to do with cash transactions. Until this Government can show this House, me, and the Australian public that the public interest to be served by this proposal justifies the reduction of the private right, it will continue to lose the argument. It will lose the argument not only with us but also with increasing numbers within its own ranks. The disquiet on this proposal is not limited to the Liberal and National parties. Do those opposite seriously exclude bodies such as large segments of the Anglican and Catholic churches, the Law Council of Australia, Frank Costigan, and all the famous Australians--

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor lawyers.

—The Labor lawyers. Far be it for me to have to invoke the Labor lawyers. I also refer to the Federated Clerks Union of Australia which is hardly the running dog of the Liberal and National parties. Some members of the left wing might think it is but I do not think any fair minded observer could seriously suggest it. So the Government really has not got harangued against it on this proposal an identifiable collection on just one side of politics; it goes right across the board. That has to tell those opposite something with ever increasing noise and the decibel rating will go up and up each week. What it has to tell them is that they have got it wrong and if they really want to get it even more wrong what they will do is draw an analogy between this and the fringe benefits tax. They will make a very big mistake because the issues that this raises and the principles that this idea assaults--
—You were wrong.

—No, I was not wrong about the fringe benefits tax. I remain unrepentant that the fringe benefits tax was a tax of envy and quite unjustifiably imposed. I remain absolutely unrepentant, but the principles involved in this go far deeper than any partisan argument over tax. This is a fundamental argument about the kind of society we want in this country. It is a fundamental argument as to whether the government believes it can use the club of the state in order to reduce the rights of an individual citizen simply because it has had a systems failure or whether we still observe that rather ancient and I think desirable principle in this country that we start with an assertion of a private right and we can lose that private right or have it reduced if it is demonstrably in the public good. I say to the Government and I say to those who have supported the Government on this issue: `You have failed to discharge that obligation and until you do you will continue to receive the unremitting opposition of the Liberal and National parties on this issue'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), in the debate on this particular issue today. Unlike him, I have spoken in every debate on this issue that has come before the House and have spoken extremely well, if I do say so myself. I cannot recall the Leader of the Opposition speaking in the debates on the Australia Card Bill on the last two occasions, nor in fact can I recall his raising the issue once during the election campaign. Quite clearly, the Australian people and indeed everyone in this place, other than the Leader of the Opposition, recalls that in fact the double dissolution election was triggered by the rejection of the Australia Card legislation. Believe it or not, I do find myself in some agreement with a few issues that have been raised by honourable members on the other side in this debate.
—It is hard to believe.

—It is hard to believe, I know. My friend the honourable member for Chifley suggests that that is a little strange, but it is not because members of the Opposition have raised the question about rational debate and about placing facts before the electorate of Australia so that people may judge for themselves. Those opposite have called for a referendum on this particular issue and have asked for people to be given all the facts so that they can make up their minds. I do not think anybody in this place would reject that as a supposition. I think everybody in this place would arrive at a decision having rationally assessed facts on any particular issue, not just the Australia Card legislation. Unfortunately what we have seen in this place today and on the last two occasions when this issue was introduced and what we are unfortunately seeing out there in our electorates is far from a rational debate. Facts are not being put before the people and consideration is not being given to the merits and, indeed, what our opponents see as being the demerits of this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer very briefly to some of those issues because they have, in fact, been raised today. I refer honourable members to a publication which somehow was floating around in the House the other day. It is headed: `ID Card-Labor's Australia Card'. On the back it says that it is prepared by Senator David MacGibbon, Liberal, Queensland, 307 Queen Street, Brisbane. This publication says that the ID card will not work, it will cost a fortune, it will not protect privacy and it will carry heavy penalties. It then lists what they might be. There is another heading: `What will Australians need to use the card for'. I found this most interesting because it mentioned that if a person goes to hospital he has to have an Australia Card. Thirteen items were listed. The last item deals with the Social Security Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—The honourable member agrees with that because it is in the legislation; and some members opposite can read. I think that is good. The twelfth item deals with claims for Medicare benefits. What has not been said in this document is that the Australia Card will replace the Medicare card. A person has to produce his Medicare card to go to hospital and, at the same time, a person has to produce his card for Medicare benefits. So the Australia Card eliminates the need for the production of the Medicare card.

SPEECH.PARA: The document then lists items which are already encapsulated in the legislation. It mentions baby sitting. This ridiculous notion about a baby sitter was mentioned yesterday. I do not propose to raise that again because it was covered yesterday in Question Time, but what concerns me-I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) would agree with me on this-is that it is important that the people of Australia are at least acquainted with the facts both for and against the argument so that a decision can be made. I am sure honourable members would agree that this puny little publication, which spells it out in the manner that I have gone through, does not put the facts to the people on this issue.

I am pleased to say that at least in my electorate and I know in the electorate of my very good friend, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), we are endeavouring to correct that misinformation and the nonsense that has been peddled by various groups in the community by at least trying to provide them with the other side of the argument. We are prepared to put out information and are prepared to go and talk at public meetings to individuals. Since this whole hoo-ha started about five people have walked into my office off the street or have made an appointment to come and talk to me about this issue. I have had letters and Auschwitz-grams with the barbed wire down the side. Surprisingly, as my colleague the honourable member for Throsby pointed out earlier today, they do come from areas, that do not necessarily give me such a really good vote. I get 12 per cent or 24 per cent of the vote in those areas. So I dismiss a lot of those letters. I also happen to know the names of some of the people who have signed these letters. They are probably card-carrying members of the Liberal Party of Australia. I saw many of them on polling day handing out the `how to vote' cards to the Liberals against me. So, I understand that they have an interest in this particular issue.

What really annoys me is to see people such as Senator Michael Baume touting himself as a senator for southern New South Wales or Wollongong-suggesting that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) members who represent the Illawarra area are running away from their responsibilities or are not prepared to make copies of legislation available or indeed to sit down and explain to constituents what the Australia Card legislation is all about. That is patent nonsense. It adds to the scare-mongering and the rumour-mongering that those opposite are prepared to peddle. But the honourable senator is not alone. The absolute pits is contained in advertisements which are presently being run in the Illawarra Mercury and being put out in pamphlets by the Illawarra branch of the Australian Small Business Association. A number of honourable members have referred to that august body in the debate today and have suggested that they have a little bit of an interest in this particular matter. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) talked about the horrendous effect on small businesses and the dreadful imposition of costs that the Australia Card legislation would have on small business. I have spoken about rational debate and providing the facts. I only hope that that is the case. Nonsense such as this gets into newspapers, with a quarter page advertisement in the Illawarra Mercury. First there is `The Auschtralia Card' with the German spelling, which is an affront to the German people. It has barbed wire running across it, and a blindfolded bearded man in the photograph. It says:
We can stop Labor's ID-database but only with your help!
If the ID-database legislation goes through with its intrusive dossier building sophisticated assets tracking, future Australians can look forward to:
1. Loss of privacy as your computer dossier can be leaked for political purposes or personal vendettas by any of the thousands of junior public servants with access to the computer.
Is that fair and rational? Does that provide facts? Even the honourable member for O'Connor would have to agree that that is not a fair and rational argument. The advertisement goes on:
2. Massive penalties and loss of access to jobs and bank accounts for those whose cards are lost, stolen or cancelled by the authority.
After the debate today, I suggest that we should have that amended to include `or eaten by the dog from Bowral'. The advertisement continues:
3. The end to the traditional healthy Australian attitude towards authority as petty bureaucrats gain greater control over our day-to-day lives.
Wake up Australians-don't give up your traditional Aussie freedom-say no to the intrusive ``licence to live''. Only honest decent Australian have anything to fear.
What does it then go on to do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask for a quid.

—Yes, it asks for money. It is like evangelists in the United States who say, `Send me $1,000 and I will be able to save the world'. This is the nonsense that is being peddled. It does not provide the information, it is far from factual and it is contributing to the hysteria being generated by certain groups. During the debate today, a number of specific issues have been raised on which it is important to touch. The centrepiece of what I am endeavouring to get across to honourable members is quite simply that I do not believe that any member of parliament who represents his constituency fairly is in any way shirking or backing away from his responsibilities by providing information to his constituents so that a rational debate on any issue can be entered into. That is a laudable aim, but what concerns me greatly is that hysteria is being generated by a select few out there. It seems at the moment that there is no other issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has said that the media are now backtracking and prepared to pick up on the issue. We can all peddle stories about the media and what they have done and are supposed to have done in the past. Recently, one of my colleagues told me that he was discussing the Australia Card with some journalist friends and asked why they were starting to run the line about the negative aspects of the Australia Card and running a paranoia campaign in all forms of the media. They said that they thought that they would see what they could get the Government to do as it was fairly quiet because the Budget had not yet arrived.

There may be some people like that, but I do not subscribe to the view of the Leader of the Opposition. He has tried to totally discredit the media by suggesting that they treated the Opposition badly. He has blamed the media and some of the words he used were: `They were part of the conspiracy of silence about the problems of the Australia Card'. I do not subscribe to that view at all. I believe that, as part of the information provision that is necessary for rational debate, every side of the argument must be put. However, I also believe that the Government's argument is the correct one. I have not yet heard any issue which will in any way change my mind or make me change my support, and the support of the overwhelming majority of the members of my local constituency, for this legislation. If one has nothing to hide, one has nothing to fear. It is as simple as that. No talk about Goebbels techniques or misinformation will make any difference to that.

The Leader of the Opposition in his contribution raised another issue. He said that Labor members had expressed their reservations about the Australia Card and spoken against it. That is true. They have done that in the past, as it is the right of any individual in society. The honourable member for O'Connor has taken up the cause of the Liberal-National Party coalition and it is his political right to do so, just as it is the right of Labor members to put their views. However, unlike the Opposition and those in the community who are not prepared to concede on certain issues, we have mechanisms within the ALP to resolve issues, and that is what has happened.

On Tuesday this legislation came to the ALP Caucus before the Bill was introduced into Parliament. Senator Susan Ryan, the Minister responsible, discussed the legislation yet again. A number of questions were asked on it and it was then put to the vote as is the wont in the Labor Party Caucus. It was passed without a dissenting voice. That is part and parcel of the process of the Labor Government in action. We are confronted with legislation and an issue which, as we know from the contributions made by honourable members on both sides of the House, will lead to a more fair and equitable system in terms of taxation revenue, social security benefits and illegal immigration.

It seems to me that many of those issues have been swept under the carpet. We have a list of when the Australia Card is to be put into place and how often one has to use it. We have heard the scare tactics saying that one has to carry the Australia Card and if one does not, one is in big trouble. That is nonsense. Clause 8 says that one is not required to carry it. However, nonsense is still peddled. I saw a great story in, I think, the Bulletin last week, with three scenarios of people caught without their Australia Card. The first one was appalling. It said that an Aboriginal was walking down the street and was accosted by a policeman who said, `Show me your Australian Card'. The Aboriginal said, `I don't have to'. He was lumbered into gaol and I cannot remember whether it went on to say that the next day he was found hanged in his cell, but the implication was there. That is patent scaremongering nonsense, put about by people in the community. The journalist was just repeating the sorts of stories peddled by different groups in the community.

To have a fair assessment of the Australia Card legislation, what it says and what it will do, is the responsibility of every member in this place. All the uses to which the Australia Card is to be put-opening bank accounts, welfare payments, Medicare replacements, taxation, employment and so on-are the issues that affect most people in the community, but they will be affected only the once.

About the other issues of investments, shares, trusts, primary production, land transaction, safety deposit boxes, futures contracts and so on, there are not a hell of a lot of constituents in Macarthur who are worried about those sorts of issues. Therefore, I believe that the issues being generated by consideration of the Australia Card legislation, which has suddenly become all things to all people and is the great bogey legislation which will take away individual rights, privacy considerations and so on, are all nonsense. I believe, as does every member who sits on this side of the House, as well as a few who sit slightly on the other side, that this legislation will do the things that it is intended to do.

Some speakers have had reservations about one or two issues associated with computer hackers and privacy. Having seen information on this and listened to the debate, I feel that such worries no longer exist. I hope that when the legislation is passed through the House, as it will be, those in the Senate who will determine its fate will be swayed by the arguments put here and not by the sorts of nonsensical, paranoid, schizophrenic arguments going on out there with people suddenly changing their minds, with conversions along the road--

TALK.START.PARA: —To Damascus.

—To Damascus or anywhere else, or to Bowral to see card-chewing dogs, or wherever it may be. I hope that the legislation receives the assent of both Houses of Parliament, is put in place as quickly as possible and goes on to solve the problems of taxation and welfare fraud and illegal immigration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening in the House we are considering the most far-reaching and invasive social or economic legislation that this Parliament has ever considered or any government in Australia's history has ever contemplated thrusting upon the Australian population. No other legislation and no other concept ever considered by government would have had the far-reaching, disruptive and social engineering impact of the identity card legislation. This Government is very aware of the consequences of this legislation. Hence it refers to it as the Australia Card, colours the card green and gold and uses attractive models on the card to make sure that it looks attractive to the average member of the community. That is the mentality of this Government. It deals in public relations and large and expensive advertising campaigns.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a $2m campaign running for the ID card at the present time. It will be very interesting to see which agency gets it and what style of campaign it will be running. What this does not cover up is the fundamental reason why this Government is moving to have an ID card. It is part of its socialist plan. Nothing will aid the implementation of the democratic socialist policies of the Australian Labor Party more than to make every Australian man, woman and child the subject of a card. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is at present sitting on the front bench, the other day talked about not Australians, not Australian men, women and children, not voters or constituents, but card subjects. We are no longer people; we are card subjects. I guess the next step will be card numbers. That is exactly what this Government has in mind for us.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used to like it.

—Those opposite were talking about how this card will not invade the privacy of the average Australian. The Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), who cannot even guard our coast, is trying to interject and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) is talking about how I used to like the idea of a card. I did, but I changed my mind. I spent four months on a committee and I learnt about it. No one on the other side of the House is able to change his or her mind. When will Caucus get a free go on this matter? When will its members have a conscience vote on the ID card to see how well it would go then? I tell honourable members opposite that more than 50 per cent of them do not support it. They are running scared of the consequences of it because they know what will happen when 16 million Australians get a letter saying, `Come in and have your photograph taken, and by the way, bring your birth certificate and your marriage certificate with you, and then come back to sign the card and pick it up'. That is exactly what will happen and those opposite know the consequences of it.

SPEECH.PARA: But the reason I do not support this card is that it just will not work. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said the other day on the AM program that the card will do something about the black economy. The black economy is the cash economy. The Minister for Community Services and Health has said that the use of the card really will not touch the cash economy. He said that in this chamber during the last Parliament. The Minister should correct the Prime Minister because he is acting under a misconception.

In recent days those opposite have been at great pains to address the civil liberties and privacy aspects of this matter. We have heard the argument that there will be dedicated lines of communication. But they will be part of the Telecom Australia network. I am waiting for someone to tell us in this House exactly what a dedicated line is. It is not something special. Telecom is not about to go out and dig trenches to put a special line in to transmit the ID card data. The line will be part of the Telecom network but it will be used for implementation of ID card legislation. It will not take very long for people to realise which line that is.

We were talking today about encryption devices. We heard a definition from the Minister responsible in this place. Let me tell the Minister, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister for Resources, who are sitting on the front bench, that one Ted Turner-I wonder whether they have heard of him; he likes racing yachts-made millions of dollars selling encryption decoding devices. They are cheap and easy to get, and they can crack the encryption code on all data transmissions. I make a prediction. When we get this ID card, the second edition of the hacker's handbook that comes out after it will contain: `How to crack the ID card data network'.

The other story that the Government has been peddling in recent days is that only a few public servants will have access to the data and the data will include a digitised photograph, which will be an interesting thing to have. I wonder whether the average Australian has considered the consequences of having one's photograph digitised on some sort of electronic data device? But only certain public servants will have access to it. That is fine; but once they push the button and get a hard copy, what will stop them putting it on a photocopier? I would like to hear the Minister's answer to that. Also, these certain public servants will have it recorded that they had access to the file. What will stop them accessing the file of the Minister's data, for example, but at the same time pushing the button and getting the file for the whole of New South Wales?

I remind the House that not so long ago all social security records for Victoria were for sale and that selected records held by the Health Insurance Commission of income for certain doctors had been made available. Certain things have dropped off the back of a truck. I do not believe that this Government, or any government, can guarantee the security or integrity of the entire Australian Public Service, nor can it give a guarantee that some of these computer geniuses that we have developed in this country in recent years cannot crack the dedicated communications network which will be used to transmit all this ID information around the country.

We have been talking about how these cards will be useful for cracking down on social security fraud, notwithstanding the fact that less than one per cent of social security fraud is identity based, and we have talked about how it will be good for cracking down on the black economy-and the Prime Minister and the Minister responsible seem to have a difference of opinion about this. But now we are talking about illegal immigrants. I will tell the Minister about illegal immigrants. There are quite a few in my electorate. They are up in the hills. Whether or not they have a card, the immigration Minister will not be able to find them unless he hires a whole stack of police to do that. That could be the next phase. After we get the cards, the numbers and the photographs, this Government will hire a whole stack more police. Notionally they will start chasing illegal immigrants. There are an awful lot of them around the hills of the far north coast of New South Wales. If the Minister wants to look there, I will be more than happy to show him where the people are. But I suggest that he get a few more members of the Australian Federal Police to help him, because that is the only way he will stop illegal immigration. Whether or not these people have a card will not make much difference to them.

The Government will not really come clean as to why it wants this card. It wants it to collect tax from people who supposedly are not paying it at the present time and to compensate for the inefficiencies of the Australian Taxation Office. Those opposite also want it in terms of their future tax plans because the numbers will become part of our commercial and social activities. This Government has a study under way on a wealth tax. The other day the Australian Council of Trade Unions said that in principle it is in favour of a wealth tax, and that what we really need to make a wealth tax work is some way of drawing together all the fiscal assets and income sources of every member of the community-and the best way to do it is with an ID card. It is the one ingredient the Government needs to bring in a wealth tax; that is, a percentage of net assets every year in cash which will be sent off to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to supplement the Government's income tax gathering.

No measure would facilitate the implementation of socialist policies more than the numbering, photographing and recording of every man, woman and child, plus their assets, income sources and everything to do with the people's families, employment histories and relationship with the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Socialism by stealth.

—It is not socialism by stealth; it is blatant socialism. It is the ingredient that takes Australia one step further towards the totalitarian state. This Government-particularly the left wing of it-could be described as a government which seems to be in relentless pursuit of totalitarianism, and not only in terms of its foreign policy. The Minister should not laugh. He should look at the Government's foreign policy. It is lined up with most of the totalitarian states. The Government will not acknowledge that publicly, but it is so. In terms of where we are going and the economic framework of this country, we are heading down the track of totalitarianism. Unfortunately, there are not enough men of principle on the other side of the House who are prepared to say, `Enough is enough. Let us knock this thing on the head'.
