TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1, add at the end the following sub-clause:
``(3) A day shall not be fixed, by Proclamation under subsection (2), for a provision of this Act to come into operation unless and until:

(a) the Governor-General has submitted to the electors in each State and Territory qualified to vote for the election of the House of Representatives the question `Do you approve the introduction of the proposed Australia Card?'; and
(b) a majority of all electors voting has answered that question `Yes'.''.

The issue of whether we should have a referendum on the Australia Card seems a very simple one. A referendum could be held with no cost to the community because the Governor-General has already told us that the Government proposes to have a referendum during this session of parliament on a matter relating to the term of this Parliament. There are other reasons why a referendum is needed. It has been said throughout the debate, but I repeat, that the Government does not have a mandate on this issue. On the basis of the election figures it is patently false to argue that, in terms of a simple majority referendum basis, the Government got the approval of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what it means.

—For the benefit of the interjector, in his State of Victoria the Australian Labor Party got 47 per cent of the vote; the Liberal-National Party-Australian Democrats got 51 per cent of primary votes for the House of Representatives. I add that the national figures were Australian Labor Party, 45.8 per cent; the Liberal-National Party-Australian Democrats, 52 per cent.
—Who won?

—The Australian Labor Party won seats but did not win on this issue on the basis of the total votes of the people of Australia. All that honourable members opposite need to do is to vote for this amendment to have the proof without any problems at all. Furthermore, there was no proper debate on the Australia Card. The constitutional requirement that there be a public, community debate between the first and second introductions of the Bill was not met. As has been said, that was not achieved primarily because of the failure of journalists reporting this place to tell people about the issues. In typical fashion they wanted to talk about whether somebody was right or wrong. That situation was repeated on the Sunday show when two very senior journalists interviewing the Prime Mininster (Mr Hawke)-might I add, like two school kids interviewing their principal-asked him whether he would or whether he would not. They did not ask him why in this legislation it is necessary to fine an employer for simply failing to ask an employee for an identification card. They did not ask why that employer would be fined $20,000. That would have been a good question to put to the Prime Minister on that Sunday morning television show. Those journalists might have asked why real estate agents, banks, stockbrokers, stock and station agents, lawyers and others could be fined up to $100,000 simply for failing to act as enforcers of this legislation by failing to report to the Commissioner of Taxation the card number and business transactions of their clients.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps, considering those journalists' technical experience and knowledge of landlines as used in the television industry, they should have questioned the Prime Minister on his Minister's claims that landlines are secure and free from interruption and interference. Those journalists might also have taken the time to get a bit of international advice, as I have done today. In fact, I have had a call from a person who has just spent a year in Sweden. That person told me that he had to have his ID card to buy a train ticket; the ID number was printed on the train ticket; and if he lost that ticket people had access to information on him. The 10-digit identification number is so constructed that it shows the year, month and day of a person's birth. The numbers are put in that order. It shows the district in which a person lives-Sweden has 99 districts. It gives numbers-odds and evens-to identify whether a person is male or female and it uses a final number if it is necessary to distinguish two people from the same district who were born on the same day and who are of the same sex. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) can deny that if he likes. It is quite authentic as far as I am concerned: we had the phone call into my office today. That is where it gets to forty years down the track. This Government cannot commit any future government to a particular course of action, and this is the method by which governments can gradually get one generation after another more used to such a system, and of course they can then intrude further into people's privacy.

The other reason this amendment should succeed and a subsequent referendum be held is that the recent massive drop in the popularity of the ID card is evidence that the community did not understand the issues of the ID card during the election. The people are entitled to a deliberate, simple majority vote under the proper procedures of a referendum. To answer some of the complaints of honourable members today, our subsequent referendum Bill will require the sending to all eligible voters of the arguments for and against the proposal. Would that not be an improvement? We have had complaint after complaint here today that the debate has been irrational. Under the legislation we propose we would send to all eligible voters in Australia the story as the Government sees it as well as that put by our side, giving them the opportunity to decide for themselves. Of course during a referendum their minds will be concentrated on the issues.

It is the Australian people who must decide. This matter has been dealt with in all sorts of cavalier fashion today. It was remarkable that at Question Time when I sought to find out whether the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) had eventually done his homework and discovered whether or not he could guarantee to this Parliament the security of the landlines that his department will provide for this system, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) said to me, `You will get it when we are good and ready'. I think he thought he was talking to me but he was not-he was talking to the only side of politics that is prepared to protect the 16 million Australians who are deeply concerned about this issue, who are deeply concerned about whether the information that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) told us today would be tripping back and forth between the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office, and is already doing so, will be secure. The Government has told us unequivocally that the information on these wonderful new landlines will be secure. No other organisation in the world, including the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Pentagon and others, has been able to protect such information.

The Australian people must decide whether they wish to pay the price of loss of privacy, the price of huge inconvenience and draconian fines for basically innocent activities in return for a doubtful increase in revenue-there is no real evidence that revenue will be improved-and an even more doubtful opportunity to get tax cuts. Everyone who has spoken on this issue today has made the point that the Government wants the money to spend the money, not to refund to the people by way of tax cuts. They are the questions that the Australian community is entitled to consider. Do Australians want this wonderful proposal, or would they be prepared to forgo the final solution that the Government offers them? I suggest that is something the Government has an obligation to ask them because this is a threshold matter; this is a question of changing the way of life of Australians as we know it. I thought the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) was spot on when he said the Government needs the numbering process to introduce a wealth tax, because I am aware that one of the requirements of such legislation is that every piece of property in the Registrar of Titles offices around Australia be progressively numbered. That will be achieved through the progressive sale or transfer of property.

We ask every member of this chamber to support the amendment. It is an amendment that is fair to the people of Australia. It will not be costly and it is not a proposal that it can be argued has something to do with just the ordinary business of government. It is very much a threshold matter involving a massive change in the way Australians will live.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). In so doing I want to say first that I regret that the Government has again gagged this debate and intends to guillotine this legislation through without providing an opportunity for members to discuss it. Indeed, that is what it is attempting to do in regard to the Australian public; it wants to ram this legislation through a joint sitting without providing the opportunity for the Australian public to express its views. That is what the amendment is all about. It will give the Australian people an opportunity to express a view on what must be one of the most serious changes ever contemplated to the relationship between the people and their Government in this country or indeed in the majority of Western democracies.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are talking about here is a change in the relationship between the Government and its people. If this proposal succeeds no longer will the Government be responsible to the people-the people will be responsible to the Government. If the proposal succeeds and is implemented and if, as the Government suggests, it will not be possible without a card to get a job, to access one's bank account, to rent or buy a house and so on, clearly our ability to operate as citizens of this community will depend on the Government giving us that licence. For the first time our ability to operate in the community will be reliant on a licence from the Government. Our ability to get a job, to transact business with our bank and to rent a home will be reliant on the Government giving us our number. I put it to the Committee that that for the first time will mean a reversal of the onus in Australia. No longer will the Federal Government be responsible to the people, but suddenly the people will be responsible to the Government.

The Australian people ought to have the opportunity to decide on other issues. The first question, of course, is whether the proposal will work. Is the majority of tax evasion and social security fraud a result of people using false identities? Certainly there is no proof that that is the case. The Department of Social Security says that the problem is not false identity; it is the misstatement of income or change in income. All the reports, including the Auditor-General's report, the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure and the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, found that the problems of tax evasion were not identity problems; they were problems in the operation of the Australian Taxation Office.

So the first point is: will the card work? Is the problem identity fraud? The answer is no, it is not. Even if that were the major problem, would the Australia Card provide an answer? Again the answer is no because clearly people will be able to get false cards. They will manufacture cards or use stolen cards so, as many speakers from this side, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), have said, it will not touch the real area of tax evasion in the cash economy. This card will not touch the cash economy.

Do honourable members opposite think that the card will stop an agreement between an employer and an employee to base a contract of employment on cash where there is compliance by both parties to the deal because the employer perhaps has to pay a lower rate and the employee gets tax free money? It will not. It will not touch the cash economy. So the answer to the first question of whether it will work is no, firstly because the majority of tax evasion and social security fraud is not identity fraud. Secondly, it would not stop identity fraud even if that were the major problem.

The second question to be answered and to be considered by the Australian public-and which should be considered by the Australian public in a referendum-is whether the proposal is cost-effective. We have to consider first the cost to the Government. What is the cost to the Government? The Government says that over the first 10 years it will cost us something like $750m to implement. That is an extraordinarily conservative estimate. Like the cost of the new Parliament House, it is likely to be doubled or trebled. Regrettably, because of the Government's gag I do not have time tonight to go into the estimate of the cost to the Government of implementing the card. If the Government really thinks it can employ an extra 2,150 public servants, open over 40 new offices, get every Australian into those offices and have them photographed and issued with an ID card for the sort of money the Government is talking about it really believes in fairies.

The second point is the cost to business. The Government just will not come clean on providing to the Australian public its estimate of the cost to business. It will not even provide its estimate, not even a conservative estimate. We know that elements of the Government have opposed the card because of their view of the cost to business. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, said on 17 November last year at an earlier stage of the discussion on the Australia Card that doubts were expressed by the Business Regulation Review Unit in relation to the Australia Card. What were those doubts based on? The cost of the card. When we asked what were the details of those doubts, why was the Unit questioning the cost-effectiveness of the card and what were the concerns it was raising in relation to the cost to business of the card what answer did the Government give us? It said, `We will not provide you with that information'.

So on 14 November under the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act I applied for that information. I have had a running battle under the FOI Act in relation to information from the Minister. Has he provided it? Tomorrow morning the battle goes on. The matter will go before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a preliminary conference and hopefully it will set a hearing date so that the Tribunal can drag the Department before it to provide the information. Why is the Government hiding the information? Why will it not tell us its estimate of the cost to business of the card? Why will it not tell the Australian public? It is a fairly simple question. The Business Regulation Review Unit has made an estimate. The Government will not give it to the public. Why? Because the cost to business is astronomical. The Government is terrified of providing that information and it is doing everything it can to stall my FOI case because it does not want to reveal that information before the Joint Sitting.

Finally, is the revenue suggested by the Government likely to be raised? It suggests that the card will raise $1,000m a year. That is the same revenue that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is claiming is being raised now because he is starting to take action to overcome the inefficiencies in the Australian Taxation Office. He said last night that the Government has this extra revenue because the Tax Office is starting to improve its administrative performance. Under the Budget he wants another 640 officers in the Treasury Department to start cracking down on tax fraud and tax evasion. That increase was for the Tax Office alone. That is to get the revenue that the ID card is supposed to raise. In the same way, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is running around the country saying that the Government is saving all this money in social security because it is cracking down on fraud. That is the same fraud the Government is claiming the ID card will stop. The Government cannot claim the benefit of all that revenue and say that the same revenue--

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendment moved by the Opposition and it does so because the amendment clearly repudiates the way in which this country has been governed for the past 86 years. I point out to the Opposition-it appears not to know-that within this country we have a system of representative government whereby parties go to an election, offer a program at that election and ask for the people's support for that program which would be carried out in the following three years. Some of the program may be unpopular. Some of it may not at the time be supported by the people but at the end of those three years a judgment is made upon the government in terms of what it has done. That is the way in which this country has been governed for the past 86 years. It is a system of representative democracy which, at its heart, says that when one elects a government that government has three years to do the job and will be judged at the end of those three years on its total job.

SPEECH.PARA: We are required to have a referendum only in relation to changes to the Constitution. Throughout the history of this country the system that has operated is a system of representative government. This Government is certainly not going to accept the overthrow of that principle in this amendment for short term populist reasons. If we introduced the sort of system that has been recommended by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) it would be a system of government by public opinion poll; every time the government had an issue which was somehow unpopular that issue would be put to the people. In the last few years, this government has made a number of tough decisions. Some of those decisions include issues on the assets test and the fringe benefits tax which would not have been supported by the people at the time. We are now beginning to see the long term benefits of those tough decisions.

Last night's Budget is a reflection of the fact that because we refuse to govern by public opinion poll but take the tough long term decisions, the benefits are now flowing through to the Australian people. The same is very much true of the Australia Card. Whatever its present popularity, this Government believes that it is essential to complete the tax reforms that we have introduced and we will pass this legislation. We are fully prepared to be judged by the Australian people at the end of our term on the total achievements of this Government. The card will be an important part in ensuring a fairer, more equitable tax system and in ensuring that those who should pay their taxes do so. It will ensure that social security benefits are paid to those in need.

I make a general point to conclude. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) spoke on the card this afternoon. While he lacked most of the facts, like many of the Opposition speakers on this issue, I grant him that he made a coherent argument which needed to be responded to. He raised, I think, two major challenges. He said, `If a bureaucratic system is not working you must find out what is wrong'. Of course, this is the very thing that this Government did. I refer to the major reports that have been presented to this House. For instance, in Mr Costigan's report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union he identified that one of the great sources of our problems was the lack of effective identification. Whatever his logical position now, in his report, critical was the lack of identification in our system. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled A Taxing Problem gives identification as one of the major problems in the system. The present Commissioner of Taxation identifies the identification problem. The challenge put out by the Leader of the Opposition was to find out what is wrong with the system first of all. On all the evidence, a fundamental flaw in our system is a lack of adequate identification. Honourable members should have also listened very carefully to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) this morning. The Minister, who has battled with this problem in the period that he has been the Minister for Social Security-a very great Minister for Social Security-pointed out the identification problems and, of course, the matching problems in that area.

We believe, therefore, that we have responded very clearly to the challenge put out by the Leader of the Opposition to identify what is the problem within the system. Secondly, he said, `There are two criteria by which we will judge the Australia Card'. One was its cost-efficiency. As I said during the second reading debate, the fact that the card will bring in $4.7 billion over the next 10 years is something that has been before the public for 18 months and is something which has scarcely been seriously challenged. Indeed, most of the people who have looked at it objectively, even some of our major critics, have said that we have probably underestimated the amounts that will be brought in by the Australia Card. There is no doubt that this single weapon, affecting, as it does, taxation and social security, and inhibiting illegal immigration, provides the single most powerful weapon to deal with this set of problems.

Finally, let me say in regard to privacy, which was the other challenge that the Leader of the Opposition issued, that not a single new fact is added to any of the databases of the Commonwealth by this proposal. What the proposal does, in addition, is to provide in this country a finer system of privacy protection than any that exist in any other state. I am therefore perfectly convinced that, having regard to the fact that the argument will go on, we have responded clearly to the major points made by the Leader of the Opposition. I am confident that that will be supported increasingly by the Australian people. We will not accept the repudiation of the fact that this country has been governed by a system of representative government, whereby a government is elected. In this case the majority is not even recognised by some members of the Opposition; they should look around the Chamber. That support which we acquired in the July election entitles us to govern for the next three years and we are confident about the judgment that will be made at the end of that three years.

Mr Young to move-

(1) that a joint standing committee be appointed to act for and represent the Parliament, as the client for the new Parliament House, in all matters concerned with the planning, design and construction of the new Parliament House and all matters incidental thereto.

(2) that the committee consider and approve the developed design for the building which, in conjunction with the revised brief for Parliament House, dated August 1980, shall be used as the basis for the design and construction of the new Parliament House, unless both Houses resolve to vary any section of the brief or have any section reconsidered by the committee.

(3) that the committee determine user requirements for approved non-building items and consider other issues relevant to ensuring that the requirements of Parliament are fully met when transferring to the new building.
(4) that the committee also consider and report on matters coming within the terms of section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 as may be referred to it by-
(a) resolution of either House of the Parliament, or
(b) the Minister responsible for administering the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957.
(5) That the committee consist of-
(a) the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives;
(b) the Minister responsible for administering the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979;
(c) 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, and

(d) 3 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and 3 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or independent Senators.
(6) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(7) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint standing committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(8) That the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives be joint chairmen of the committee.

(9) That in matters of procedure, each of the chairmen whether or not occupying the chair, have a deliberative vote and, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman occupying the chair have a casting vote.
(10) That in matters other than those of procedure, each of the chairmen, whether or not occupying the chair, have a deliberative vote only.
(11) That 5 members of the committee, one of whom is the President or the Speaker, constitute a quorum of the committee.
(12) That the committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(13) That the committee appoint the chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(14) That the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the members of that sub-committee.

(15) That members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(16) That the committee or any sub-committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(17) That the committee or any sub-committee have power to move from place to place.
(18) That a sub-committee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(19) That a sub-committee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(20) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.

(21) That the committee or any sub-committee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Joint Standing Committee on the new Parliament House appointed during previous Parliaments.

(22) That the committee be authorised to provide, on behalf of the Parliament, all necessary information concerning the functional requirements for the new Parliament House and matters incidental thereto direct to the Parliament House Construction Authority as the authority responsible to Parliament to undertake or arrange for the planning, design and construction of the new Parliament House.
(23) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(24) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.
